Original:
1.1 Dhritarashtra said  What did my people and the sons of Pandu do when they had assembled
together eager for battle on the holy plain of Kurukshetra, O Sanjaya.
Translated: ..1.1.. Dhritarashtra said – O Sanjay! What did I and Pandu's sons do when they gathered in the sacred land of Kurukshetra, desirous of war (yuyutsavah)?

Original:
1.2. Sanjaya said  Having seen the army of the Pandavas drawn up in battle-array,
King Duryodhana then approached his teacher (Drona) and spoke these words.
Translated: .1.2..Sanjay said - Seeing the formation of the Pandava army, King Duryodhana went to Acharya Drona and said these words.

Original:
1.3. "Behold, O Teacher! this mighty army of the sons of Pandu,
arrayed by the son of Drupada, thy wise disciple.
Translated: ..1.3..O Acharya! Behold this mighty army of the sons of Pandu, arrayed in array by your wise disciple Drupadaputra (Dhrishtadyumna).

Original:
1.4. Here are heroes, mighty archers, eal in battle to Bhima
and Arjuna, Yoyudhana (Satyaki), Virata and Drupada, of the great car (mighty
warriors).
Translated: ..1.4..This army has great archers and brave warriors, who are equal to Bhima and Arjuna in battle, like Yuyudhan, Virat and the great warrior King Drupada.

Original:
1.5. "Dhrishtaketu, chekitana and the valiant king of Kasi, Purujit
and Kuntibhoja and Saibya, the best men.
Translated: ..1.5..Dhrishtaketu, Chekitana, the mighty King of Kashi, Purujit, Kuntibhoja and Shaibya, the best among humans.

Original:
1.6. "The strong Yodhamanyu and the brave Uttamaujas, the son
of Subhadra (Abhimanyu, the son of Subhadra and Arjuna), and the sons of
Draupadi, all of great chariots (great heroes).
Translated: ..1.6..The mighty Yudhamanyu, the strong Uttamauja, the sons of Subhadra (Abhimanyu) and Draupadi -- all of them are great warriors.
..1.7..O Dwijottam! Know the special warriors who are on our side too; For your information, I will tell you the names of the heroes of my army.

Original:
1.8. "Thyself and Bhishma, and Karna and also Kripa, the victorious
in war, Asvatthama, Vikarna, and also Bhurisrava, the son of Somadatta.
Translated: .1.8..One is yourself, Bhishma, Karna, and the war-winning Kripacharya and the son of Ashwatthama, Vikarna and Somdutt.

Original:
1.9. "And also many other heroes who are ready to give up their
lives for my sake, armed with various weapons and missiles, all well-skilled
in battle.
Translated: ..1.9..There are many other brave men who are ready to sacrifice their lives for me, equipped with many types of weapons and skilled in war.

Original:
1.10. "This army of ours marshalled by Bhishma is insufficient,
whereas that army of theirs marshelled by Bhima is sufficient.
Translated: .1.10..Our army protected by Bhishma is inadequate; But their army protected by Bheema is sufficient or, our army protected by Bheema is unlimited but their army protected by Bheema is limited.

Original:
1.11. "Therefore do ye all, stationed in your respective positions,
in the several divisions of the army, protect Bhishma alone."
Translated: .1.11..Standing at your respective places on different fronts, all of you should protect Bhishma Pitamah from all sides.

Original:
1.12. His glorious grandsire (Bhishma), the oldest of the Kauravas,
in order to cheer Duryodhana, now roared like a lion, and blew his conch.
Translated: .1.12..At that time, Bhishma, the oldest among the Kauravas and the glorious grandfather, created joy in the heart of Duryodhana and made a loud roar and blew his conch.

Original:
1.13. Then (following Bhishma), conches and kettledrums, tabors,
drums and cow horns blared forth ite suddenly (from the Kaurava side)
and the sound was tremendous.
Translated: ..1.13..After that, musical instruments like conch, drums, drums and horns started playing simultaneously, which made a very terrible sound.

Original:
1.14. Then, also, Madhava (Krishna) and the son of Pandu (Arjuna),
seated in the magnificent chariot, yoked with white horses, blew divine
conches.
Translated: ..1.14..After this, Madhav (Shri Krishna) and Pandu's son Arjun, sitting in a grand chariot with white horses, also blew their divine conch shells.

Original:
1.15. Hrishikesha blew the Panchajanya and Arjuna blew the Devadatta
and Bhima (the wolf-bellied), the doer of terrible deeds, blew the great
conch Paundra.
Translated: 1.15 Lord Hrishikesh blew Panchjanya, Dhananjay (Arjun) blew Devdutt and Bhima, who did terrible deeds, blew the great conch called Paundu.

Original:
1.16. The king Yodhishthira, the son of Kunti, blew the Anantavijaya;
Nakula and Sahadeva blew the Sughosha and the Manipushpaka.
Translated: ..1.16..Kunti's son King Yudhishthir blew the conch called Anant Vijay and Nakul and Sahadeva blew the conch called Sughosh and Manipushpak respectively.

Original:
1.17. The king of Kasi, an exellent archer, Sikhandi, the mighty
car-warrior, Dhrishtadyumna and Virata and Satyaki, the unconered.
Translated: ..1.17..Kashiraj having the best bow, Shikhandi, the expert warrior, Dhrishtadyumna, King Virat and the invincible Satyaki.

Original:
1.18. Drupada and the sons of Draupadi, O Lord of the earth, and
the son of Subhadra, the mighty-armed, blew their conches separately.
Translated: ..1.18..O King! King Drupada, Draupadi's son and the mighty Saubhadra (Abhimanyu) all blew different conch shells.

Original:
1.19. That tumultuous sound rent the hearts of (the members of)
Dhritarashtra's party, making both the heaven and the earth resound.
Translated: ..1.19..That terrible roar started echoing in the sky and the earth and it tore the hearts of Dhritarashtra's sons.

Original:
1.20. Then, seeing the people of Dhritarashtra’s party standing
arrayed and the discharge of weapons about to begin, Arjuna, the son of
Pandu, whose ensign was a monkey, took up his bow and said the following
to Krishna, O Lord of the earth.
Translated: ..1.20..O Mahipate! Thus, when the war was about to begin, Kapidhwaja Arjuna, seeing Dhritarashtra's sons positioned, raised his bow and said these words to Lord Hrishikesh.

Original:
1.21 Arjuna said  In the middle between the two armies, place my chariot,
O krishna, so that I may behold those who stand here desirous to fight,
and know with whom I must fight, when the battle is about to commence.
Translated: ..1.21..Arjun said - Hey! Achyut, make my chariot stand between the two armies.

Original:
1.22. Arjuna said  In the middle between the two armies, place my chariot,
O krishna, so that I may behold those who stand here desirous to fight,
and know with whom I must fight, when the battle is about to commence.
Translated: ..1.22..So that I can observe these people standing with the desire for war, with whom I have to fight in this war.

Original:
1.23. For I desire to observe those who are assembled here to fight,
wishing to please in battle the evil-minded Duryodhana (the son of Dhritarashtra).
Translated: ..1.23..These kings and the lovers of foolish Dhartarashtra (Duryodhana) who have gathered here in the war, I will see those warriors.

Original:
1.24. Sanjaya said  Thus addressed by Arjuna, Krishna, having stationed that
best of chariots, O Dhritarashtra, in the midst of the two armies.
Translated: ..1.24..Sanjay said – O Bharat (Dhritarashtra)! On Arjuna saying this, Lord Hrishikesh placed the best chariot between the two armies.

Original:
1.25. In front of Bhishma and Drona, and all the rulers of the
earth, said: "O Arjuna (son of Pritha), behold these Kurus gathered together."
Translated: ..1.25.. In front of Bhishma, Drona and all the rulers of the earth, he said, “O Partha, look at the Kauravas gathered here”.

Original:
1.26. Then, Arjuna (son of Pritha) saw there (in the armies) stationed,
fathers and grandfathers, teachers, maternal uncles, brothers, sons, grandsons
and friends too.
Translated: ..1.26..There Arjun saw his father's brothers, grandfathers, teachers, maternal uncles, brothers, sons, grandsons, friends, father-in-laws and brother-in-laws standing in those two armies.

Original:
1.27. (He saw) fathers-in-law and friends also in both the armies.
The son of Kunti, Arjuna, seeing all those kinsmen thus standing arrayed,
spoke this, sorrowfully filled with deep pity.
Translated: 1.27. Seeing all those relatives standing like this, Kunti's son Arjun's heart was filled with compassion and he said this in sadness.

Original: 1.28. Arjuna said  Seeing these, my kinsmen, O krishna, arrayed, eager to fight.
Translated: 1.28 1.29 Arjun said - O Krishna! Seeing these relatives present with the desire to fight, my limbs become weak, my mouth is also dry and my body is trembling and thrilled.

Original:
1.29. My limbs fail and my mouth is parched, my body ivers and
my hair stands on end.
Translated: 1.28 1.29 Arjun said - O Krishna!  Seeing these relatives present with the desire to fight, my limbs become weak, my mouth is also dry and my body is trembling and thrilled.

Original:
1.30. The (bow) Gandiva slips from my hand, and also my skins burns
all over; I am unable even to stand and my mind is reeling, as it were.
Translated: ..1.30..Gandiva (bow) is falling from my hand and the skin is burning. My mind is becoming confused, and I am unable to stand.

Original:
1.31. And I see adverse omens, O Kesava. I do not see any good
in killing my kinsmen in battle.
Translated: ..1.31..O Keshav! I am seeing the opposite in the omens and I do not see any benefit in killing my relatives in the war.

Original:
1.32. I desire not victory, O Krishna, nor kingdom, nor pleasures.
Of what avail is dominion to us, O Krishna, or pleasures or even life?
Translated: ..1.32..O Krishna! I neither want victory, nor kingdom, nor happiness. Hey Govind! What use do we have from the state or from pleasures or even from living?

Original:
1.33. Those for whose sake we desire kingdom, enjoyments and pleasures,
stand here in battle, having renounced life and wealth.
Translated: ..1.33..Those for whom we desire kingdom, enjoyment and happiness, they are the ones who have given up the hope of wealth and life and are standing in the war.

Original:
1.34. Teachers, fathers, sons and also grandfathers, maternal uncles,
fathers-in-law, grandsons, brothers-in-law and other relatives,-
Translated: ..1.34..Those people are Gurujan, paternal uncle, uncle, son, paternal grandfather, father-in-law, grandson, shyalak and other relatives.

Original:
1.35. These I do not wish to kill, though they kill me, O Krishna,
even for the sake of dominion over the three worlds; leave alone killing
them for the sake of the earth.
Translated: ..1.35..O Madhusudan!  I don't want to kill them even if they kill me or for the kingdom of Trilokya, to say nothing of the earth.

Original:
1.36. By killing these sons of Dhritarashtra, what pleasure can
be ours, O Janardana? Only sin will accrue to us from killing these felons.
Translated: ..1.36..O Janardan! What pleasure will we get by killing the sons of Dhritarashtra?  By killing these terrorists we will only feel guilty.

Original:
1.37. Therefore, we should not kill the sons of Dhritarashtra,
our relatives; for how can we be happy by killing our own people, O Madhava
(Krishna)?
Translated: ..1.37..O Madhava!  Therefore it is not proper for us to kill the sons of our kinsman Dhritarashtra, because how can we be happy by killing our own relatives.

Original:
1.38. Though they, with intelligence overpowered by greed, see
no evil in the destruction of families, and no sin in hostility to friends,
Translated: ..1.38..Although these people, corrupted by greed, do not see sin in the evil committed by them and in betrayal of friends.

Original:
1.39. Why should not we who clearly see evil in the destruction
of families, learn to turn away from this sin, O Janardana (Krishna)?
Translated: ..1.39..But, O Janardan!  Why should we, who know the harm caused by Kulakshaya, not think of abstaining from this sin?

Original:
1.40. In the destruction of a family, the immemorial religious
rites of that family perish; on the destruction of spirituality, impiety,
indeed, overcomes the whole family.
Translated: 1.40 Sanatan Dharma gets destroyed due to the destruction of the clan. When Dharma is destroyed, Adharma (sin) suppresses the entire family.

Original:
1.41. By the prevalence of impiety, O Krishna, the women of
the family become corrupt; and , women being corrupted, O Varshenya (descendant
of Vrishni), there arises intermingling of castes.
Translated: ..1.41..O Krishna! Due to increase in sin the women of the family become polluted, and O Varshneya! When women become infected, hybrids arise.

Original:
1.42. Confusion of castes leads to hell the slayers of the family,
for their forefathers fall, deprived of the offerings of rice-ball and
water (libations).
Translated: ..1.42..That caste hybrid causes the murderers and the clan to go to hell. Deprived of the rituals of Pinda and Jaldaan, their ancestors also fall into hell.

Original:
1.43. By these evil deeds of the destroyers of the family, which
cause confusion of castes, the eternal religious rites of the caste and
the family are destroyed.
Translated: ..1.43.. Due to these varnasankar causative defects, the eternal family religion and caste religion are destroyed due to family-killing defects.

Original:
1.44. We have heard, O Janardana, that inevitable is the dwelling
for an unknown period in hell for those men in whose families the religious
practices have been destroyed.
Translated: ..1.44..O Janardan!  We have heard that those people whose family religion is destroyed, reside in hell indefinitely.

Original:
1.45. Alas! We are involved in a great sin, in that we are
prepared to kill our kinsmen, through greed for the pleasures of a kingdom.
Translated: ..1.45..Oh!  It is sad that we have decided to commit a huge sin, and are ready to destroy our family due to the greed of this kingdom.

Original:
1.46. If the sons of Dhritarashtra with weapons in hand should
slay me in battle, unresisting and unarmed, that would be better for me.
Translated: ..1.46..If these armed Kauravas kill me in battle, who is unarmed and does not fight back, it will still be beneficial for me.

Original:
1.47. Sanjaya said  Having thus spoken in the midst of the battlefield, Arjuna,
casting away his bow and arrow, sat down on the seat of the chariot with
his mind overwhelmed with sorrow.
Translated: ..1.47..Sanjay said – Arjuna, distraught with grief in the battlefield (Sankhye), saying thus, left the bow with the arrows and sat in the rear part of the chariot.

Original: 2.1 Sanjaya said  To him who was thus overcome with pity and who was despondent, with eyes full of tears and agitated, Madhusudana (the destroyer of Madhu) or Krishna spoke these words.
Translated: .2.1. Sanjaya said - Thus, overwhelmed with compassion and sadness, Madhusudan said this sentence to the tearful-eyed Arjuna.

Original: 2.2 The Blessed Lord said  Whence is this perilous strait come upon thee, this dejection which is unworthy of you, disgraceful, and which will close the gates of heaven upon you, O Arjuna?
Translated: .2.2. Shri Bhagwan said – O Arjun! Where did you get this fascination for this strange place?  Contrary to Arya conduct, it is neither a means of attaining heaven nor is it a source of fame.

Original: 2.3 Yield not to impotence, O Arjuna, son of Pritha. It does not befit thee. Cast off this mean weakness of the heart! Stand up, O scorcher of the foes!
Translated: ..2.3.. O Partha, don't be a coward. This is unbecoming of you, hey! Leave aside the petty weakness of the heart and stand up.

Original: 2.4 Arjuna said  How, O Madhusudana, shall I fight in battle with arrows against Bhishma and Drona, who are fit to be worshipped, O destroyer of enemies?
Translated: 2.4. Arjun said--O Madhusudan! How will I fight with arrows in the battlefield with Bhishma and Drona. O Arisudan, both of them are worthy of worship.

Original: 2.5 Better it is, indeed, in this world to accept alms than to slay the most noble teachers. But if I kill them, even in this world all my enjoyments of wealth and fulfilled desires will be stained with (their) blood.
Translated: ..2.5.. Taking alms in this world is more beneficial than killing these great teachers, because by killing the teachers, I will enjoy only the blood-stained pleasures of wealth and lust in this world.

Original: 2.6 I can hardly tell which will be better, that we should  coner them or that they should coner us. Even the sons of Dhritarashtra, after slaying whom we do not wish to live, stand facing us.
Translated: ..2.6.. We don't know what we should do. We don't even know whether we will win, or whether they will win over us, those whom we do not want to kill and live, those sons of Dhritarashtra are standing in front of us for the war.

Original: 2.7 My heart is overpowered by the taint of pity; my mind is confused as to duty. I ask Thee: Tell me decisively what is good for me. I am Thy disciple. Instruct me who has taken refuge in Thee.
Translated: ..2.7.. Overwhelmed by the taint of compassion and confused on the path of duty, I ask you to say with certainty whatever is best for me, because I am your disciple; Please give me advice when I take refuge in you.

Original: 2.8 I do not see that it would remove this sorrow that burns up my senses, even if I should attain prosperous and unrivalled dominion on earth or lordship over the gods.
Translated: ..2.8.. Despite having an uninterruptedly prosperous kingdom on earth and the ownership of the gods, I do not see a solution that can remove this grief that is drying up my senses.

Original: 2.9 Sanjaya said  Having spoken thus to Hrishikesha (the Lord of the senses), Arjuna (the coneror of sleep), the destroyer of foes, said to Krishna, "I will not fight" and became silent.
Translated: ..2.9.. Sanjay said - Thus, Gudakesh Parantap Arjun became silent after saying to Lord Hrishikesh, O Govind, "I will not fight."

Original: 2.10 To him who was despondent in the midst of the two armies, Krishna, as if smiling, O Bharata, spoke these words.
Translated: ..2.10.. O India (Dhritarashtra)! Lord Hrishikesh laughingly said these words to the grieving Arjun in between the two armies.

Original: 2.11 The Blessed Lord said  Thou hast grieved for those that should not be grieved for, yet thou speakest words of wisdom. The wise grieve neither for the living nor for the dead.
Translated: 2.11. Sri Bhagavan said - (Ashochyan) For those for whom it is not appropriate to mourn, you mourn and speak words to the wise, but wise men do not mourn for both the dead (gatasuna) and the living (agatasuna). Are..

Original: 2.12 Nor at any time indeed was I not, nor thou, nor these rulers of men, nor verily shall we ever cease to be hereafter.
Translated: 2.12. In reality, it is neither the case that I did not exist at any time or you were not there or these kings were not there nor is it the case that we all will not exist from this onwards.

Original: 2.13 Just as in this body the embodied (soul) passes into childhood, youth and old age, so also does it pass into another body; the firm man does not grieve thereat.
Translated: 2.13. Just as the physical soul in this body undergoes puberty, youth and old age, similarly it attains another body;  A patient person is not attracted by this.

Original: 2.14 The contacts of the senses with the objects, O son of Kunti, which cause heat and cold, pleasure and pain, have a beginning and an end; they are impermanent; endure them bravely, O Arjuna.
Translated: ..2.14.. O son of Kunti! There is a beginning and end to the combination of cold and heat and the senses and objects that give happiness and sorrow;  They are impermanent, therefore, O Bharat! You tolerate them.

Original: 2.15 That firm man whom, surely, these afflict not, O chief among men, to whom pleasure and pain are the same, is fit for attaining immortality.
Translated: 2.15. Oh best man! The patient person who remains equanimous in pain and pleasure and cannot be troubled by these, is entitled to immortality (salvation).

Original: 2.16 The unreal hath no being; there is non-being of the real; the truth about both has been seen by the knowers of the Truth (or the seers of the Essence).
Translated: ..2.16.. The unreal does not exist and the real never exists. In this way, the essence of both of these has been seen by wise men.

Original: 2.17 Know that to be indestructible, by Which all this is pervaded. None can cause the destruction of That, the Imperishable.
Translated: ..2.17.. You should know that thing as imperishable, which pervades this entire universe. No one is capable of destroying this element.

Original: 2.18 These bodies of the embodied Self, Which is eternal, indestructible and immeasurable, are said to have an end. Therefore fight, O Arjuna.
Translated: ..2.18.. All these bodies of this imperishable immeasurable eternal bodily soul are said to be perishable. That's why India! You fight.

Original: 2.19 He who takes the Self to be the slayer and he who thinks It is slain, neither of them ï1knowsï1. It slays not, nor is It slain.
Translated: ..2.19.. The one who considers this soul to be a killer and the one who considers it dead, both do not know, because this soul neither dies nor is killed.

Original: 2.20 It is not born, nor does It ever die; after having been, It again ceases not to be; unborn, eternal, changeless and ancient, It is not killed when the body is killed.
Translated: .2.20. This soul is neither born nor dies in any time nor is it going to exist once and then disappear again. This soul is unborn, eternal, eternal and ancient, it does not get destroyed even after the destruction of the body.

Original: 2.21 Whosoever knows It to be indestructible, eternal, unborn and inexhaustible, how can that man slay, O Arjuna, or cause to be slain?
Translated: 2.21. Hey Parth! The man who knows this soul to be indestructible, eternal and eternal, how will he cause whom to die and how will he kill whom?

Original: 2.22 Just as a man casts off worn-out clothes and puts on new ones, so also the embodied Self casts off worn-out bodies and enters others which are new.
Translated: .2.22. Just as a human being gives up old clothes and puts on new clothes, similarly the soul gives up old bodies and acquires new bodies.

Original: 2.23 Weapons cut It not, fire burns It not, water wets It not, wind dries It not.
Translated: ..2.23.. Weapons cannot cut this soul nor can fire burn it; Water cannot wet it and air cannot dry it.

Original: 2.24 This Self cannot be cut, burnt, wetted, nor dried up. It is eternal, all-pervading, stable, immovable and ancient.
Translated: ..2.24.. Because this soul is achhedya (cannot be cut), adhaya (cannot be burnt), akledya (cannot get wet) and ashoshya (cannot be dried);  It is eternal, omnipresent, stable, immovable and eternal.

Original: 2.25 This (Self) is said to be unmanifested, unthinkable and unchangeable. Therefore, knowing This to be such, thou shouldst not grieve.
Translated: ..2.25.. This soul is said to be unmanifested, unthinkable and unchangeable;  Therefore, it is not right for you to feel sad after knowing it like this.

Original: 2.26 But even if thou thinkest of It as being constantly born and constantly dying, even then, O mighty-armed, thou shouldst not grieve.
Translated: ..2.26.. And even if you consider the soul to be born daily and die daily, O mighty-armed one!  It is not appropriate for you to mourn like this.

Original: 2.27 For certain is death for the born, and certain is birth for the dead; therefore, over the inevitable thou shouldst not grieve.
Translated: ..2.27.. Death of one who is born is certain and birth of one who dies is certain;  Therefore, you should not mourn over what is permanent and inevitable.

Original: 2.28 Beings are unmanifested in their beginning, manifested in their middle state, O Arjuna, and unmanifested again in their end. What is there to grieve about?
Translated: ..2.28.. Hey India! All living beings remain in latent state before birth and after death and become manifest in between. Then what is there to worry or mourn about?

Original: 2.29 One sees This (the Self) as a wonder; another speaks of It as a wonder; another hears of It as a wonder; yet having heard, none understands It at all.
Translated: ..2.29.. Some look upon it as a matter of surprise;  Someone speaks of it as a matter of surprise;  And any other man hears it with surprise;  And then no one knows even after listening.

Original: 2.30 This, the Indweller in the body of everyone, is ever indestructible, O Arjuna; therefore, thou shouldst not grieve for any creature.
Translated: ..2.30.. Hey India! This physical soul is always present in everyone's body, hence it is not appropriate for you to mourn for all living beings.

Original: 2.31 Further, having regard to thy duty, shouldst not waver, for there is nothing higher for a Kshatriya than a righteous war.
Translated: ..2.31.. And it is not right for you to get disturbed even after seeing your own religion, because there is no other more beneficial duty for a Kshatriya than righteous war.

Original: 2.32 Happy are the Kshatriyas, O Arjuna! who are called upon to fight in such a battle that comes of itself as an open door to heaven.
Translated: ..2.32.. And O Parth! Only the fortunate Kshatriya people get to have this kind of war which is achieved automatically and which opens the door to heaven.

Original: 2.33 But if thou wilt not fight this righteous war, then having abandoned thine own duty and fame, thou shalt incur sin.
Translated: .2.33. And if you do not accept this crusade, then you will lose your self-righteousness and fame and commit sin.

Original: 2.34 People, too, will recount thy everlasting dishonour; and to one who has been honoured, dishonour is worse than death.
Translated: ..2.34.. And everyone will also keep talking about your long lasting bad reputation;  And for a respected man, dishonor is worse than death.

Original: 2.35 The great car-warriors will think that thou hast withdrawn from the battle through fear; and thou wilt be lightly held by them who have thought much of thee.
Translated: 2.35. And for those for whom you are very respectable, you will now become insignificant, those great people will consider you retired from the war out of fear.

Original: 2.36 Thy enemies also, cavilling at thy power, will speak many abusive words. What is more painful than this?
Translated: ..2.36.. Your enemies will speak many unspeakable words criticizing your strength, and what could be more painful than that?

Original: 2.37 Slain, thou wilt obtain heaven; victorious, thou wilt enjoy the earth; therefore, stand up, O son of Kunti, resolved to fight.
Translated: ..2.37.. By dying in battle you will attain heaven or by winning you will enjoy the earth;  Therefore, O Kaunteya! You stand up after deciding to fight.

Original: 2.38 Having made pleasure and pain, gain and loss, victory and defeat the same, engage thou in battle for the sake of battle; thus thou shalt not incur sin.
Translated: ..2.38.. Get ready for war by equating happiness-sorrow, profit-loss and victory-defeat;  In this way you will not commit sin.

Original: 2.39 This, which has been taught to thee, is wisdon concerning Sankhya. Now listen to wisdom concerning Yoga, endowed with which, O Arjuna, thou shalt cast off the bonds of action.
Translated: ..2.39.. Hey Parth! You were told the knowledge related to Sankhya and now listen to the knowledge related to this (karma) yoga, with the knowledge of which you will be able to destroy the bondage of karma.

Original: 2.40 In this there is no loss of effort, nor is there any harm (production of contrary results or transgression). Even a little of this knowledge (even a little practice of this Yoga) protects one from great fear.
Translated: ..2.40.. There is no defect in sequence or suffix in this. Even a little practice of this religion (yoga) protects from great fear.

Original: 2.41 Here, O joy of the Kurus, there is but a single one-pointed determination; many-branched and endless are the thoughts of the irresolute.
Translated: ..2.41.. Hey Kurunandan! There is only one decisive intellect in this (subject), the intellects (resolutions) of ignorant people are many different and infinite.

Original: 2.42 Flowery speech is uttered by the unwise, taking pleasure in the eulogising words of the Vedas, O Arjuna, saying, "There is nothing else."
Translated: ..2.42.. O Partha, the ignorant man who speaks these flowery words while enjoying the Vedas? There is nothing greater than this (heaven).

Original: 2.43 Full of desires, having heaven as their goal, (they utter speech which is directed to ends) leading to new births as the result of their works, and prescribe various methods abounding in specific actions, for the attainment of pleasure and power.
Translated: ..2.43.. Full of desires? People who believe that heaven is the best, tell about many activities that lead to enjoyment and wealth, which (in reality) give the results of karma in the form of birth.

Original: 2.44 For those who are attached to pleasure and power, whose minds are drawn away by such teaching, ï1thatï1 determinate reason is not formed which is steadily bent on meditation and Samadhi (superconscious state).
Translated: ..2.44..Those whose mind has been taken away, such people who are attached to pleasures and luxuries do not have determined intelligence in their conscience, that is, they are not capable of practicing meditation.

Original: 2.45 The Vedas deal with the three attributes (of Nature); be thou above these three attributes. O Arjuna, free yourself from the pairs of opposites, and ever remain in the ality of Sattva (goodness), freed from (the thought of) acisition and preservation, and be established in the Self.
Translated: ..2.45.. O Arjun, the subject of the Vedas is related to the three gunas (world), are you beyond the three gunas? Uncontested? Situated in eternal sattva (purity)? Become free from Yogakshema and self-sufficient.

Original: 2.46 To the Brahmana who has known the Self, all the Vedas are of as much use as is a reservoir of water in a place where there is a flood.
Translated: ..2.46.. How much use does a human being have in a small reservoir when there is abundant water from all sides? The self-enlightened Brahmin has the same purpose in all the Vedas.

Original: 2.47 Thy right is to work only, but never with its fruits; let not the fruits of action be thy motive, nor let thy attachment be to inaction.
Translated: ..2.47.. Do you have the right just to do the work? Never in fruit. You should not be dependent on the results of your actions and you should not be attached to non-actions either.

Original: 2.48 Perform action, O Arjuna, being steadfast in Yoga, abandoning attachment and balanced in success and failure. Evenness of mind is called Yoga.
Translated: ..2.48.. O Dhananjaya, abandoning attachment and being equanimous between success and failure, do your work while being situated in yoga. This equanimity is called yoga.

Original: 2.49 Far lower than the Yoga of wisdon is action, O Arjuna. Seek thou refuge in wisdom; wretched are they whose motive is the fruit.
Translated: ..2.49.. In comparison to this Buddhiyoga, are (fruitful) actions extremely inferior? Therefore, O Dhananjaya, take refuge in your wisdom. Those who desire fruits are misers.

Original: 2.50 Endowed with wisdom (evenness of mind), one casts off in this life both good and evil deeds; therefore, devote thyself to Yoga; Yoga is skill in action.
Translated: ..2.50.. Does a man with equanimity give up both virtuous and sinful actions here (in this life)? That's why you become full of yoga. Yoga is efficiency in actions.

Original: 2.51 The wise, possessed of knowledge, having abandoned the fruits of their actions, and being freed from the fetters of birth, go to the place which is beyond all evil.
Translated: ..2.51.. The wise people having the Yoga of Buddhi, renouncing the fruits of their actions and freed from the bondage of birth, attain the state of Anamaya i.e. innocent.

Original: 2.52 When thy intellect crosses beyond the mire of delusion, then thou shalt attain to indifference as to what has been heard and what has yet to be heard.
Translated: .2.52. When your intellect will get rid of the swamp of illusion (Kalil), then you will attain detachment from all those things (detachment)? Which is worth listening to and is heard.

Original: 2.53 When thy intellect, which is perplexed by the Veda text, which thou hast read, shall stand immovable and steady in the Self, then thou shalt attain Self-realisation.
Translated: ..2.53.. When your mind, which has been distracted by listening to various topics, becomes immovable and stable in the form of the Self, then you will attain (Paramarth) Yoga.

Original: 2.54 Arjuna said  What, O Krishna, is the description of him who has steady wisdom, and is merged in the superconscious state? How does one of steady wisdom speak, how does he sit, how does he walk?
Translated: ..2.54.. Arjun said - O Keshav, what are the characteristics of a man with a stable mind in samadhi? How does a man with a stable mind speak, how does he sit, how does he walk?

Original: 2.55 The Blessed Lord said  When a man completely casts off, O Arjuna, all the desires of the mind and is satisfied in the Self by the Self, then is he said to be one of steady wisdom.
Translated: ..2.55.. Shri Bhagwan said – O Partha? The time when a man gives up all the desires in his mind and remains content with the soul itself? At that time he is called Sthithaprajna.

Original: 2.56 He whose mind is not shaken by adversity, who does not hanker after pleasures, and is free from attachment, fear and anger, is called a sage of steady wisdom.
Translated: ..2.56.. Whose mind is not disturbed in sorrow? Whose desire is quenched in happiness? Whose heart is angry with? Have fear and anger been destroyed? That sage is called Sthitapragya.

Original: 2.57 He who is everywhere without attachment, on meeting with anything good or bad, who neither rejoices not hastes, his wisdom is fixed.
Translated: ..2.57.. The one who is devoid of extreme affection everywhere, neither becomes happy nor hateful after receiving those auspicious and inauspicious things? His wisdom is established (stable).

Original: 2.58 When, like the tortoise which withdraws on all sides its limbs, he withdraws his senses from the sense-objects, then his wisdom becomes steady.
Translated: ..2.58.. Just as a tortoise gathers its body parts, in the same way does this man surround his senses from all sides with the objects of the senses? Then his intellect becomes stable.

Original: 2.59 The objects of the senses turn away from the abstinent man leaving the longing (behind); but his longing also turns away on seeing the Supreme.
Translated: ..2.59.. Do the desires go away from the non-vegetarian physical person? But on seeing the supreme element, there is no attachment (for them), and this (man's) attachment also goes away.

Original: 2.60 The turbulent senses, O Arjuna, do violently carry away the mind of a wise man though he be striving (to control them).
Translated: ..2.60.. O Kaunteya, while striving for (restraint) these senses forcefully take away the mind of even an intelligent (Vipacchit) man.

Original: 2.61 Having restrained them all he should sit steadfast, intent on Me; his wisdom is steady whose senses are under control.
Translated: ..2.61.. By controlling all those senses, one becomes united and intelligent. The man whose senses are under control? His wisdom is respected.

Original: 2.62 When a man thinks of the objects, attachment for them arises; from attachment desire is born; from desire anger arises.
Translated: ..2.62.. Does a man who thinks about things become attached to them? From attachment comes desire and from desire comes anger.

Original: 2.63 From anger comes delusion; from delusion loss of memory; from loss of memory the destruction of discrimination; from the destruction of discrimination he perishes.
Translated: ..2.63.. Attachment arises from anger and confusion arises from attachment. When memory gets confused, intelligence gets destroyed and due to loss of intelligence, the person gets destroyed.

Original: 2.64 But the self-controlled man, moving among the objects with the senses under restraint and free from attraction and repulsion, attains to peace.
Translated: ..2.64.. A self-controlled (vidheyatma) man, free from attachment and aversion, attains happiness (prasad) by enjoying the objects through his controlled (atmavashyai) senses.

Original: 2.65 In that peace all pains are destroyed; for the intellect of the tranil-minded soon becomes steady.
Translated: ..2.65.. On receiving Prasad, all the sorrows end and the mind of a happy person soon becomes stable.

Original: 2.66 There is no knowledge of the Self to the unsteady and to the unsteady no meditation is possible, and to the unmeditative there can be no peace, and to the man who has no peace, how can there be happiness?
Translated: ..2.66.. (Without restraint) An Ayukt man does not have (self) knowledge and an Ayukt man does not have the capacity for emotion and meditation. An emotionless man does not get peace. A disturbed man does not find happiness.

Original: 2.67 For the mind, which follows in the wake of the wandering senses, carries away his discrimination, as the wind (carries away) a boat on the waters.
Translated: ..2.67.. Just as wind moves a boat in water, in the same way, which sense does the mind imitate in the midst of senses vying with objects? That one sense takes away his intelligence.

Original: 2.68 Therefore, O mighty-armed Arjuna, his knowledge is steady whose senses are completely restrained from sense-objects.
Translated: ..2.68.. Therefore? O mighty-armed man, whose senses are all under the control of the objects of the senses? His intellect is stable.

Original: 2.69 That which is night to all beings, in that the self-controlled man is awake; when all beings are awake, that is night for the Muni (sage) who sees.
Translated: ..2.69.. The night which is there for all the lovers? In that the restrained man is awake and where all the living beings are awake? It is night for the sage who sees (the elements).

Original: 2.70 He attains peace into whom all desires enter as waters enter the ocean which, filled from all sides, remains unmoved; but not the man who is full of desires.
Translated: ..2.70.. Just as the waters (of many rivers) get absorbed (without disturbing it) into the ocean, which is full of unshakable prestige on all sides? Similarly, the man for whom the objects of desires get absorbed in him (without causing any disorder)? That man attains peace? Not a man who desires pleasures.

Original: 2.71 That man attains peace who, abandoning all desires, moves about without longing, without the sense of mine and without egoism.
Translated: ..2.71.. The man who has given up all desires and is soulless? Wanders without any attachment or ego? He attains peace.

Original: 2.72 This is the Brahmic seat (eternal state), O son of Pritha. Attaining to this, none is deluded. Being established therein, even at the end of life, one attains to oneness with Brahman.
Translated: ..2.72.. O Partha, this is a Brahmi situation. A man does not get fascinated after receiving this. By remaining steadfast in this faith even in the final moments, one attains Brahmanirvana (oneness with Brahma).

Original: 3.1 Arjuna said  If Thou thinkest that knowledge is superior to action, O Krishna, why then, O Kesava, dost Thou ask me to engage in this terrible action?
Translated: ..3.1.. O Janardan, if you believe that knowledge is superior to action, then O Keshav, why do you force me into this terrible action?

Original: 3.2 With this apparently perplexing speech, Thou confusest, as it were, my understanding; therefore tell me that one way for certain by which I may attain bliss.
Translated: ..3.2.. You fascinate my mind with this compound sentence, so please definitely tell me that one (path) by which I can attain the ultimate glory.

Original: 3.3 The Blessed Lord said  In this world there is a twofold path, as I said before, O sinless one; the path of knowledge of the Sankhyas and the path of action of the Yogins.
Translated: ..3.3.. Shri Bhagwan said, O sinless (Anagh) Arjun, in this verse, I have already mentioned two types of loyalty: that of the knowledgeable people (Sankhyaanam) through Gyan Yoga and that of the Yogis through Karma Yoga.

Original: 3.4 Not by non-performance of actions does man reach actionlessness; nor by mere renunciation does he attain to perfection.
Translated: ..3.4.. Man does not attain renunciation by not performing deeds, nor does he attain perfection (perfection) only by renunciation of deeds.

Original: 3.5 Verily none can ever remain for even a moment without performing action; for everyone is made to act helplessly indeed by the alities born of Nature.
Translated: ..3.5.. No man can ever remain without doing work even for a moment because all (men) who are possessed by the qualities arising from nature are made to do work.

Original: 3.6 He who, restraining the organs of action, sits thinking of the sense-objects in mind, he of deluded understanding is called a hypocrite.
Translated: ..3.6.. The foolish person who controls the physical senses and keeps remembering (contemplating) the pleasures of the senses in his mind is called a liar (arrogant).

Original: 3.7 But whosoever, controlling the senses by the mind, O Arjuna, engages himself in Karma Yoga with the organs of action, without attachment, he excels.
Translated: ..3.7.. But O Arjun, the man who controls the senses through his mind and is free from attachment and practices Karma Yoga through his senses, is the best.

Original: 3.8 Do thou perform (thy) bounden duty, for action is superior to inaction and even the maintenance of the body would not be possible for thee by inaction.
Translated: ..3.8.. You do your duty because action is better than non-action. Due to your inaction, even the subsistence of (your) body will not be accomplished.

Original: 3.9 The world is bound by actions other than those performed for the sake of sacrifice; do thou, therefore, O son of Kunti (Arjuna), perform action for that sake (for sacrifice alone), free from attachment.
Translated: ..3.9.. This man, engaged in any action other than the one performed for the Yagya, is bound by his actions, therefore, O Kaunteya, give up all attachment and perform the actions properly only for the sake of the Yagya.

Original: 3.10 The Creator, having in the beginning (of creation) created mankind together with sacrifice, said, "By this shall ye propagate; let this be the milch cow of your desires (the cow which yields all the desired objects)."
Translated: ..3.10.. Prajapati (Creator) created the people along with Yagya in the beginning (of creation) and said that through this Yagya, you get growth and this Yagya fulfills the desires desired for you (Ishtakamdhuk).

Original: 3.11 With this do ye nourish the gods and may those gods nourish you; thus nourishing one another, ye shall attain to the highest good.
Translated: ..3.11.. You people should progress the gods through this yajna and those gods should progress you. By making mutual progress in this way, you will attain ultimate glory.

Original: 3.12 The gods, nourished by the sacrifice, will give you the desired objects. So, he who enjoys the objects given by the gods without offering (in return) to them, is verily a thief.
Translated: ..3.12.. The gods nourished by the Yagya will provide you with the desired food. The man who enjoys the pleasures given by them without giving them to them is definitely a thief.

Original: 3.13 The righteous who eat the remnants of the sacrifice are freed from all sins; but those sinful ones who cook food (only) for their own sake verily eat sin.
Translated: ..3.13.. The noble men who eat the leftover food from the Yagya are freed from all sins, but those who cook only for themselves, eat only sins.

Original: 3.14 From food come forth beings; from rain food is produced; from sacrifice arises rain and sacrifice is born of action.
Translated: ..3.14.. All living beings are born from food. Food is born from plants. Parjanya originates from Yagya and Yagya originates from actions.

Original: 3.15 Know thou that action comes from Brahma and Brahma comes from the Imperishable. Therefore, the all-pervading (Brahma) ever rests in sacrifice.
Translated: ..3.15.. Karma originates from Brahmaji and Brahmaji is expressed through Akshar Tattva. That is why the omnipresent Brahma is always established in Yagya.

Original: 3.16 He who does not follow here the wheel thus set revolving, who is of sinful life, rejoicing in the senses, he lives in vain, O Arjuna.
Translated: ..3.16.. The man who does not follow the cycle thus initiated here, O Partha, that sinful man who indulges in the senses, lives his life in vain.

Original: 3.17 But for that man who rejoices only in the Self, who is satisfied with the Self and who is content in the Self alone, verily there is nothing to do.
Translated: ..3.17.. But the person who rejoices in the soul, is satisfied in the soul and is satisfied in the soul, there is no duty for him.

Original: 3.18 For him there is no interest whatever in what is done or what is not done; nor does he depend on any being for any object.
Translated: ..3.18.. In this world, that man has no concern with action and non-action, nor does he depend on mere existence for anything.

Original: 3.19 Therefore without attachment, do thou always perform action which should be done; for by performing action without attachment man reaches the Supreme.
Translated: ..3.19.. Therefore, you should always perform your duty properly without being attached;  Because, an unattached man attains God while doing work.

Original: 3.20 Janaka and others attained perfection verily by action only; even with a view to the protection of the masses thou shouldst perform action.
Translated: ..3.20.. Janakadi (knowledgeable people) also looking at the accumulation of people (people's protection) achieved through action itself;  You are capable of doing the work.

Original: 3.21 Whatsoever a great man does, that the other men also do; whatever he sets up as the standard, that the world (mankind) follows.
Translated: ..3.21.. Whatever a great man conducts, others also imitate him; Whatever man proves, people also follow him.

Original: 3.22 There is nothing in the three worlds, O Arjuna, that should be done by Me, nor is there anything unattained that should be attained; yet I engage Myself in action.
Translated: ..3.22.. Even though I do not have any duties in the worldly world and even the slightest thing worth attaining (Avapatvyam) is not unattainable, still I behave in action only.

Original: 3.23 For, should I not ever engage Myself in action, unwearied, men would in every way follow My path, O Arjuna.
Translated: .3.23. If I am careful (Atandritah) then perhaps I may not continue in action, O Partha! Men will follow my path in every way.

Original: 3.24 These worlds would perish if I did not perform action; I should be the author of confusion of castes and destruction of these beings.
Translated: ..3.24.. If I do not act, all these worlds will be destroyed; And I will be the creator of casteism and the destroyer of this people.

Original: 3.25 As the ignorant men act from attachment to action, O Bharata (Arjuna), so should the wise act without attachment, wishing the welfare of the world.
Translated: ..3.25.. Hey India! Just as ignorant people who are attached to work do their work, similarly a learned man should work without attachment and with the desire of public welfare.

Original: 3.26 Let no wise man unsettle the mind of ignorant people who are attached to action; he should engage them in all actions, himself fulfilling them with devotion.
Translated: ..3.26.. A knowledgeable person should not create confusion in the minds of ignorant people who are engrossed in their deeds. They themselves should conduct their deeds properly and make them do the same.

Original: 3.27 All actions are wrought in all cases by the alities of Nature only. He whose mind is deluded by egoism thinks, "I am the doer."
Translated: ..3.27.. All actions are performed by the modes of nature; the man, deluded by ego, believes, “I am the doer.”

Original: 3.28 But he who knows the Truth, O mighty-armed (Arjuna), about the divisions of the alities and (their) functions, knowing that the Gunas as senses move amidst the Gunas as the sense-objects, is not attached.
Translated: ..3.28.. But O mighty-armed one! A wise man, who knows the truth (element) of the division of Gunas and Karmas, does not get attached (in Karma), knowing that "Gunas interact with Gunas" (in Karmas).

Original: 3.29 Those deluded by the alities of Nature are attached to the functions of the alities. The man of perfect knowledge should not unsettle the foolish one who is of imperfect knowledge.
Translated: ..3.29.. Men who are fascinated by the qualities of nature are attached to qualities and actions; those dull-witted men with incomplete knowledge (Akritsnavidah) should not be disturbed by men with complete knowledge.

Original: 3.30 Renouncing all actions in Me, with the mind centred in the Self, free from hope and egoism, and from (mental) fever, do thou fight.
Translated: ..3.30.. By renouncing all actions in Me, devoid of hope and attachment, free from sorrow, fight the battle.

Original: 3.31 Those men who constantly practise this teaching of Mine with faith and without cavilling, they too are freed from actions.
Translated: ..3.31.. Those people who are devoid of flawed intellect (anasuyantah) and full of faith, who always follow this opinion (sermon) of mine ritually, they become free from the bondage of karma.

Original: 3.32 But those who carp at My teaching and do not practise it, deluded of all knowledge, and devoid of discrimination, know them to be doomed to destruction.
Translated: .3.32. But those foolish people with flawed views who do not follow this opinion of mine, you should consider that those people with minds deluded in all knowledge have been destroyed.

Original:
3.33 Even a wise man acts in accordance with his own nature; beings will follow Nature; what can 
restraint do?
Translated: .3.33. A wise man also tries according to his nature. All living beings follow their own nature, then what will control (of anyone) do to them.

Original: 3.34 Attachment and aversion for the objects of the senses abide in the senses; let none come under their sway; for, they are his foes.
Translated: ..3.34.. There are passions and aversions (in the mind) towards the object of the senses (i.e. every sense);  Man should not be under the control of both of them;  Because they are his (man's) enemies.

Original: 3.35 Better is one's own duty, though devoid of merit than the duty of another well discharged. Better is death in one's own duty; the duty of another is fraught with fear (is productive of danger).
Translated: ..3.35.. It is better to follow one's own religion without virtues than to follow another religion properly practiced;  Death in one's own religion is beneficial (but) death in other religion gives fear.

Original: 3.36 Arjuna said  But impelled by what does man commit sin, though against his wishes, O Varshneya (Krishna), constrained as it were, by force?
Translated: ..3.36.. Arjun said – O Varshneya! Then, by what inspiration does this man commit sin, despite his unwillingness as if he was forced to do so?

Original: 3.37 The Blessed Lord said  It is desire, it is anger both of the ality of Rajas, all-devouring, all-sinful; know this as the foe here (in this world).
Translated: ..3.37.. Shri Bhagavan said – This is the 'desire' arising in Rajoguna, this is anger; This great person (who has a big appetite) and a great sinner, consider him your enemy here (in this world).

Original: 3.38 As fire is enveloped by smoke, as a mirror by dust, and as an embryo by the amnion, so is this enveloped by that.
Translated: ..3.38.. Just as fire is covered by smoke and a mirror by dust and just as a fetus is covered by the uterus, so is this (knowledge) covered by that (work).

Original: 3.39 O Arjuna, wisdom is enveloped by this constant enemy of the wise in the form of desire, which is unappeasable as fire.
Translated: ..3.39.. Hey Konteya! Like fire which is difficult to satisfy, knowledge is covered by the form of lust, this eternal enemy of the wise.

Original: 3.40 The senses, the mind and the intellect are said to be its seat; through these it deludes the embodied by veiling his wisdom.
Translated: ..3.40.. The senses, mind and intellect are said to be its abodes;  This work fascinates the physical person by covering the knowledge through them.

Original: 3.41 Therefore, O best of the Bharatas (Arjuna), controlling the senses first, do thou kill this sinful thing, the destroyer of knowledge and realisation.
Translated: ..3.41.. Therefore, O Arjun! You first control your senses and destroy this evil destroyer of knowledge and science.

Original: 3.42 They say that the senses are superior (to the body); superior to the senses is the mind; superior to the mind is the intellect; one who is superior even to the intellect is He (the Self).
Translated: ..3.42.. Beyond (the body) are called the (superior) senses;  Beyond the senses is the mind and beyond the mind is the intellect, and that which is beyond the intellect is the soul.

Original: 3.43 Thus knowing Him Who is superior to the intellect and restraining the self by the Self, slay thou, O mighty-armed Arjuna, the enemy in the form of desire, hard to coner.
Translated: ..3.43.. In this way, knowing the (pure) soul beyond the intellect and controlling the soul (mind) through the soul (intellect), O mighty-armed one! You kill this formidable (Durasadam) enemy of Kamarupa.

Original: 4.1 The Blessed Lord said  I taught this imperishable Yoga to Vivasvan; he told it to Manu; Manu proclaimed it to Ikshvaku.
Translated: ..4.1.. Sri Bhagavan said --- I told (taught) this imperishable Yoga to Vivasvan (Sun God);  Vivasvan said to Manu;  Manu said to Ikshvaku.

Original: 4.2 This, handed down thus in regular succession, the royal sages knew. This Yoga, by long lapse of time, has been lost here, O Parantapa (burner of the foes).
Translated: ..4.2.. In this way, the royal sages came to know this yoga received through tradition, (but) O Parantap! That yoga got destroyed here (in this world) after a long time.

Original: 4.3 That same ancient Yoga has been today taught to thee by Me, for thou art My devotee and My friend; it is the supreme secret.
Translated: ..4.3.. I told (taught) this ancient yoga to you today because you are my devotee and friend. This is a great secret.

Original: 4.4 Arjuna said  Later on was Thy birth, and prior to it was the birth of Vivasvan (the Sun); how am I to understand that Thou taughtest this Yoga in the beginning?
Translated: ..4.4.. Arjun said - Your birth is after (after) and Vivasvan's birth is before (yours), therefore how should I know that you had said (this yoga) in the beginning (of creation)?

Original: 4.5 The Blessed Lord said  Many births of Mine have passed as well as of thine, O Arjuna; I know them all but thou knowest not, O Parantapa (scorcher of foes).
Translated: ..4.5.. Lord Shri said - Oh Arjun! You and I have had many births, (but) O Parantap! I know them all and you don't.

Original: 4.6 Though I am unborn, of imperishable nature, and though I am the Lord of all beings, yet, governing My own Nature, I am born by My own Maya.
Translated: ..4.6.. Although I am an unborn and imperishable form and am the God of all existence, (yet) by keeping my nature under my control (Adhishthaya), I take birth from my Maya.

Original: 4.7 Whenever there is decline of righteousness, O Arjuna, and rise of unrighteousness, then I manifest Myself.
Translated: ..4.7.. Hey India! Whenever there is loss of righteousness and increase of unrighteousness, I reveal Myself.

Original: 4.8 For the protection of the good, for the destruction of the wicked and for the establishment of righteousness, I am born in every age.
Translated: ..4.8.. For the protection of virtuous people, the destruction of evildoers, and the establishment of religion, I appear in every age.

Original: 4.9 He who thus know, in their true light, My divine birth and action, having abandoned the body, is not born again, he comes to Me, O Arjuna.
Translated: ..4.9.. Hey Arjun! My birth and actions are divine, thus the man who knows the principle does not take birth again after leaving the body;  Only I get it.

Original: 4.10 Freed from attachment, fear and anger, absorbed in Me, taking refuge in Me, purified by the fire of knowledge, many have attained to My Being.
Translated: ..4.10.. Many men who have taken refuge in me with a mind free from attachment, fear and anger, have attained my form, purified by penance in the form of knowledge.

Original: 4.11 In whatever way men approach Me even so do I reward them; My path do men tread in all ways, O Arjuna.
Translated: ..4.11.. Those who worship Me, I show my grace to them;  O Partha, all men follow my path in every way.

Original: 4.12 Those who long for success in action in this world sacrifice to the gods; because success is ickly attained by men through action.
Translated: ..4.12.. (Ordinary humans) here (in this world) worship the gods, desiring the fruits of their actions;  Because in the human world the fruits of one's actions are achieved soon.

Original: 4.13 The fourfold caste has been created by Me according to the differentiation of Guna and Karma; though I am the author thereof know Me as non-doer and immutable.
Translated: ..4.13.. Chaturvanya has been composed by me from the department of qualities and actions. Although I am its doer, yet you know me as non-doer and imperishable.

Original: 4.14 Actions do not taint Me, nor have I a desire for the fruit of actions. He who knows Me thus is not bound by actions.
Translated: ..4.14.. Karmas do not indulge me;  Nor am I interested in the fruits of my actions. In this way, one who knows me is also not bound by deeds.

Original: 4.15 Having known this, the ancient seekers after freedom also performed action; therefore do thou also perform action, as did the ancients in days of yore.
Translated: ..4.15.. Even the ancient men of the past have performed their actions with this knowledge;  Therefore, you too should always perform the same actions done by your ancestors.

Original: 4.16 What is action? What is inaction? As to this even the wise are confused. Therefore I shall teach thee such action (the nature of action and inaction) by knowing which thou shalt be liberated from the evil (of Samsara, the wheel of birth and death).
Translated: ..4.16.. What is karma and what is non-action? Even intelligent people get confused in this matter. That's why I will tell you karma, (that is, I will explain the nature of action and non-action) knowing which you will be free from inauspicious (worldly bondage).

Original:
4.17 For verily (the true nature) of action (enjoined by the scriptures) should be known, also (that) 
of forbidden (or unlawful) action, and of inaction; hard to understand is the nature (path) of action.
Translated: ..4.17.. One should know the nature of one's actions and one should also know the nature of one's vices; (Boddhavyam) and also the nature of non-action should be known (because) the speed of action is deep.

Original: 4.18 He who seeth inaction in action and action in inaction, he is wise among men; he is a Yogi and performer of all actions.
Translated: ..4.18.. The man who sees inaction in action and action in inaction, he is wise among men, he is a yogi who performs complete actions.

Original: 4.19 He whose undertakings are all devoid of desires and (selfish) purposes and whose actions have been burnt by the fire of knowledge,  him the wise call a sage.
Translated: ..4.19.. A person whose actions are free from desire and determination, whose actions are burnt by the fire of knowledge, is called a knowledgeable scholar.

Original: 4.20 Having abandoned attachment to the fruits of the action, ever content, depending on nothing, he does not do anything though engaged in activity.
Translated: ..4.20.. The man who, having given up the desire for action, is eternally satisfied and devoid of all shelter, does nothing (actually) even though he is engaged in action.

Original: 4.21 Without hope and with the mind and the self controlled, having abandoned all covetousness, doing mere bodily action, he incurs no sin.
Translated: ..4.21.. One who is free from hope and who has controlled the mind and soul (body), who has renounced all attachments, such a person does not commit sin even while performing physical activities.

Original: 4.22 Content with what comes to him without effort, free from the pairs of opposites and envy, even-minded in success and failure, though acting, he is not bound.
Translated: ..4.22.. A man who is content with whatever he gets as per his own will, free from conflicts and desires, and equanimous between success and failure, does not get bound even by doing work.

Original: 4.23 To one who is devoid of attchment, who is liberated, whose mind is established in knowledge, who works for the sake of sacrifice (for the sake of God), the whole action is dissolved.
Translated: ..4.23.. All the deeds of a person who is free from attachment and free, whose mind is situated in knowledge, who conducts the yagya are absorbed.

Original: 4.24 Brahman is the oblation; Brahman is the melted butter (ghee); by Brahman is the oblation poured into the fire of Brahman; Brahman verily shall be reached by him who always sees Brahman in action.
Translated: ..4.24.. Arpan (i.e. the means of offering, Shruva) is Brahma and Havi (Shakalya or liquid capable of being offered as Havan) is also Brahma;  The havan performed by the doer in the form of Brahma in the fire of Brahma is also Brahma. In this way, the destination of the person who is in samadhi in the form of Brahma is also Brahma.

Original: 4.25 Some Yogies perform sacrifice to the gods alone; while others (who have realised the Self) offer the self as sacrifice by the Self in the fire of Brahman alone.
Translated: ..4.25.. Some yogis only perform Yagya in the form of worship of Gods; And others (knowledgeable people) perform Yagya through Yagya in the fire of Brahma.

Original: 4.26 Some again offer the organ of hearing and other senses as sacrifice in the fire of restraint; others offer sound and other objects of the senses as sacrifice in the fire of the senses.
Translated: ..4.26.. Others (yogis) offer all the senses in the fire of restraint, and others (people) offer the objects of speech in the fire of the senses.

Original: 4.27 Others again sacrifice all the functions of the senses and those of the breath (vital energy or Prana) in the fire of the Yoga of self-restraint kindled by knowledge.
Translated: ..4.27.. Others (yogis) sacrifice the actions of all the senses and the soul in the fire of self-control and yoga illuminated by knowledge.

Original: 4.28 Others again offer wealth, austerity and Yoga as sacrifice, while the ascetics of self-restraint and rigid vows offer study of scriptures and knowledge as sacrifice.
Translated: ..4.28.. Some (seekers) are the ones who perform Dravya Yagya, Tapayagya and Yoga Yagya;  And others are the yogis who observe difficult fasts, do self-study and perform knowledge yagya.

Original: 4.29 Others offer as sacrifice the outgoing breath in the incoming, and the incoming in the outgoing, restraining the course of the outgoing and the incoming breaths, solely absorbed in the restraint of the breath.
Translated: ..4.29.. Others (yogis) sacrifice Pranavayu in Apanavayu, and sacrifice Apana in Prana. By stopping the movement of Prana and Apana, they consider it to be the same as Pranayama.

Original: 4.30 Others who regulate their diet offer life-breaths in life-breaths. All these are knowers of sacrifice, whose sins are destroyed by sacrifice.
Translated: ..4.30.. Others, those who eat regularly (meditational people) perform havan in their lives. All of them are the ones who know Yagya, whose sins have been destroyed by Yagya.

Original: 4.31 Those who eat the remnants of the sacrifice, which are like nectar, go to the eternal Brahman. This world is not for the man who does not perform sacrifice; how then can he have the other, O Arjuna?
Translated: ..4.31.. Oh best of Kurus! Those who enjoy the residual nectar of Yagya attain eternal Brahma. A man without Yagya does not even get this world, then how will he get the next world?

Original: 4.32 Thus, manifold sacrifices are spread out before Brahman (literally) at the mouth or face of Brahman). Know them all as born of action and thus knowing, thou shalt be liberated.
Translated: ..4.32.. Many types of such yagyas are spread in the mouth of Brahma i.e. the Vedas i.e. they are described. Know all of them to be born out of karma;  Knowing this way you will become free.

Original: Swami Sivananda did not comment on this sloka
Translated: ..4.33.. Hey Parantap! The yagya of knowledge is better than the yagya performed with liquids. Hey Parth! All actions end in knowledge, that is, knowledge is their culmination.

Original: 4.34 Know That by long prostration, by estion and by service; the wise who have realised the Truth will instruct thee in (that) knowledge.
Translated: ..4.34.. Know that (knowledge) by (going near the Guru), prostrating, asking questions and doing service;  These philosophical wise men will preach knowledge to you.

Original: 4.35 Knowing ï1thatï1 thou shalt not, O Arjuna, again get deluded like this; and by that thou shalt see all beings in thy Self and also in Me.
Translated: ..4.35.. Knowing this you will never again be tempted like this, and O Pandava! Through which you will see the ghost in your self and also in me.

Original: 4.36 Even if thou art the most sinful of all sinners, yet thou shalt verily cross all sins by the raft of knowledge.
Translated: ..4.36.. Even if you are the one who commits more sins than all the other sinners, then by the boat of knowledge, you will definitely get rid of all the sins.

Original: 4.37 As the blazing fire reduces fuel to ashes, O Arjuna, so does the fire of knowledge reduce all actions to ashes.
Translated: ..4.37.. Just as a burning fire consumes fuel, so too, O Arjun! The fire of knowledge burns all the deeds to ashes.

Original: 4.38 Verily, there is no purifier in this world like knowledge. He who is perfected in Yoga finds it in the Self in time.
Translated: ..4.38.. There is, undoubtedly, nothing in this world as purifying as knowledge. A man accomplished in Yoga himself attains it in the soul at the appropriate time.

Original: 4.39 The man who is full of faith, who is devoted to it, and who has subdued the senses obtains (this) knowledge; and having obtained the knowledge he attains at once to the supreme peace.
Translated: ..4.39.. A man who is faithful, ready and alert attains knowledge. After attaining knowledge he soon attains ultimate peace.

Original: 4.40 The ignorant the faithless, the doubting self goes to destruction; there is neither this world nor the other, nor happiness for the doubting.
Translated: ..4.40.. The ignorant, faithless and doubtful man gets destroyed, (among them too) for the doubtful man there is neither this world, nor the next world, nor happiness.

Original: 4.41 He who has renounced actions by Yoga, whose doubts are rent asunder by knowledge, and who is self-possessed  actions do not bind him, O Arjuna.
Translated: ..4.41.. To the self-realized man who has renounced actions through Yoga, whose doubts have been destroyed through knowledge, O Dhananjay! Karmas do not bind.

Original: 4.42 Therefore with the sword of the knowledge (of the Self) cut asunder the doubt of the self born of ignorance, residing in thy heart, and take refuge in Yoga. Arise, O Arjuna.
Translated: ..4.42.. Therefore, by cutting the self-doubt arising from ignorance in your heart with the sword of knowledge, O Bharat! Stand up with the help of yoga.

Original: 5.1 Arjuna said  Renunciation of actions, O Krishna, Thou praisest, and again Yoga. Tell me conclusively that which is the better of the two.
Translated: ..5.1.. Arjun said - Krishna! You praise renunciation of actions and then yoga (conduct of action). Tell me which one is definitely better among these two.

Original: 5.2 The Blessed Lord said  Renunciation and the Yoga of action both lead to the highest bliss; but of the two, the Yoga of action is superior to the renunciation of action.
Translated: 5.2. Shri Bhagwan said - Renunciation of Karma and Karmayoga both are extremely beneficial;  But among both of them, Karmayoga is better than Sannyasa.

Original: 5.3 He should be known as a perpertual Sannyasi who neither hates nor desires; for, free from the pairs of opposites, O mighty-armed Arjuna, he is easily set free from bondage.
Translated: 5.3. The man who neither hates anyone nor desires anyone, is always considered a Sanyasi;  Because, O mighty-armed one! A man free from conflicts easily becomes free from bondage.

Original: 5.4 Children, not the wise, speak of knowledge and the Yoga of action or the performance of action as though they are distinct and different; he who is truly established in one obtains the fruits of both.
Translated: 5.4. Children, i.e. people of childlike mind consider Sankhya (Sanyas) and Yoga as different from each other;  A person properly established in either one attains the fruits of both.

Original: 5.5 That place which is reached by the Sankhyas or the Jnanis is reached by the Yogis (Karma Yogis). He sees, who sees knowledge and the performance of action (Karma Yoga) as one.
Translated: ..5.5.. The place which is attained by the wise, the Karma Yogis also reach the same place. Therefore the man who sees Sankhya and Yoga (in effect) as one and the same, sees the same (in reality).

Original: 5.6 But renunciation, O mighty-armed Arjuna, is hard to attain without Yoga; the Yoga-harmonised sage ickly goes to Brahman.
Translated: 5.6. But, O mighty-armed one! It is difficult to attain sannyasa without yoga;  A person who meditates with yoga soon attains God.

Original: 5.7 He who is devoted to the path of action, whose mind is ite pure, who has conered the self, who has subdued his senses and who realises his Self as the Self in all beings, though acting, is not tainted.
Translated: 5.7. The man who is engaged in Yoga, has a pure conscience, has controlled the body, has experienced unity with the senses and the soul situated in the physical world, does not get attached to them even while doing work.

Original: 5.8 "I do nothing at all," thus would the harmonised knower of Truth think  seeing, hearing, touching, smelling, eating, going, sleeping, breathing.
Translated: 5.8. A man having Tattva-Vitta will think (i.e. know) that “I do not do even the slightest action” while seeing, hearing, touching, smelling, eating, walking, sleeping, breathing.

Original: 5.9 Speaking, letting go, seizing, opening and closing the eyes  convinced that the senses move among the sense-objects.
Translated: 5.9. Speaking, giving up, receiving and opening and closing the eyes, (he) knows with certainty that all the senses are moving about their respective objects.

Original: 5.10 He who does actions, offering them to Brahman, and abandoning attachment, is not tainted by sin, just as a lotus-leaf is not tainted by water.
Translated: ..5.10.. The man who performs all his actions by offering them to Brahma and renouncing attachment, is not indulged in sins like a lotus leaf.

Original: 5.11 Yogis, having abandoned attachment, perform actions only by the body, mind, intellect, and even by the senses, for the purification of the self.
Translated: 5.11. Yogis work for self-purification (purification of mind) by renouncing attachments through body, mind, intellect and senses.

Original: 5.12 The united one (the well poised or the harmonised) having abandoned the fruit of action attains to the eternal peace: the non-united only (the unsteady or the unbalanced) impelled by desire, attached to the fruit, is bound.
Translated: 5.12. A wise man attains ultimate peace by renouncing the fruits of his actions;  And the uneducated man becomes attached to the fruit and becomes bound by desire.

Original: 5.13 Mentally renouncing all actions and self-controlled, the embodied one rests happily in the nine-gated city, neither acting nor causing others (body and senses) to act.
Translated: ..5.13.. Having renounced all actions from the mind, a man of self-control neither does nor gets any action done, while living happily in the city of the body with Navdwar.

Original: 5.14 Neither agency nor actions does the Lord create for the world, nor union with the fruits of actions. But it is Nature that acts.
Translated: ..5.14.. For the common people, the Lord (God) does not create any combination of actions, nor actions, nor results of actions. But nature does (everything).

Original: 5.15 The Lord takes neither the demerit nor even the merit of any; knowledge is enveloped by ignorance, thery beings are deluded.
Translated: 5.15. Vibhu Parmatma neither accepts anyone's sinful deeds nor virtuous deeds;  (But) knowledge is covered by ignorance, and all living beings are deluded by it.

Original: 5.16 But to those whose ignorance is destroyed by the knowledge of the Self, like the sun, knowledge reveals the Supreme (Brahman).
Translated: ..5.16.. But for those whose ignorance is destroyed by self-knowledge, that knowledge, like the sun, illuminates God.

Original: 5.17 Their intellect absorbed in That, their self being That, established in That, with That for their supreme goal, they go whence there is no return, their sins dispelled by knowledge.
Translated: ..5.17.. Those whose intelligence is situated in Him (God), whose mind is transformed, who have faith in Him, whose ultimate goal is He (Brahm), through knowledge the sinless persons attain non-rebirth, i.e. they are not reborn. .

Original: 5.18 Sages look with an eal eye on a Brahmana endowed with learning and humility, on a cow, on an elephant, and even on a dog and an outcaste.
Translated: ..5.18.. (Such are those) who see the same principle in the learned Brahmins endowed with knowledge and modesty, and also in the cows, elephants, dogs and Chandalas.

Original: 5.19 Even here (in this world) birth (everything) is overcome by those whose minds rest in eality; Brahman is spotless indeed and eal; therefore they are established in Brahman.
Translated: ..5.19.. Those whose mind is situated in equanimity, this chapter is conquered by them; Because Brahma is innocent and equal, hence they are situated in Brahma only.

Original: 5.20 Resting in Brahman, with steady intellect and undeluded, the knower of Brahman neither rejoiceth on obtaining what is pleasant nor grieveth on obtaining what is unpleasant.
Translated: ..5.20.. The man with stable intellect, who is free from illusion and is situated in Brahman, does not become happy after getting what he likes and does not get disturbed after getting what is unpleasant.

Original: 5.21 With the self unattached to external contacts he finds happiness in the Self; with the self engaged in    the meditation of Brahman he attains to the endless happiness.
Translated: 5.21. A man whose conscience is free from attachment to external things attains happiness in the soul itself;  A man whose mind is absorbed in the meditation of Brahma attains eternal happiness.

Original: 5.22 The enjoyments that are born of contacts are only generators of pain, for they have a beginning and an end, O Arjuna; the wise man does not rejoice in them.
Translated: ..5.22.. O Kaunteya, the pleasures that arise from the combination (of senses and objects) are the cause of sorrow, because they have a beginning and an end. An intelligent man does not enjoy them.

Original: 5.23 He who is able, while still here (in this world) to withstand, before the liberation from the body, the impulse born out of desire and anger  he is a Yogi, he is a happy man.
Translated: ..5.23.. The man who is capable of bearing the passions arising out of lust and anger even before leaving his body in this world, is a yogi and a happy man.

Original: 5.24 He who is happy within, who rejoices within, and who is illuminated within, that Yogi attains absolute freedom or Moksha, himself becoming Brahman.
Translated: ..5.24.. The person who has happiness in the inner soul, rest in the soul and knowledge in the soul, becomes a Yogi Brahma and attains Brahmanirvana i.e. ultimate salvation.

Original: 5.25 The sages (Rishis) obtain absolute freedom or Moksha  they whose sins have been destroyed, whose dualities (perception of dualities or experience of the pairs of opposites) are torn asunder, who are self-controlled, and intent on the welfare of all beings.
Translated: ..5.25.. Those sages attain salvation - those whose sins have been destroyed, who have no doubt, are self-controlled and are happy only in the welfare of the world.

Original: 5.26 Absolute freedom (or Brahmic bliss) exists on all sides for those self-controlled ascetics who are free from desire and anger, who have controlled their thoughts and who have realised the Self.
Translated: ..5.26.. Moksha (or Brahmananda) is present everywhere for the yetis who are free from lust and anger, have balanced mind and know the soul.

Original: 5.27 Shutting out (all) external contacts and fixing the gaze between the eyrow, ealising the outgoing and incoming breaths moving within the nostrils.
Translated: ..5.27.. Keeping external objects outside, placing the vision of the eyes in the middle of the eyebrows and equalizing the prana and apanavayu circulating in the nostrils.

Original: 5.28 With the senses, the mind and the intellect (ever) controlled, having liberation as his supreme goal, free from desire, fear and anger  the sage is verily liberated for ever.
Translated: ..5.28.. The man whose senses, mind and intellect are controlled, such a sage devoted to salvation, who is free from desire, fear and anger, is always free.

Original: 5.29 He who knows Me as the enjoyer of sacrifices and austerities, the great Lord of all the worlds and the friend of all beings, attains to peace.
Translated: ..5.29.. (Sadhak Devotee) One attains peace by knowing that I am the enjoyer of Yagya and penance, the great God of all the worlds and the friend of every living being.

Original: 6.1 The Blessed Lord said  He who performs his bounden duty without depending on the fruits of his actions  he is a Sannyasi and a Yogi; not he who is without fire and without action.
Translated: 6.1. Sri Bhagavan said - The man who performs his duties without being dependent on the results of his actions, is a Sanyasi and a Yogi, and not the one who has renounced only fire and activities.

Original: 6.2 Do thou, O Arjuna, know Yoga to be that which they call renunciation; no one verily becomes a Yogi who has not renounced thoughts.
Translated: 6.2. Hey Pandava! What is called (scripturally) renunciation, you should consider it as yoga; Because no man is a yogi who does not give up his resolutions.

Original: 6.3 For a sage who wishes to attain to Yoga, action is said to be the means; for the same sage who has attained to Yoga, inaction (iescence) is said to be the means.
