Translated: 6.3. For a sage who wishes to become established in Yoga, doing work is said to be the means and for the same person after becoming established in Yoga, Sham (peace, resolution and renunciation) is said to be the means.

Original: 6.4 When a man is not attached to the sense-objects or to actions, having renounced all thoughts, then he is said to have attained to Yoga.
Translated: ..6.4.. When (the seeker) is neither attached to the objects of the senses nor to the actions, then the sannyasi of all resolutions is called Yogarudha.

Original: 6.5 One should raise oneself by one's Self alone; let not one lower oneself; for the Self alone is the friend of oneself, and the Self alone is the enemy of oneself.
Translated: 6.5. Man must save himself by himself and not degrade himself; Because the soul itself is the soul's friend and the soul (man himself) is the soul's (own) enemy.

Original: 6.6 The Self is the friend of the self of him by whom the self has been conered by the Self, but to the unconered self, this Self stands in the position of an enemy, like an (external) foe.
Translated: ..6.6.. One who has conquered the soul (senses, etc.) through the soul, the soul is his friend, but for the Ajitendriya, the soul is like an enemy.

Original: 6.7 The Supreme Self of him who is self-controlled and peaceful is balanced in cold and heat, pleasure and pain, as also in honour and dishonour.
Translated: 6.7. For such a Jitatma Purusha who remains calm in cold-heat, happiness-sorrow and honor-insult, God is situated in the right way, that is, present in the form of self.

Original: 6.8 The Yogi who is satisfied with the knowledge and the wisdom (of the Self), who has conered the senses, and to whom a clod of earth, a piece of stone and gold are the same, is said to be harmonied (i.e., is said to have attained Nirvikalpa Samadhi).
Translated: 6.8. The Yogi who is satisfied with knowledge and science, who is free from vices (Kutastha) and has good senses, who is equal to mud, stone and pebbles, is called one who is united (with God).

Original: 6.9 He who is of the same mind to the good-hearted, friends, enemies, the indifferent, the neutral, the hateful, the relatives, the righteous and the unrighteous, excels.
Translated: 6.9. The man who is kind-hearted, friend, enemy, indifferent, mediator, hater and has equal feelings among his relatives, righteous souls and sinners, is the best.

Original: 6.10 Let the Yogi try constantly to keep the mind steady, remaining in solitude, alone, with the mind and the body controlled, and free from hope and covetousness.
Translated: 6.10. A yogi who has controlled his body and mind should remain alone in a secluded place, free from hopes and attachments, and should constantly stabilize his mind in the soul.

Original: 6.11 In a clean spot, having established a firm seat of his own, neither too high nor too low, made of a cloth, a skin and Kusa-grass, one over the other.
Translated: 6.11. In a pure land, you have kept kush, mrigashala and clothes on it, by making your seat stable neither too high nor too low….॥॥.

Original: 6.12 There, having made the mind one-pointed, with the actions of the mind and the senses controlled, let him, seated on the seat, practise Yoga for the purification of the self.
Translated: 6.12. There (sitting in the asana), concentrate the mind and practice yoga for self-purification by controlling the activities of the mind and senses.

Original: 6.13 Let him firmly hold his body, head and neck erect and still, gazing at the tip of his nose, without looking around.
Translated: 6.13. Keeping the body, head and neck equal and immovable, standing still and looking at the tip of one's nose and not looking at other directions.

Original: 6.14 Serene-minded, fearless, firm in the vow of a Brahmachari, having controlled the mind, thinking of Me and balanced in mind, let him sit, having Me as his supreme goal.
Translated: ..6.14.. (The seeker) should sit with a peaceful conscience, fearlessness and established in the vow of celibacy, controlling the mind and concentrating the mind on me, considering me as the ultimate goal.

Original: 6.15 Thus always keeping the mind balanced, the Yogi, with the mind controlled, attains to the peace abiding in Me, which culminates in liberation.
Translated: 6.15. In this way, the yogi with a controlled mind, always trying to stabilize the mind, attains peace in the form of ultimate nirvana (salvation) situated in me.

Original: 6.16 Verily Yoga is not possible for him who eats too much, nor for him who does not eat at all, nor for him who sleeps too much, nor for him who is (always) awake, O Arjuna.
Translated: ..6.16.. But, O Arjun! This yoga is not possible for a man who eats too much or does not eat at all and who sleeps a lot or is always awake.

Original:
6.17 Yoga becomes the destroyer of pain for him who is moderate in eating and recreation (such 
as walking, etc.), who is moderate in exertion in actions, who is moderate in sleep and wakefulness.
Translated: 6.17. Yoga is the destroyer of sorrows for that person who has proper diet and exercise, makes the right efforts and has limited sleep and wakefulness.

Original: 6.18 When the perfectly controlled mind rests in the Self only, free from longing for all the objects of desires, then it is said, 'He is united'.
Translated: ..6.18.. The period when the controlled mind becomes established in its own form and becomes free from all objects, at that time he is called a Yogi.

Original: 6.19 As a lamp placed in a windless spot does not flicker  to such is compared the Yogi of controlled mind, practising Yoga in the Self (or absorbed in the Yoga of the Self).
Translated: ..6.19.. Just as the flame of a lamp situated in a place of vibrationless air becomes free from desires, a similar analogy has been given to the mind of a yogi with yatchitta while practicing yoga.

Original: 6.20 When the mind, restrained by the practice of Yoga attains to quietude and when seeing the Self by the self, he is satisfied in his own Self.
Translated: ..6.20.. By practicing Yoga, the restrained mind becomes free and the state in which one becomes satisfied with oneself by looking at oneself.

Original: 6.21 When he (the Yogi) feels that Infinite Bliss which can be grasped by the (pure) intellect and which transcends the senses, and established wherein he never moves from the Reality.
Translated: ..6.21.. The state in which he experiences the happiness which is ultimate, supersensuous and buddhigraham and in the happiness in which he is situated, this meditative yogi never gets distracted from the element again.

Original: 6.22 Which, having obtained, he thinks there is no other gain superior to it; wherein estabished, he is not moved even by heavy sorrow.
Translated: 6.22. On attaining the benefit, he cannot accept any other benefit greater than that and when he is established in it, he is not disturbed even by great sorrow.

Original: 6.23 Let that be known by the name of Yoga, the severance from union with pain. This Yoga should be practised with determination and with an undesponding mind.
Translated: ..6.23.. There is separation from the combination of sorrow, that should be known by the name 'Yoga'. (The yoga which is the goal of Dhyanayoga) should be practiced with determination and without getting tired.

Original: 6.24 Abandoning without reserve all desires born of Sankalpa (thought and imagination) and completely restraining the whole group of the senses by the mind from all sides.
Translated: ..6.24.. By completely renouncing all the desires arising from the resolution, by properly controlling the senses from all sides through the mind.

Original: 6.25 Little by little let him attain to ietude by the intellect held firmly; having made the mind establish itself in the Self, let him not think of anything.
Translated: ..6.25.. Gradually (Yogi) may attain Uparamta (peace) through a patient intellect;  Keep the mind situated in the soul and then do not think about anything else.

Original: 6.26 From whatever cause the restless and unsteady mind wanders away, from that let him restrain it and bring it under the control of the Self alone.
Translated: ..6.26.. Control this fickle and unstable mind due to the reasons due to which it wanders (about subjects), bring it under the control of the soul itself, that is, make it stable in the soul.

Original: 6.27 Supreme Bliss verily comes to this Yogi whose mind is ite peaceful, whose passion is ieted, who has become Brahman and who is free from sin.
Translated: ..6.27.. One whose mind is peaceful, who is sinless (Akalmasham) and whose Rajoguna (Viksepa) has been calmed, such a Yogi who is in the form of Brahma, attains supreme happiness.

Original: 6.28 The Yogi, always engaging the mind thus (in the practice of Yoga), freed from sins, easily enjoys the Infinite Bliss of contact with Brahman (the Eternal).
Translated: ..6.28.. In this way, a sinless yogi who always practices the yoga of fixing the mind in the soul happily attains the ultimate happiness of contact with Brahma.

Original: 6.29 With the mind harmonised by Yoga he sees the Self abiding in all beings and all beings in the Self; he sees the same everywhere.
Translated: ..6.29.. A yogi who has a yogic heart and is omniscient sees the soul in all beings and only the ghosts in the soul.

Original: 6.30 He who sees Me everywhere and sees everything in Me, he never becomes separated from Me, nor do I become separated from him.
Translated: ..6.30.. For the man who sees Me everywhere and sees everyone in Me, I am not destroyed (that is, for him I do not go away) and he is not separated from Me.

Original: 6.31 He who, being established in unity, worships Me Who dwells in all beings, that Yogi abides in Me, whatever may be his mode of living.
Translated: ..6.31.. The man who worships me, situated in the feeling of oneness, who is present in all the beings, is a yogi who remains situated in me, acting (living) in every way.

Original: 6.32 He who, through the likeness of the Self, O Arjuna, sees eality everywhere, be it pleasure or pain, he is regarded as the highest Yogi.
Translated: ..6.32.. Hey Arjun! The man who sees everything as equal to himself, be it happiness or sorrow, is considered the ultimate yogi.

Original: 6.33 Arjuna said  This Yoga of eanimity taught by Thee, O Krishna, I do not see its steady continuance, because of the restlessness (of the mind).
Translated: ..6.33.. Arjun said – O Madhusudan! This Samya Yoga which you said, I do not see its permanent state because of the fickleness of the mind.

Original: 6.34 The mind verily is restless, turbulent, strong and unyielding, O Krishna: I deem it as difficult to control it as to control the wind.
Translated: ..6.34.. Because O Krishna! This mind is of fickle and restless nature and is strong and firm; I consider it to be as difficult as air to control it.

Original: 6.35 The Blessed Lord said  Undoubtedly, O mighty-armed Arjuna, the mind is difficult to control and restless; but by practice and by dispassion it may be restrained.
Translated: ..6.35.. Shri Bhagavan says – O beloved ones! Undoubtedly the mind is fickle and difficult to control; But, O son of Kunti! It can be controlled through practice and renunciation.

Original: 6.36 I think Yoga is hard to be attained by one of uncontrolled self, but the self-controlled and striving one can attain to it by the (proper) means.
Translated: ..6.36.. It is difficult for a man with an uncontrollable mind to attain Yoga, but it is possible for a man with an independent mind to attain Yoga through some means, this is my opinion.

Original: 6.37 Arjuna said  He who is unable to control himself though he has the faith, and whose mind wanders away from Yoga, what end does he, having failed to attain perfection in Yoga, mee,t O Krishna?
Translated: ..6.37.. Arjun said – O Krishna! What speed does such a man with incomplete efforts (Ayati) whose mind has become active through Yoga, achieve without attaining the success of Yoga?

Original: Swami Sivananda did not comment on this sloka
Translated: ..6.38.. Oh dear ones! Doesn't that man, deluded and without shelter in the path of Brahma, get corrupted from both sides like a scattered cloud and gets destroyed?

Original: 6.39 This doubt of mine, O Krishna, do Thou dispel completely; because it is not possible for any but Thee to dispel this doubt.
Translated: ..6.39.. Hey Krishna! You are the only one capable of completely resolving this doubt of mine; Because it is not possible to find anyone other than you who can pierce this doubt.

Original: 6.40 The Blessed Lord said  O Arjuna, neither in this world, nor in the next world is there destruction for him; none, verily, who does good, O My son, ever comes to grief.
Translated: ..6.40.. Lord Shri said - O Partha! That man is destroyed neither in this world nor in the next world; Oh father! No one who does any good deed gets into trouble.

Original: 6.41 Having attained to the worlds of the righteous and having dwelt there for everlasting years, he who fell from Yoga is rorn in a house of the pure and wealthy.
Translated: ..6.41.. A person who has lost his yoga after reaching the worlds of virtuous people, resides there for a long time and takes birth in the house of rich people with pure conduct.

Original: 6.42 Or he is born in a family of even the wise Yogis; verily a birth like this is very difficult to obtain in this world.
Translated: ..6.42.. Or, (the seeker) is born in a family of knowledgeable yogis, but this type of birth is undoubtedly very rare in this world.

Original: 6.43 Thee he comes in touch with the knowledge acired in his former body and strives more than before for perfection, O Arjuna.
Translated: ..6.43.. Hey Kurunandan! That person, being enriched with the knowledge acquired there in the previous body, makes even more efforts for the attainment of Yoga.

Original: 6.44 By that very former practice he is borne on in spite of himself. Even he who merely wishes to know Yoga goes beyond the Brahmic word.
Translated: ..6.44.. Because of that rehearsal he gets attracted towards Avash Hua Yoga. Only the one who is curious about Yoga transcends Shabda-Brahma.

Original: 6.45 But the Yogi who strives with assiduity, purified of sins and perfected gradually through many births, reaches the highest goal.
Translated: ..6.45.. But a Yogi who practices diligently and gets purified from all sins and becomes perfect through many births (Shanai: Shanai:) then attains the supreme state.

Original: 6.46 The Yogi is thought to be superior to the ascetics and even superior to men of knowledge (obtained through the study of scriptures); he is also superior to men of action; therefore be thou a Yogi, O Arjuna.
Translated: ..6.46.. Because a Yogi is superior to the ascetics and is considered superior to those who have knowledge (only of the scriptures) and is superior to those who do good deeds, therefore O Arjun, become a Yogi.

Original: 6.47 And among all the Yogis he who, full of faith and with his inner self merged in Me, worships Me is deemed by Me to be the most devout.
Translated: ..6.47.. Among all the yogis, any devout yogi who worships me with his inner soul united in me (i.e. with a sense of unity) is considered the most adept (best) by me.

Original: 7.1 The Blessed Lord said  O Arjuna, hear how you shall without doubt know Me fully, with the mind intent on Me, practising Yoga and taking refuge in Me.
Translated: ..7.1.. Hey Parth! Listen to me, with your mind unattached to me and by practicing yoga while being dependent on alcohol, how you will know me completely, without any doubt.

Original: 7.2 I shall declare to thee in full this knowledge combined with realisation, after knowing which nothing more here remains to be known.
Translated: 7.2. I will tell you this knowledge along with science in full form, knowing which nothing else is left worth knowing here (in the world).

Original: 7.3 Among thousands of men, one perchance strives for perfection; even among those successful strivers, only one perchance knows Me in essence.
Translated: 7.3. Among thousands of human beings, only one person strives for perfection and even among those striving seekers, only one person knows me from the essence.

Original: 7.4 Earth, water, fire, air, ether, mind, intellect and egoism  thus is My Nature divided eightfold.
Translated: 7.4. Earth, water, fire, air and sky and mind, intellect and ego - this is my nature divided into eight types.

Original: 7.5 This is the inferior Prakriti, O mighty-armed (Arjuna); know thou as different from it My higher Prakriti (Nature), the very life-element, by which this world is upheld.
Translated: 7.5. Oh great arms! This is placental nature. Apart from this, know my supernature in the form of a living being, by which this world is sustained.

Original: 7.6 Know that these two (Natures) are the womb of all beings. So I am the source and dissolution of the whole universe.
Translated: ..7.6.. Know that all beings originate from both these natures. (Therefore) I am the place of origin and destruction of the entire world.

Original: 7.7 There is nothing whatsoever higher than Me, O Arjuna. All this is strung on Me, as clusters of gems on a string.
Translated: ..7.7.. Hey Dhananjay! There is no other thing that is superior (beyond) me. This entire world is strung in me like beads in a thread.

Original: 7.8 I am the sapidity in water, O Arjuna; I am the light in the moon and the sun; I am the syllable Om in all the Vedas, sound in ether and virility in men.
Translated: ..7.8.. Hey Konteya! I am the essence in water, I am light in the moon and the sun, I am the energy in all the Vedas, I am the sound in the sky and I am the manliness in men.

Original: 7.9 I am the sweet fragrance in the earth and the brilliance in the fire, the life in all beings, and I am the austerity in ascetics.
Translated: 7.9. I am pure fragrance in the earth and bright in fire; I am life in all beings and I am penance in ascetics.

Original: 7.10 Know Me, O Arjuna, as the eternal seed of all beings; I am the intelligence of the intelligent; the splendour of the splendid objects am I.
Translated: 7.10. Hey Parth! Know me as the eternal seed (cause) of all beings; I am the wisdom of the wise and the brightness of the brilliant.

Original: 7.11 Of the strong, I am the strength devoid of desire and attachment, and in (all) beings, I am the desire unopposed to Dharma, O Arjuna.
Translated: ..7.11.. O great Bharat! I am the power of the strong, devoid of desires and attachments, and among all the beings, I am the work that is not against the religion, i.e. is favorable.

Original: 7.12 Whatever beings (and objects) that are pure, active and inert, know that they proceed from Me. They are in Me, yet I am not in them.
Translated: 7.12. Whatever sattvik (pure), rajasik (active) and tamasik (inanimate) emotions, know them all to have originated from me; Yet I am not in them, they are in me.

Original: 7.13 Deluded by these Natures (states or things) composed of the three alities of Nature all this world does not know Me as distinct from them and immutable.
Translated: ..7.13.. The whole world (people) is fascinated by these emotions (disorders) arising from the three gunas. Beyond these (gunas), the indivisible form does not know me.

Original: 7.14 Verily, this divine illusion of Mine, made up of the (three) alities (of Nature) is difficult to cross over; those who take refuge in Me alone, cross over this illusion.
Translated: 7.14. This divine triune Maya of mine is a great enemy. But those who take refuge in me transcend this illusion.

Original: 7.15 The evil-doers and the deluded who are the lowest of men do not seek Me; they whose knowledge is destroyed by illusion follow the ways of demons.
Translated: ..7.15.. Evildoers, fools and unrighteous people do not worship me; Those whose knowledge has been taken away by Maya, continue to hold demonic feelings.

Original: 7.16 Four kinds of virtuous men worship Me, O Arjuna, and they are the distressed, the seekr of knowledge, the seekr of wealth and the wise, O lord of the Bharatas.
Translated: ..7.16.. O great Arjun of Bharat! Four types of people worship me: those who do good deeds (Sukritin:) the artful, the inquisitive, the well-meaning and the knowledgeable.

Original: 7.17 Of them the wise, ever steadfast and devoted to the One, excels (is the best); for I am exceedingly dear to the wise and he is dear to Me.
Translated: ..7.17.. Among them too, the wise man with daily and undivided devotion is superior to me, because I am very dear to the wise man and he is very dear to me.

Original: 7.18 Noble indeed are all these; but I deem the wise man as My very Self; for, steadfast in mind he is established in Me alone as the supreme goal.
Translated: ..7.18.. (Although) all these are excellent, but it is my opinion that the knowledgeable person is my form, because that stable intellect of the knowledgeable person is well established in me in the form of the most excellent movement.

Original: 7.19 At the end of many births the wise man comes to Me, realising that all this is Vaasudeva (the innermost Self); such a great soul (Mahatma) is very hard to find.
Translated: ..7.19.. At the end of many births (in a particular birth) after attaining the knowledge that 'all this is Vasudev', I become a knowledgeable devotee; Such a Mahatma is very rare.

Original: 7.20 Those whose wisdom has been rent away by this or that desire, go to other gods, following this or that rite, led by their own nature.
Translated: ..7.20.. Those people whose knowledge has been taken away by the desire of special enjoyment, such people, inspired by their nature, worship other gods following specific rules.

Original: 7.21 Whatsoever form any devotee desires to worship with faith  that (same) faith of his I make firm and unflinching.
Translated: ..7.21.. Whichever form (of God) the devotee wants to worship with devotion, I establish the faith of that (devotee) towards that God only.

Original: 7.22 Endowed with that faith, he engages in the worship of that (form) and from it he obtains his desire, these being verily ordained by Me (alone).
Translated: ..7.22.. He (the devotee) worships that deity with that faith and without any doubt gets the desired pleasures prescribed by me.

Original: 7.23 Verily the reward (fruit) that accrues to those men of small intelligence is finite. The worshippers of the gods go to them, but My devotees come to Me.
Translated: ..7.23.. But the fruit of those people with less intelligence is perishable. The worshipers of the gods are attained by the gods and my devotees are attained by me only.

Original: 7.24 The foolish think of Me, the Unmanifest, as having manifestation, knowing not My higher, immutable and most excellent nature.
Translated: ..7.24.. Unintelligent people, without knowing My Anuttama (best) Avyaya Param Bhava, consider Me the Avyakta as the Manifest.

Original: 7.25 I am not manifest to all (as I am) veiled by the Yoga-Maya. This deluded world does not know Me, the unborn and imperishable.
Translated: ..7.25.. Covered with my Yogamaya, I am not visible to everyone. This deluded world (man) does not know me, the birthless, imperishable one.

Original: 7.26 I know, O Arjuna, the beings of the past, the present and the future, but no one knows Me.
Translated: ..7.26.. Hey Arjun! I know all that has happened in the past, is present in the present and will happen in the future, but no man knows me.

Original: 7.27 By the delusion of the pairs of opposites arising from desire and aversion, O Bharata, all beings are subject to delusion at birth, O Parantapa.
Translated: ..7.27.. Oh great India! Due to conflict and attachment arising from desire and hatred, one attains delusion (indiscretion) during the time of mere birth.

Original: 7.28 But those men of virtuous deeds whose sins have come to an end, and who are freed from the delusion of the pairs of opposites, worship Me, steadfast in their vows.
Translated: ..7.28.. But the virtuous people whose sins have been destroyed, those free from conflict and determination, worship me.

Original: 7.29 Those who strive for liberation from old age and death, taking refuge in Me, realise in full ï1thatï1 Brahman, the whole knowledge of the Self and all action.
Translated: ..7.29.. Those who surrender to me and try to get freedom from death and death, those people know that Brahma, complete spirituality and complete action.

Original: 7.30 Those who know Me with the Adhibhuta (pertaining to the elements), Adhidaiva (pertaining to the gods) and the Adhiyajna (pertaining to the sacrifice) know Me even at the time of death, steadfast in mind.
Translated: ..7.30.. Those men who know me along with Adhibhuta, Adhidaiva and Adhiyagya, those men with wise minds know me even in the last moments.

Original: Swami Sivananda did not comment on this sloka
Translated: 8.1. Arjun said - Oh great man! What is that Brahma? What is spirituality? And what is karma? And what is said by the name Adhibhuta? And what is said by the name Adhidaiva,

Original: 8.2 Who and how is Adhiyajna here in this body, O destroyer of Madhu (Krishna)? And how at the time of death, art Thou to be known by the self-controlled?
Translated: 8.2. And oh Madhusudan! Who is Adhiyagya here? And how is he in this body? And how are you known in the end times by moderate minded people,

Original: 8.3 The Blessed Lord said  Brahman is the Imperishable, the Supreme; Its essential nature is called Self-knowledge; the offering (to the gods) which causes existence and manifestation of beings and which also sustains them is called action.
Translated: 8.3. Sri Bhagavan said – The ultimate Akshar (imperishable) element is Brahma; Nature (one's own form) is called spirituality; The Visarga (sacrifice, motive force) that generates the emotions of the ghosts is known as Karma.

Original: 8.4 Adhibhuta (knowledge of the elements) pertains to My perishable Nature and the Purusha or the Soul is the Adhidaiva; I alone am the Adhiyajna here in this body, O best among the embodied (men).
Translated: ..8.4.. O Arjun, the best among bodily beings! The mortal thing (Panchamahabhoota) is Adhibhuta and Purusha Adhidaiva; I am the master in this body.

Original: 8.5 And whosoever, leaving the body, goes forth remembering Me alone, at the time of death, he attains My Being: there is no doubt about this.
Translated: ..8.5.. And whoever leaves his body remembering Me in his last moments attains My form, there is no doubt in this.

Original: 8.6 Whosoever at the end leaves the body, thinking of any being, to that being only does he go, O son of Kunti (Arjuna), because of his constant thought of that being.
Translated: 8.6. Hey Konteya! Whatever feeling (this living being) remembers when he leaves his body at the last moment, he always attains the same feeling as a result of thinking about that feeling.

Original: 8.7 Therefore at all times remember Me only and fight. With mind and intellect fixed (or absorbed) in Me, thou shalt doubtessly come to Me alone.
Translated: 8.7. Therefore, remember me constantly in all times; And fight with your mind and intellect dedicated to me, you will undoubtedly attain me.

Original: 8.8 With the mind not moving towards any other thing, made steadfast by the method of habitual meditation, and constantly meditating, one goes to the Supreme Person, the Resplendent, O Arjuna.
Translated: ..8.8.. Hey Parth! One who constantly thinks with a mind that does not go anywhere else, with the practice of yoga, attains the supreme divine person.

Original: 8.9 Whosoever meditates on the Omniscient, the Ancient, the Ruler (of the whole world), minuter than an atom, the supporter of all, of inconceivable form, effulgent like the sun and beyond the darkness of ignorance.
Translated: ..8.9.. One who remembers the man who is omniscient, ancient (Puraan), controller of all, subtler than the subtle, material of all, unthinkable, form of light like the sun and (Avidya) beyond darkness.

Original: 8.10 At the time of death, with unshaken mind, endowed with devotio, by the power of Yoga, fixing the whole life-breath in the middle of the two eyrows, he reaches that resplendent Supreme Person.
Translated: ..8.10.. He (the seeker) at the end of his life, with the power of yoga, properly establishes his Prana between the eyebrows and with a calm mind, filled with devotion, attains that supreme divine person.

Original: 8.11 That which is declared Imperishable by those who know the Vedas, that which the self-controlled (ascetics or Sannyasins) and passion-free enter, that desiring which celibacy is practised  that goal I will declare to thee in brief.
Translated: 8.11. Scholars who know the Vedas call it Akshar; In which diligent men without attachment enter; I will briefly tell you about the goal due to whose wish (the devotees) follow celibacy.

Original: 8.12 Having closed all the gates, confined the mind in the heart and fixed the life-breath in the head, engaged in the practice of concentration.
Translated: 8.12. By controlling all the doors (of the senses), stabilizing the mind in the heart and establishing the life force in the head, he became established in Yogadharana.

Original: 8.13 Uttering the one-syllabled Om  the Brahman  and remembering Me, he who departs, leaving the body, attains to the Supreme Goal.
Translated: 8.13. The person who leaves his body while reciting this one syllable 'Om', Brahma and remembering me, attains the supreme state.

Original: 8.14 I am easily attainable by that ever-steadfast Yogi who constantly and daily remembers Me (for a long time), not thinking of anything else (with a single mind or one-pointed mind), O Partha (Arjuna).
Translated: ..8.14.. Hey Parth! I am easily accessible to the daily yogi who remembers me with a single mind, that is, I am easily attained.

Original:
8.15 Having attained Me these great souls do not again take birth (here) which is the place of pain 
and is non-eternal: they have reached the highest perfection (liberation).
Translated: ..8.15.. The great souls who have attained supreme success, after attaining me, do not get rebirth in the homely form of eternal sorrow.

Original: 8.16 (All) the worlds including the world of Brahma are subject to return again, O Arjuna; but he who reaches Me, O son of Kunti, has no rirth.
Translated: ..8.16.. Hey Arjun! Everyone up to Brahma Loka is of reclusive nature. But, O Kaunteya! There is no rebirth after attaining me.

Original: 8.17 Those people who know the day of Brahma which is of a duration of a thousand Yugas (ages) and the night which is also of a thousand Yugas duration, they know day and night.
Translated: ..8.17.. Those who know the duration of one day of Lord Brahma which is of a thousand years and know the duration of a night of one thousand years, they are the men who know the day and night.

Original: 8.18 From the Unmanifested all the manifested (worlds) proceed at the coming of the 'day'; at the coming of the 'night' they dissolve verily into ï1thatï1 alone which is called the Unmanifested.
Translated: ..8.18.. When (Brahmaji's) day rises, from the unexpressed (this) manifest (charachar world) arises; And on the arrival of (Brahmaji's) night, he gets absorbed in the same unmanifested.

Original: 8.19 This same multitude of beings, being born again and again, is dissolved, helplessly, O Arjuna (into the Unmanifested) at the coming of the night and comes forth at the coming of the day.
Translated: ..8.19.. Hey Parth! It is this ghost community, which is born again and again and gets absorbed. Avash Hua (this ghost village) disappears with the arrival of night and manifests with the rise of day.

Original: 8.20 But verily there exists, higher than this Unmanifested, another unmanifested Eternal, which is not destroyed when all beings are destroyed.
Translated: ..8.20.. But beyond that unmanifested thing, the other eternal unmanifested feeling does not get destroyed even after the destruction of all the ghosts.

Original: 8.21 What is called the Unmanifested and the Imperishable, That they say is the highest goal. They who reach It do not return (to this Samsara). That is My highest abode (place or state).
Translated: ..8.21.. The latent letter which has been said is the ultimate goal (goal). The one which (the devotees) do not return back (to the world) after attaining it, is my supreme abode.

Original: 8.22 That highest Purusha, O Arjuna, is attainable by unswerving devotion to Him alone within Whom all beings dwell and by Whom all this is pervaded.
Translated: 8.22. Hey Parth! The Supreme Being, under whom all the beings are included and through whom this entire world is pervaded, is attainable only through exclusive devotion.

Original: 8.23 Now I will tell thee, O chief of Bharatas, the times departing at which the Yogis will return or not return.
Translated: ..8.23.. O Bharatashrestha! I will tell you the period (path) during which the yogis who have left their bodies attain non-repetition and (or) re-occurrence.

Original: 8.24 Fire, light daytime, the bright fortnight, the six months of the northern path of the sun (the northern solstice)  departing then (by these) men who know Brahman go to Brahman.
Translated: ..8.24.. Those Brahmavid devotees who go through the path of six months of Agni, Jyoti, Din, Shuklapaksha and Uttarayan after death, attain Brahma.

Original: 8.25 Attaining to the lunar light by smoke, night time, the dark fortnight also, the six months of the southern path of the sun (the southern solstice), the Yogi returns.
Translated: ..8.25.. The Yogi returns (to the world) after attaining the light of the moon through the six-monthly path of Dhoom, Night, Krishna Paksha and Dakshinayan.

Original: 8.26 The bright and the dark paths of the world are verily thought to be eternal; by the one (the bright path) a man goes not to return and by the other (the dark path) he returns.
Translated: 8.26. These two types of Shukla and Krishna paths of the world are considered eternal. Of these, through one (Shukla) (the seeker) one achieves non-repetition and through the other (Krishna) one achieves repetition.

Original: 8.27 Knowing these paths, O Arjuna, no Yogi is deluded; therefore at all times be steadfast in Yoga.
Translated: ..8.27.. O Partha, no yogi who knows these two paths (from the elements) becomes bewildered. Therefore, O Arjuna! May you all become yogyukt in time.

Original: 8.28 Whatever fruit of merit is declared (in the scriptures) to accrue from (the study of) the Vedas, (the performance of) sacrifices, (the practice of) austerities, and gifts  beyond all this goes the Yogi, having known this; and he attains to the Supreme Primeval (first or ancient) Abode.
Translated: ..8.28.. Knowing all this (the essence of both the paths), a yogi person violates all the virtuous results mentioned in the study of Vedas, yagya, penance and charity and attains the original (eternal), supreme place.

Original: 9.1 The Blessed Lord said  I shall now declare to thee who does not cavil, the greatest secret, the knowledge combined with experience (Self-realisation). Having known this thou shalt be free evil.
Translated: 9.1. Shri Bhagwan said - For you Anasuyu (without flawed vision), I will tell you this secret knowledge along with science, knowing which you will be free from inauspicious (worldly bondage).

Original: 9.2 This is the kingl science, the kingly secret, the supreme purifier, realisable by direct intuitional knowledge, according to righteousness, very easy to perform and imperishable.
Translated: 9.2. This knowledge is Rajvidya (king of knowledge) and Rajguhya (king of all secrets i.e. secrets) and is sacred, good, having direct knowledge and religious, and is easy and indispensable in doing.

Original: 9.3 Those who have no faith in this Dharma (knowledge of the Self), O Parantapa (Arjuna), return to the path of this world of death without attaining Me.
Translated: 9.3. Hey Parantap! In this religion, people without faith do not attain me but live (travel) in the world of death.

Original: 9.4 All this world is pervaded by Me in My unmanifest aspect; all beings exist in Me, but I do not dwell in them.
Translated: 9.4. This entire universe is pervaded by the unmanifested form of Me (God); The ghosts are present in me, but I am not present in them.

Original: 9.5 Nor do beings exist in Me (in reality); behold My divine Yoga, supporting all beings, but not dwelling in them, is My Self, the efficient cause of beings.
Translated: 9.5. And (in reality) the mere existence is not situated in me; Look at my divine yoga that my soul which holds the ghosts and which creates the ghosts is not present in those ghosts.

Original: 9.6 As the mighty wind, moving everywhere, rests always in the ether, even so, know thou that all beings rest in Me.
Translated: 9.6. Just as the great wind that travels everywhere is always present in the sky, similarly all the ghosts are present in me, know this.

Original: 9.7 All beings, O Arjuna, go into My Nature at the end of a Kalpa; I send them forth again at the beginning of (the next) Kalpa.
Translated: 9.7. Hey Konteya! (1) At the end of the Kalpa, all the ghosts attain my nature; And I create them again at the beginning of the (second) Kalpa.

Original: 9.8 Animating My Nature, I again and again send forth all this multitude of beings, helpless by the force of the Nature.
Translated: 9.8. By bringing nature under my control (i.e. by giving it consciousness), I again and again create this entire ghost community which has become dependent under the influence of nature.

Original: 9.9 These acts do not bind Me, O Arjuna, sitting like one indifferent, unattached to those acts.
Translated: ..9.9.. Hey Dhananjay! Those actions do not bind me (God), who is free from attachment and indifferent to those actions.

Original: 9.10 Under Me as supervisor, Nature produces the moving and the unmoving; because of this, O Arjuna, the world revolves.
Translated: ..9.10.. Hey Konteya! Because of me as the president (i.e. under my leadership) nature gives birth to the living world; This is why this world keeps rotating.

Original: 9.11 Fools disregard Me, clad in human form, not knowing My higher Being as the great Lord of (all) beings.
Translated: 9.11. Not knowing the ultimate meaning of Me, the great God of all beings, foolish people disrespect Me, the Supreme Soul, in human form.

Original: 9.12 Of vain hopes, of vain actions, of vain knowledge and senseless, they verily are possessed of the deceitful nature of demons and undivine beings.
Translated: 9.12. Ignorant people with useless hopes, useless actions and useless knowledge retain the bewitching nature of demons and demons.

Original: 9.13 But the great souls, O Arjuna, partaking of My divine nature, worship Me with a single mind (with the mind devoted to nothing else), knowing Me as the imperishable source of beings.
Translated: ..9.13.. Hey Parth! But great men dependent on the divine nature, considering me to be the original cause and eternal form of all existences, worship me with a single mind.

Original: 9.14 Always glorifying Me, striving,firm in vows, prostrating themselves before Me, they worship Me with devotion always steadfast.
Translated: ..9.14.. Constantly chanting My Kirtan, hard-working, steadfast men, saluting Me, worshiping Me with daily devotion.

Original: 9.15 Others also sacrificing with the wisdom-sacrifice worship Me, the All-faced, as one, as distinct, and as manifold.
Translated: 9.15. Some worship me with a sense of unity while worshiping me through the Gyan Yagya, some worship me with a separate feeling, some worship me as a vast form (Vishwato Mukham) in many ways.

Original: 9.16 I am the Kratu; I am the Yajna; I am the offering (food) to the manes; I am the medicinal herbs and all the plants; I am the Mantra; I am also the Ghee or the melted butter; I am the fire; I am the oblation.
Translated: ..9.16.. I am Rikratu; I am Yagya; I am Swadha and medicine, I am Mantra, I am Ghee, I am Fire and I am Hutan i.e. Havan Karma.

Original:
9.17 I am the father of this world, the mother, the dispenser of the fruits of actions and the 
grandfather; the (one) thing to be known, the purifier, the sacred monosyllable (Om), and also the Rik-, the Sama-and the Yajur-Vedas.
Translated: 9.17. I am the father, mother, dhata (bearer) and grandfather of this world, I am the Vedya (thing worth knowing), I am the sacred, Omkar, Rigveda, Samveda and Yajurveda.

Original: 9.18 I am the goal, the supporter, the Lord, the witness, the abode, the shelter, the friend, the origin, the dissolution, the foundation, the treasure-house and the seed which is imperishable.
Translated: ..9.18.. I am the speed (goal), the sustainer, the Lord (master), the witness, the abode, the refuge and friend and also the origin, the form of destruction and the place (base), the foundation and the eternal cause.

Original: 9.19 (As the sun) I give heat; I withhold and send forth the rain; I am immortality and also death, existence and non-existence, O Arjuna.
Translated: ..9.19.. Hey Arjun! I alone (in the form of the Sun) get hot; I control and emit rain. I am nectar and death and true and false.

Original: 9.20 The knowers of the three Vedas, the drinkers of Soma, purified of all sins, worshipping Me by sacrifices, pray for the way to heaven; they reach the holy world of the Lord of the gods and enjoy in heavn the divine pleasures of the gods.
Translated: ..9.20.. Those who know the three Vedas (those who perform fruitful actions based on Vedas), those who drink soma and those who are purified from sins, want to attain heaven by worshiping me through yagyas; Those men attain Indraloka as a result of their good deeds and enjoy the pleasures of the divine gods in heaven.

Original: 9.21 They, having enjoyed the vast heaven, enter the world of mortals when their merit is exhausted; thus abiding by the injunctions of the ï1threeï1 (Vedas) and desiring (objects of) desires, they attain to the state of going and returning.
Translated: ..9.21.. After enjoying that vast heaven, when their virtues wane, they reach the world of death. In this way, the people who take refuge in the work as stated in the three Vedas and desire the pleasures, attain the state of transportation (Gatagata).

Original: 9.22 For those men who worship Me alone, thinking of no other, for those ever-united, I secure what is not already possessed and preserve what they already possess.
Translated: ..9.22.. I take care of the welfare of those devotees who worship me by thinking of me with utmost devotion.

Original: 9.23 Even those devotees who, endowed with faith, worship other gods, worship Me alone, O Arjuna, b the wrong method.
Translated: ..9.23.. Hey Konteya! The devotees with faith who worship other gods, also worship me unrighteously.

Original: 9.24 (For) I alone am the enjoyer and also the Lord of all sacrifices; but they do not know Me in essence (in reality), and hence they fall (return to this mortal world).
Translated: ..9.24.. Because I am the enjoyer and master of all yagyas, but they do not know Me in essence, that is why they fall, that is, they attain the world.

Original: 9.25 The worshippers of the gods go to them; to the manes go the ancestor-worshippers; to the deities who preside over the elements go their worshippers; but My devotees come to Me.
Translated: ..9.25.. The worshipers of the Gods go to the Gods, the worshipers of the ancestors go to the ancestors, the worshipers of the ghosts go to the ghosts and the devotees who worship me go to me only.

Original: 9.26 Whoever offers Me with devotion a leaf, a flower, a fruit or a little water  that, so offered devotedly by the pure-minded, I accept.
Translated: ..9.26.. Any devotee who offers leaves, flowers, fruits, water etc. for me with devotion, I enjoy that devotionally offered (Patra Pushpadi) of that pure minded devotee, that is, I accept it.

Original: 9.27 Whatever thou doest, whatever thou eatest, whatever thou offerest in sacrifice, whatever thou givest, whatever thou practisest as austerity, O Arjuna, do it as an offering unto Me.
Translated: ..9.27.. Hey Konteya! Whatever work you do, whatever you eat, whatever havan you perform, whatever you donate and whatever penance you perform, you should offer it all to me.

Original: 9.28 Thus shalt thou be freed from the bonds of actions yielding good and evil fruits; with the mind steadfast in the Yoga of renunciation, and liberated, thou shalt come unto Me.
Translated: ..9.28.. In this way you will be freed from the bondages of karma as a result of good and bad luck; And if you become wise through Sannyasa Yoga, you will become free and reach me.

Original: 9.29 The same am I to all beings; to Me there is none hateful or dear; but those who worship Me with devotion are in Me and I am also in them.
Translated: ..9.29.. I am equal to all beings; Neither is anyone unpleasant nor dear to me; But those who worship me with devotion are in me and I am also in them.

Original: 9.30 Even if the most sinful worships Me, with devotion to none else, he too should indeed by regarded as righteous for he has rightly resolved.
Translated: ..9.30.. If even a very evil person becomes my devotee and worships me with full dedication, he deserves to be considered a saint because he has true faith.

Original: 9.31 Soon he becomes righteous and attains to eternal peace; O Arjuna, proclaim thou for certain that My devotee never perishes.
Translated: ..9.31.. O Kaunteya, he soon becomes a virtuous soul and attains eternal peace. You must know the truth that my devotee never gets destroyed.

Original: 9.32 For, taking refuge in Me, they also who, O Arjuna, may be of a sinful birth  women, Vaisyas as well as Sudras  attain the Supreme Goal.
Translated: ..9.32.. Hey Parth! Women, Vaishyas and Shudras, whosoever are sinful, they also attain the supreme state by depending on me (surrendering to me).

Original: 9.33 How much more (easily) then the hold Brahmins and devoted royal saints (attain the goal); having come to this impermanent and unhappy world, do thou worship Me.
Translated: ..9.33.. Then what is there to say that virtuous Brahmins and Rajarshi devotees (achieve the supreme state); (Therefore) after attaining this impermanent and pleasureless world, (now) you worship me with devotion.

Original: 9.34 Fix thy mind on Me; by devoted to Me; sacrifice unto Me; bow down to Me; having thus united thy whole self to Me, taking Me as the supreme goal, thou shalt come unto Me.
Translated: ..9.34.. (You) be of steadfast mind in Me; Become my devotee and my worshipper; Greet me; In this way, by becoming self-oriented (i.e., whose ultimate goal is I), by uniting your soul with me, you will attain me.

Original: 10.1 The Blessed Lord said  Again, O mighty-armed Arjuna, listen to my supreme word which I will declare to thee who who art beloved, for thy welfare.
Translated: 10.1. Shri Bhagwan said – O mighty-armed one! Again, listen to my supreme words, which I will say with a desire to benefit the one who loves you very much.

Original: 10.2 Neither the hosts of the gods nor the great sages know My origin; for in every way I am the source of all the gods and the great sages.
Translated: 10.2. Neither the gods nor the great sages know my origin (Prabhav); Because I am the original cause of all the gods and Maharishis also.

Original: 10.3 He who knows Me as unborn and beginningless, as the great Lord of the worlds, he, among mortals, is undeluded and he is liberated from all sins.
Translated: 10.3. One who knows Me as the unborn, the eternal and the great Lord of the worlds, such a person free from attachment (knowledgeable) among mortal beings becomes free from all sins.

Original: 10.4 Intellect, wisdom, non-delusion, forgiveness, truth, self-restraint, calmness, happiness, pain, existence or birth, non-existence or death, fear and also fearlessness.
Translated: 10.4. Wisdom, knowledge, absence of attachment, forgiveness, truth, dam (sense control), sham (mind control), happiness, sorrow, birth and death, fear and fearlessness.

Original: 10.5 Non-injury, eanimity, contentment, austerity, beneficence, fame, ill-fame  (these) different kinds of alities of beings arise from Me alone.
Translated: 10.5. Non-violence, equality, contentment, penance, charity. The various feelings of such creatures as fame and infamy are manifested from me only.

Original: 10.6 The seven great sages, the ancient four and also the Manus, possessed of powers like Me (on account of their minds being fixed on Me), were born of (My) mind; from them are these creatures born in this world.
Translated: 10.6. The seven Maharishis, the four (Sankadis) of the past and the (fourteen) Manus, these have arisen from my resolution under my influence, whose subjects are in this world (world).

Original: 10.7 He who in truth knows these manifold manifestations of My Being and (this) Yoga-power of Mine becomes established in the unshakable Yoga; there is no doubt about it.
Translated: ..10.7.. The man who knows this My Vibhuti and Yoga from the essence, he becomes equipped with Avikampa Yoga (i.e. motionless meditation yoga), there is no doubt in this.

Original: 10.8 I am the source of all; from Me everything evolves; understanding thus, the wise, endowed with meditation, worship Me.
Translated: 10.8. I am the dominant place of all; It is only from me that the whole world attains development, knowing this the wise people worship me with full devotion.

Original: 10.9 With their mind and their life wholly absorbed in Me, enlightening each other and ever speaking of Me, they are satisfied and delighted.
Translated: 10.9. The devotees who fix their mind on Me and surrender their lives (senses) to Me, always become satisfied and happy while making each other aware of Me and talking about Me.

Original: 10.10 To them who are ever steadfast, worshipping Me with love, I give the Yoga of discrimination by which they come to Me.
Translated: ..10.10.. To those devotees who are daily united with me and worship me with love, I give the 'Buddhiyoga' by which they attain me.

Original: 10.11 Out of mere compassion for them, I, dwelling within their Self, destroy the darkness born of ignorance by the luminous lamp of knowledge.
Translated: ..10.11.. To show favor to them, I reside in their hearts and destroy the darkness born of ignorance with the lamp of luminous knowledge.

Original: 10.12 Arjuna said  Thou art the Supreme Brahman, the supreme abode (or the supreme light), the supreme purifier, eternal, divine Person, the primeval God, unborn andn omnipresent.
Translated: ..10.12.. Arjun said - You are the ultimate Brahma, the ultimate abode and the ultimate pure; The eternal divine man, the progenitor of gods, is birthless and omnipresent.

Original: 10.13 All the sages have thus declared Thee, as also the divine sage Narada; so also Asita, Devala and Vyasa; and now Thou Thyself sayest so to me.
Translated: 10.13. This is what all the sages say to you;  Similarly, Devarshi Narad, Asit, Deval Rishi and Vyas and you yourself also say about me.

Original: 10.14 I believe all this that Thou sayest to me to be true, O Krishna; verily, O blessed Lord! neither the gods nor the demons know Thy manifestation (origin).
Translated: ..10.14.. Hey Keshav! Whatever you say about me, I consider it all to be true. Oh Lord, neither the gods nor the demons know your (real) form.

Original: Swami Sivananda did not comment on this sloka
Translated: ..10.15.. Hey Purushottam! Hey ghostly spirit! Hey Bhootesh! O God of gods! O Lord of the world! You yourself know yourself.

Original: 10.16 Thou shouldst indeed tell, without reserve, of Thy divine glories by which Thou existest, pervading all these worlds. (None else can do so.)
Translated: ..10.16.. You are the only one who is qualified to call those divine personalities of yours as essence, through which you have pervaded all these worlds.

Original:
10.17 How shall I, ever meditating, know Thee, O Yogin? In what aspects or things, O blessed 
Lord, art Thou to be thought of by me?
Translated: ..10.17.. Oh Yogeshwar! How can I know you by thinking continuously, and oh Lord! In what ways are you worthy of being contemplated by me?

Original: 10.18 Tell me again in detail, O Krishna, of Thy Yogic power and glory; for I am not satiated with what I have heard of Thy life-giving and nectar-like speech.
Translated: ..10.18.. Hey Janardan! Tell me again in detail about your yogic power and glory, because I am never satisfied while listening to your nectar-filled words.

Original: 10.19 The Blessed Lord said  Very well! Now I will declare to thee My divine glories in their prominence, O Arjuna; there is no end to their detailed description.
Translated: ..10.19.. Shri Bhagwan said - Sir, now I will tell you about my divine personalities with priority. O great Kurus, there is no end to my expansion.

Original: 10.20 I am the Self, O Gudakesa, seated in the hearts of all beings; I am the beginning, the middle and also the end of all beings.
Translated: ..10.20.. O Gudakesh (sleeping one)! I am the soul of everyone located in the heart of all beings and I am also the beginning, middle and end of all beings.

Original: 10.21 Among the (twelve) Adityas, I am Vishnu; among luminaries, the radiant sun; I am Marichi among the (seven or forty-nine) Maruts; among stars the moon am I.
Translated: ..10.21.. I am Vishnu among the (twelve) Adityas and Anshuman Surya among the lights; I (forty-nine) am Marichi among the Maruts (wind gods) and among the constellations I am Shashi (Moon).

Original: 10.22 Among the Vedas I am the Sama-Veda; I am Vasava among the gods; among the senses I am the mind; and I am intelligence among living beings.
Translated: ..10.22.. I am Samaveda among the Vedas, I am Vasava (Indra) among the gods; I am the mind in the senses and consciousness (knowledge power) in the living beings.

Original: 10.23 And, among the Rudras I am Sankara; among the Yakshas and Rakshasas, the Lord of wealth (Kubera); among the Vasus I am Pavaka (fire); and among the (seven) mountains I am the Meru.
Translated: ..10.23.. I am Shankar among the (eleven) Rudras and among the Yakshas and demons I am Kuber (Vittesha), the lord of wealth; (8) I am Agni among the Vasus and I am Meru among the peaked mountains.

Original:
10.24 And, among the household priests (of kings), O Arjuna, know Me to be the chief, Brihaspati; among the army generals I am Skana; among lakes I am the ocean.
'
Translated: ..10.24.. Hey Parth! Know me to be Brihaspati among the priests; I am Skanda among commanders and the ocean among reservoirs.

Original: 10.25 Among the great sages I am Bhrigu; among words I am the one syllable (Om); among sacrifices I am the sacrifice of silent repetition; among the immovable things I am the Himalayas.
Translated: ..10.25.. I am Bhrigu among the Maharishis and Omkar in words. I am the Japayajna among yagyas and Himalaya among immovables.

Original: 10.26 Among all the trees ( I am) the Peepul; among the divine sages, I am Narada; among Gandharvas, Chitraratha; among the perfected, the sage Kapila.
Translated: ..10.26.. I am Ashvattha (Peepal) among all the trees and Narad among the Devarshis; I am Chitrarath among the Gandharvas and Kapil Muni among the accomplished men.

Original: 10.27 Know Me as Ucchaisravas born of nectar, among horses; among lordly elephants (I am) the Airavata; and, among men, the king.
Translated: ..10.27.. Among the horses, know me only, the horse named Uchchaishrava born from nectar, Airavata among the elephants and the king among humans.

Original: 10.28 Among weapons I am the thunderbolt; among cows I am the wish-fulfilling cow called Kamadhenu; I am the progenitor, the god of love; among serpents I am Vasuki.
Translated: ..10.28.. I am the thunderbolt among weapons and Kamadhenu among the cows, I am Kandarpa (Kamadev) the cause of creation of people and I am Vasuki among the snakes.

Original: 10.29 I am Ananta among the Nagas; I am Varuna among water-deities; Aryaman among the Manes I am; I am Yama among the governors.
Translated: ..10.29.. I am Anant (Sheshnag) among the snakes and Varun among the water gods; I am Aryama among the ancestors and Yama among those who regulate.

Original: 10.30 And, I am Prahlada among the demons, among the reckoners I am time; among beasts I am the lion, and Vainateya (Garuda) among birds.
Translated: ..10.30.. I am Prahlad among the demons and Kaal among those who calculate, I am the lion (Mrigendra) among the animals and Garuda among the birds.

Original: 10.31 Among the purifiers (or the speeders) I am the wind; Rama among the warriors am I; among the fishes I am the shark; among the streams I am the Ganga.
Translated: ..10.31.. I am Vayu among those who purify and I am Ram among those who wield weapons; And among fishes I am the crocodile and among rivers I am the Ganga.

Original: 10.32 Among creations I am the beginning, the middle and also the end, O Arjuna; among the sciences I am the science of the Self; and I am the logic among controversialists.
Translated: ..10.32.. Hey Arjun! I am the beginning, end and middle of the creations, I am the spiritual knowledge among the sciences and I am the debate among those who dispute (i.e. among the types of disputes).

Original:
10.33 Among the letters of the alphabets, the letter 'A' I am and the dual among the compounds. I am verily the inexhaustible or everlasting time; I am the dispenser (of the fruits of actions) having 
faces in all directions.
Translated: ..10.33.. I am formless in letters (alphabet) and duality in compounds (called compound); I am the one who is eternal and world-first (Virat Swaroop).

Original: 10.34 And I am the all-devouring Death, and the prosperity of those who are to be prosperous; among the feminine alities (I am) fame, prosperity, speech, memory, intelligence, firmness and forgiveness.
Translated: ..10.34.. I am the cause of omnivorous death and the origin of all future ones; Among women, I am Kirti, Shri, Vak (speech), Smriti, Medha, Dhriti and Kshama.

Original: 10.35 Among the hymns also I am the Brihatsaman; among metres Gayatri am I; among the montsh I am the Margasirsha; among the seasons (I am) the flowery season.
Translated: ..10.35.. In Samas (lyrical mantras) I am Brihatsam and in Chhandas I am Gayatri Chhand; I am Margashirsha among the months (part of December-January) and spring among the seasons.

Original: 10.36 I am the gambling of the fraudulent; I am the splendour of the splendid; I am victory; I am determination (of those who are determined); I am the goodness of the good.
Translated: ..10.36.. I am brave among the deceitful and am brilliant among the brilliant, I am the victory; I am business (entrepreneurship) and I am the virtuous spirit of virtuous men.

Original: 10.37 Among the Vrishnis I am Vaasudeva; among the Pandavas I am Arjuna; among the sages I am Vyasa; among the Poets I am Usanas, the poet.
Translated: ..10.37.. I am Vasudeva among the Vrishnis and Dhananjay among the Pandavas, I am Vyas among the sages and Ushana among the poets.

Original: 10.38 Of those who punish, I am the sceptre; among those who seek victory, I am statesmanship; and also among secrets, I am silence; knowledge among knowers I am.
Translated: ..10.38.. I am the punishment of the oppressors and the policy of those who wish to conquer; I am silent in the secrets and am the knowledge of the knowledgeable people.

Original: 10.39 And whatever is the seed of all beings, that also am I, O Arjuna; there is no being, whether moving or unmoving, that can exist without Me.
Translated: ..10.39.. Hey Arjun! I am also the seed (reason) for the origin of all existences, because there is no such variable or immovable existence which is devoid of me.

Original: 10.40 There is no end to My divine gloreis, O Arjuna, but this is a brief statement by Me of the particulars of My divine glories.
Translated: ..10.40.. Hey Parantap! There is no end to my divine gifts; I have told this detail of my personalities to one country, that is, in brief.

Original: 10.41 Whatever being there is glorious, prosperous or powerful, that know thou to be a manifestation of a part of My splendour.
Translated: ..10.41.. Whatever object (or creature) is endowed with power, radiance or power, you should consider it to have arisen from a part of my radiance.

Original: 10.42 But, of what avail to thee is the knowledge of all these details, O Arjuna? I exist, supporting this whole world by one part of Myself.
Translated: ..10.42.. Or O Arjun! What is the use of you knowing a lot? I am present holding this entire world with just a part of me.

Original: 11.1 Arjuna said  By this word (explanation) of the highest secret concerning the Self which Thou hast spoken, for the sake of blessing me, my delusion is gone.
Translated: 11.1. Arjun said - My attachment has been dispelled by the highly confidential, spiritual-related words (sermons) spoken by you to show your favor to me.

Original: 11.2 The origin and the destruction of beings verily have been heard by me in detail from Thee, O lotus-eyed Lord, and also Thy inexhaustible greatness.
Translated: 11.2. O lotus flower! I have heard from you in detail about the origin and destruction of ghosts and have also heard about your greatness (influence).

Original: 11.3 (Now) O Supreme Lord, as Thou hast thus described Thyself, O Supreme Person, I wish to see Thy divine form.
Translated: 11.3. O God! It is exactly what you call yourself. (But) Oh great man! I want to see your divine form directly.

Original: 11.4 If Thou, O Lord, thinkest it possible for me to see it, do Thou, then, O Lord of the Yogins, show me Thy imperishable Self.
Translated: 11.4. Oh, Lord ! If you believe that it is possible for me to see that form of yours, then oh Yogeshwar! Please show me your indestructible form.

Original: 11.5 The Blessed Lord said  Behold, O Arjuna, forms of Mine, by the hundreds and thousands, of different sorts, divine, and of various colours and shapes.
Translated: 11.5. Lord Shri said - O Partha! Look at my hundreds and thousands of divine forms of different types and with different colors and shapes.

Original: 11.6 Behold the Adityas, the Vasus, the Rudras, the two Asvins and also the Maruts; behold many wonders never seen before, O Arjuna.
Translated: 11.6. Hey India! See (in me) the Adityas, the Vasus, the Rudras and the Ashvinikumars and the Marudganas, and many more wonders never seen before.

Original: 11.7 Now behold, O Arjuna, in this, My body, the whole universe centred in one  including the moving and the unmoving  and whatever else thou desirest to see.
Translated: 11.7. Hey Gudakesh! Today (now) see the entire world including the pastures situated at one place in this body of mine and whatever else you want to see, see it also.

Original: 11.8 But thou art not able to behold Me with these thine own eyes; I give thee the divine eye; behold My lordly Yoga.
Translated: 11.8. But you are not able to see me with these (natural) eyes of yours; (Therefore) I give you divine eyes, through which you can see My divine 'Yoga'.

Original: 11.9 Sanjaya said  Having thus spoken, O king, the great Lord of Yoga, hari (Krishna), showed to Arjuna His supreme form as the Lord.
Translated: 11.9. Sanjay said - O king! Saying this, Mahayogeshwar Hari then showed his most opulent form to Arjun.

Original: 11.10 With numerous mouths and eyes, with numerous wonderful sights, with numerous divine ornaments, with numerous divine weapons uplifted (such a form He showed).
Translated: ..11.10.. That one with many mouths and eyes and having many wonderful visions and having many divine ornaments and holding many divine weapons in his hands.

Original: 11.11 Wearing divine garlands (necklaces) and apparel, anointed with divine unguents, the all-wonderful, resplendent (Being) endless with faces on all sides.
Translated: ..11.11.. Arjuna saw the infinite, Vishwatomukha (colossal form) Supreme God wearing the divine garland and clothes and smeared with divine fragrance and full of all kinds of wonders.

Original: 11.12 If the splendour of a thousand suns were to blaze out at once (simultaneously) in the sky, that would be the splendour of that mighty Being (great Soul).
Translated: 11.12. The light that will be produced by the simultaneous rising of thousands of suns in the sky will be like the light of that (universal form) God.

Original: 11.13 There, in the body of the God of gods, Arjuna then saw the whole universe resting in one, with its many groups.
Translated: ..11.13.. At that time, Pandu's son Arjun saw the entire world, divided in many ways, situated at one place in the body of Lord Krishna.

Original: 11.14 Then, Arjuna, filled with wonder and with his hair standing on end, bowed down his head to the God and spoke with joined palms.
Translated: ..11.14.. After that, he was surprised, Dhananjay Arjun, with joyful hair (who is feeling thrilled), bowed his head (with reverence and devotion) to Lord Vishwaroop and said with folded hands.

Original: 11.15 Arjuna said  I see all the gods, O God, in Thy body, and (also) hosts of various classes of beings, Brahma, the Lord, seated on the lotus, all the sages and the celestial serpents.
Translated: ..11.15.. Arjun said--O God! I am seeing in your body all the Gods and the communities of many ghosts and Brahmaji, the Lord of the universe, sitting on Kamalasana, the sages and the divine snakes.

Original: 11.16 I see Thee of boundless form on every side with many arms, stomachs, mouths and eyes: neither the end nor the middle nor also the beginning do I see, O Lord of the universe, O Cosmic Form.
Translated: ..11.16.. O Vishweshwar! I see you having many arms, abdomen, mouth and eyes and having infinite forms from all sides. O world form! I see neither your end nor your middle nor your beginning.

Original:
11.17 I see Thee with the diadem, the club and the discus, a mass of radiance shining 
everywhere, very hard to look at, blazing all round like burning fire and the sun, and immeasurable.
Translated: ..11.17.. I see you crowned, armed with a mace and discus, a beam of light shining from all sides, glowing like fire and the sun, very difficult to see and inexplicable from all sides.

Original: 11.18 Thou art the Imperishable, the Supreme Being, worthy to be known. Thou art the great treasure-house of this universe; Thou art the imperishable protector of the eternal Dhrama; Thou art the Primal Person, I deem.
Translated: ..11.18.. You are the supreme letter worth knowing (Veditavyam); You are the ultimate shelter of this world! You are the protector of the eternal religion and you are the eternal man, this is my opinion.

Original: 11.19 I see Thee without beginning, middle or end, infinite in power, of endless arms, the sun and the moon being Thy eyes, the burning fire Thy mouth, heating the whole universe with Thy radiance.
Translated: ..11.19.. I see you without beginning, end and middle and having infinite power and having infinite arms and having eyes like the moon and the sun and a face like bright fire and warming this world with your brilliance.

Original: 11.20 This space between the earth and the heaven and all the arters are filled by Thee alone; having seen this, Thy wonderful and teriible form, the three worlds are trembling with fear, O great-souled Being.
Translated: ..11.20.. Oh great man! This sky between heaven and earth and all the directions are pervaded by You alone; Seeing this wonderful and fierce form of yours, all three worlds are experiencing extreme pain (fear).

Original: 11.21 Verily, into Thee enter these hosts of gods; some extol Thee in fear with joined palms; saying 'may it be well', bands of great sages and perfected ones praise Thee with hymns complete.
Translated: ..11.21.. All these groups of gods are entering into you and many are frightened and praising you with folded hands; The community of Maharishis and Siddhas praise you through the best (or complete) sources, saying 'Kalyan Hove' (reciting the Swasthya).

Original: 11.22 The Rudras, Adityas, Vasus, Sadhyas, Visvedevas, the two Asvins, Maruts, the manes and the hosts of celestial singers, Yakshas, demons and the perfected ones, are all looking at Thee, in great amazement.
Translated: ..11.22.. Rudragana, Aditya, Vasu and Sadhyagan, Vishvedev and two Ashvinikumars, Marudgan and Ushampa, Gandharva, Yaksha, Asura and community of Siddhagan - all of them look at you in amazement.

Original: 11.23 Having seen Thy immeasurable form with many mouths and eyes, O mighty-armed, with many arms, thighs and feet, with many stomachs and fearful with many teeth  the worlds are terrified and so am I.
Translated: ..11.23.. Oh great arms! Seeing your great form with many mouths and eyes, many arms, thighs and legs, many huge bellies and many huge teeth, everyone is getting distressed and in the same way I am also getting distressed. .

Original: 11.24 On seeing Thee (the Cosmic Form) touching the sky, shining in many colours, with mouths wide open, with large fiery eyes, I am terrified at heart and find neither courage nor peace, O Vishnu.
Translated: ..11.24.. Hey Vishno! Seeing you with many resplendent forms touched with the sky and with wide mouth and huge shining eyes, I am frightened and am unable to find patience and peace.

Original: 11.25 Having seen Thy mouths fearful with teeth (blazing) like the fires of cosmic dissolution, I know not the four arters, nor do I find peace. Have mercy, O Lord of the gods, O abode of the universe.
Translated: ..11.25.. Looking at your faces with huge beards and burning like the fire of destruction, I am neither able to know the directions nor attain peace; That's why O Devesh!  Oh Jagannivas! You become happy.

Original: 11.26 All the sons of Dhritarashtra, with the hosts of kings of the earth, Bhishma, Drona and Karna, with the chief among our warriors.
Translated: ..11.26.. And all these sons of Dhritarashtra enter into you along with the company of kings. Bhishma, Drona and Karna and also the chief warriors of our side...

Original: 11.27 Some hurriedly enter Thy mouths with their terrible teeth, fearful to behold. Some are found sticking in the gaps between the teeth with their heads crushed to powder.
Translated: ..11.27.. With great speed they enter your terrible mouths with huge molars and many are seen stuck between your teeth along with powdered heads.

Original: 11.28 Verily, just as many torrents of rivers flow towards the ocean, even so these heroes in the world of men enter Thy flaming mouths.
Translated: ..11.28.. Just as the numerous streams of rivers flow rapidly towards the sea, in the same way these brave warriors of the human world enter your blazing mouths.

Original: 11.29 As moths hurriedly rush into a blazing fire for (their own) destruction, so also these creatures hurriedly rush into Thy mouths for (their own) destruction.
Translated: ..11.29.. Just as moths enter the burning fire with great speed to destroy themselves, similarly these people also enter your mouth with great speed to destroy themselves.

Original: 11.30 Thou lickest up, devouring all the worlds on every side with Thy flaming mouths. Thy fierce rays, filling the whole world with radiance, are burning, O Vishnu!
Translated: ..11.30.. Hey Vishno! You are consuming and enjoying all these worlds with your flaming mouths, your fiery light is warming the entire world by filling it with brilliance.

Original: 11.31 Tell me, who Thou art, so fierce of form. Salutations to Thee, O God Supreme: have mercy. I desire to know Thee, the original Being. I know not indeed Thy working.
Translated: ..11.31.. (Please) tell me, who are you in the fierce form? O best among the gods! Greetings to you, may you be happy. I want to know you as the original form (from the essence), because I am not able to understand your nature (i.e. purpose).

Original: 11.32 The Blessed Lord said  I am the full-grown world-destroying Time, now engaged in destroying the worlds. Even without thee, none of the warriors arrayed in the hostile armies shall live.
Translated: ..11.32.. Shri Bhagwan said - I am the old Kaal who destroys the worlds. At this time, I am engaged in destroying these worlds. All those warriors in the adversary's army will not survive even without you.

Original: 11.33 Therefore, stand up and obtain fame. Coner the enemies and enjoy the unrivalled kingdom. Verily by Me have they been already slain; be thou a mere instrument, O Arjuna.
Translated: ..11.33.. Therefore you stand up and achieve fame; Enjoy a prosperous kingdom by conquering your enemies. All of them have already been killed by me. O Savyasachin! You become the only reason.

Original: 11.34 Drona, Bhishma, Jayadratha, Karna and other brave warriors  these are already slain by Me: do thou kill; be not distressed with fear; fight and thou shalt coner thy enemies in battle.
Translated: ..11.34.. You kill Drona, Bhishma, Jayadratha, Karna and many other brave warriors killed by me; Don't be afraid; make war; You will win over your enemies in the war.

Original: 11.35 Sanjaya said  Having heard that speech of Lord Krishna, Arjuna, with joined palms, trembling, prostrating himself, again addressed Krishna, in a choked voice, bowing down, overwhelmed with fear.
Translated: ..11.35.. Sanjay said - Hearing these words of Lord Keshav, the crowned Arjuna, with folded hands, trembling and offering namaskar, again became frightened and spoke in an angry voice towards Shri Krishna.

Original: 11.36 Arjuna said  It is meet, O Krishna, that the world delights and rejoices in Thy praise; demons fly in fear to all arters and the hosts of the perfected ones bow to Thee.
Translated: ..11.36.. Arjun said - It is worthy that the world becomes very happy with your Kirtan and Anurag also gets it. Frightened demons run in all directions and the entire community of siddhas salute you.

Original: 11.37 And why should they not, O great Soul, bow to Thee Who art greater (than all else), the primal cause even of the Creator (Brahma), O Infinite Being, O Lord of the gods, O Abode of the universe; Thou art the imperishable, the Being, the non-being and That which is the supreme (that which is beyond the Being and the non-being).
Translated: ..11.37.. Oh great man! How can they not pay obeisance to you, even Brahma, the original doer and the best of all? (Because) O Eternal! Hey Devesh! Oh Jagannivas! You are the one who is beyond the true and false and the Akshar Tattva.

Original: 11.38 Thou art the primal God, the ancient Purusha, the supreme refuge of this universe, the knower, the knowable and the supreme Abode. By Thee is the universe pervaded, O Being of infinite forms.
Translated: ..11.38.. You are Adidev and Purana (Eternal) man. You are the ultimate shelter of this world, the knower, the knowable, (able to know) and the ultimate abode. O infinite form, this world is pervaded by you.

Original: 11.39 Thou art Vayu, Yama, Agni, Varuna, the moon, the Creator, and the great-grandfather. Salutations, salutations unto Thee, a thousand times, and again salutations, salutations unto Thee.
Translated: ..11.39.. You are Vayu, Yama, Agni, Varuna, Chandrama, Prajapati (Brahma) and Prapitamaha (also the cause of Brahma); A thousand times Namaskar, Namaskar to you, once again Namaskar, Namaskar to you again and again.

Original: 11.40 Salutations to Thee, in front and behind! Salutations to Thee on every side! O All!! Thou infinite in power and prowess, pervadest all; wherefore Thou art all.
Translated: ..11.40.. Oh God of infinite power! Salutations to you from the front and the back, O Supreme Soul! Greetings to you from all sides. You are infinite and powerful and you have pervaded everyone, hence you are omnipresent.

Original: 11.41 Whatever I have presumptuously said from carelessness or love, addressing Thee as O Krishna! O Yadava! O Friend! regarding Thee merely as a friend, unknowing of this, Thy greatness.
Translated: ..11.41.. Oh God! Considering you as my friend and not knowing your greatness, out of negligence or even out of love, I said, "O Krishna! O Yadav, my friend!" Whatever has been said in this way is forced.

Original: 11.42 In whatever way I may have insulted Thee for the sake of fun, while at play, reposing, sitting or at meals, when alone (with Thee), O Krishna, or in company  that I implore Thee, immeasurable one, to forgive.
Translated: ..11.42.. And, O Achyuta! I apologize to you in an inexplicable form for all those who have been insulted by me for the sake of laughter, whether in bed, in bed, during meals, in private or even in front of others.

Original: 11.43 Thou art the Father of this world, moving and unmoving. Thou art to be adored by this world, Thou, the greatest Guru; (for) none there exists who is eal to Thee; how then could there be another superior to Thee in the three worlds, O Being of unealled power?
Translated: ..11.43.. You are the father, the worshipable and the best teacher of this living world. O God of immense influence! There is no one equal to you in the three worlds, then how can anyone be better than you?

Original:
11.44 Therefore, bowing down, prostrating my body, I crave Thy forgiveness, O adorable Lord. As a father forgives his son, a friend his (dear) friend, a lover his beloved, even so shouldst Thou 
forgive me, O God.
Translated: ..11.44.. That's why oh God! I prostrate myself with my body and pray to please the praiseworthy God. Hey, God! Just as a father forgives the transgressions of his son, a friend forgives his friend and a lover forgives his beloved's transgressions, similarly you too forgive my transgressions.

Original: 11.45 I am delighted, having seen what has never been seen before; and yet my mind is distressed with fear. Show me that (previous) form only, O God; have mercy, O God of gods, O Abode of the universe.
Translated: ..11.45.. I am feeling happy after seeing this invisible form of yours and my mind is also getting overwhelmed with fear. That's why oh God! You show me that earlier period only. Hey Devesh! Oh Jagannivas! You be happy.

Original: 11.46 I desire to see Thee as before, crowned, bearing a mace, with the discus in hand, in Thy former form only, having four arms, O thousand-armed, Cosmic Form (Being).
Translated: ..11.46.. I want to see you wearing the same crown, holding mace and discus in your hands. O idol of the world! O thousand-armed one! You become like that quadrilateral.

Original: 11.47 The Blessed Lord said  O Arjuna, this Cosmic Form has graciously been shown to thee by Me by My own Yogic power; full of splendour, primeval, and infinite, this Cosmic Form of Mine has never been seen before by anyone other than thyself.
Translated: ..11.47.. Hey Arjun! Being pleased with you, with the influence of my power of yoga (self-realization), I have shown you this most brilliant, original and infinite form of the universe, which no one has seen before you.

Original: 11.48 Neither by the study of the Vedas and sacrifices, nor by gifts nor by rituals nor by severe austerities can I be seen in this form in the world of men by any other than thyself, O great hero of the Kurus (Arjuna).
Translated: ..11.48.. O Kurupravira! Apart from you, I cannot be seen in this form by anyone else in this human world, neither through the study of the Vedas, nor through sacrifices, nor through charity, nor through (religious) activities, nor through severe penances.
