Original: 11.49 Be not afraid, nor bewildered on seeing such a teriible form of Mine as this; with thy fear dispelled and with a gladdened heart, now behold again this former form of Mine.
Translated: ..11.49.. In this way, seeing this terrible form of mine, do not get pain and foolishness. Be fearless and happy and see my same (earlier) form again.

Original: 11.50 Sanjaya said  Having thus spoken to Arjuna, Krishna again showed His own form and the great Soul (Krishna), assuming His gentle form, consoled him (Arjuna) who was terrified.
Translated: ..11.50.. Sanjaya said - Lord Vasudeva, saying this to Arjuna, again showed His (former) form, and then, the mild-mannered Mahatma Shri Krishna reassured this frightened Arjuna.

Original: 11.51 Arjuna said  Having seen this Thy gentle human form, O Krishna, now I am composed and am restored to my own nature.
Translated: ..11.51.. Arjun said--O Janardan! Seeing this gentle human form of yours, I have become calm and have regained my nature.

Original: 11.52 The Blessed Lord said  Very hard indeed it is to see this form of Mine which thou hast seen. Even the gods are ever longing to behold it.
Translated: ..11.52.. Shri Bhagwan said - It is very rare to see this form of mine which you have seen. Even the gods always desire to see this form.

Original: 11.53 Neither by the Vedas nor by austerity, nor by gift, nor by sacrifice can I be seen in this form as thou hast seen Me (so easily).
Translated: ..11.53.. Neither by the Vedas, nor by penance, nor by charity, nor by yajna can I be seen as you have seen me.

Original: 11.54 But by single-minded devotion can I, of this Form, be known and seen in reality and also entered into, O Arjuna.
Translated: ..11.54.. But oh blessed Arjun! Through exclusive devotion, I am fundamentally capable of 'knowing', 'seeing' and 'entering' (to attain with a single feeling).

Original: 11.55 He who does all actions for Me, who looks upon Me as the Supreme, who is devoted to Me, who is free from attachment, who bears enmity towards no creature, he comes to Me, O Arjuna.
Translated: ..11.55.. Hey Pandavas! The man who works for me only, and considers me as the ultimate goal, who is my devotee and is free from attachment, who has no animosity towards mere existence, he is attained by me.

Original: 12.1 Arjuna said  Those devotees who, ever steadfast, thus worship Thee and those also who worship the imperishable and the unmanifested  which of them are better versed in Yoga?
Translated: 12.1. Arjun said - The devotees who worship you in this (aforesaid) manner by being constantly united and the devotees who worship the Akshar and the Avyakt, which is the best Yogavit?

Original: 12.2 The Blessed Lord said  Those who, fixing their mind on Me, worship Me, ever steadfast and endowed with supreme faith, are the best in Yoga in My opinion.
Translated: 12.2. Shri Bhagwan said - Those devotees who concentrate their mind on Me and worship Me daily with utmost faith, they are, in my opinion, the most auspicious i.e. the best.

Original: Swami Sivananda did not comment on this sloka
Translated: Swami Tejomayananda did not comment on this sloka

Original: 12.4 Having restrained all the senses, even-minded everywhere, intent on the welfare of all beings  verily they also come unto Me.
Translated: 12.4. By properly regulating the senses, those devotees who have equanimity everywhere and are engaged in the welfare of all existence, are attained by me only.

Original: 12.5 Greater is their trouble whose minds are set on the unmanifested; for the goal; the unmanifested, is very hard for the embodied to reach.
Translated: 12.5. But those people whose minds are attached to the unmanifested face more distress, because the movement of the unmanifested is achieved with difficulty from the bodily beings.

Original: 12.6 But to those who worship Me, renouncing all actions in Me, regarding Me as the supreme gaol, meditating on Me with single-minded Yoga.
Translated: 12.6. But the devotees who consider Me as the ultimate goal and dedicate all their deeds to Me and meditate on Me (Saguna) through Ananyayoga.

Original: 12.7 To those whose minds are set on Me, O Arjuna, verily I become ere long the saviour out of the ocean of Samsara.
Translated: ..12.7.. Hey Parth! I will soon save those devotees whose mind is fixed on me from the ocean of death.

Original: 12.8 Fix thy mind in Me only, thy intellect in Me, (then) thou shalt no doubt live in Me alone hereafter.
Translated: 12.8. You fix your mind and intellect in me, only then you will reside in me, there is no doubt in this.

Original: 12.9 If thou art unable to fix thy mind steadily on Me, then by the Yoga of constant practice do thou seek to reach Me, O Arjuna.
Translated: ..12.9.. Hey Dhananjay! If you are not able to fix your mind on Me, then you should desire (ie try) to attain Me through Abhyasa Yoga.

Original: 12.10 If thou art unable to practise even this Abhyasa Yoga, be thou intent on doing actions for My sake; even by doing actions for My sake, thou shalt attain perfection.
Translated: ..12.10.. If you are unable even to practice, then become devoted to matkarma; In this way, even while performing deeds for me, you will achieve success.

Original: 12.11 If thou art unable to do even this, then, resorting to union with Me, renounce the fruits of all actions with the self controlled.
Translated: ..12.11.. And if you are unable to do even this, then by having self-control and taking refuge in Yoga in the form of my attainment, you should give up the fruits of all your actions.

Original: 12.12 Better indeed is knowledge than practice; than knowledge meditation is better; than meditation the renunciation of the fruits of actions: peace immediately follows renunciation.
Translated: ..12.12.. Knowledge is better than practice; Meditation is better than knowledge and the fruit of action better than meditation is renunciation; One gets immediate peace.

Original: 12.13 He who hates no creature, who is friendly and compassionate to all, who is free from attachment and egoism, balanced in pleasure and pain, and forgiving.
Translated: ..12.13.. Who is without malice towards all living beings and is a friend and compassionate person to all; Who is free from attachment and ego, equanimous and forgiving in happiness and sorrow.

Original: 12.14 Ever content, steady in meditation, self-controlled, possessed of firm conviction, with the mind and intellect dedicated to Me, he, My devtoee, is dear to Me.
Translated: ..12.14.. The balanced soul, the determined yogi who is always content, the one who has surrendered his mind and intellect to me, the one who is such a devotee of mine, he is dear to me.

Original: 12.15 He by whom the world is not agitated and who cannot be agitated by the world, and who is freed from joy, anger, fear and anxiety  he is dear to Me.
Translated: ..12.15.. The devotee from whom no world (i.e. living being, person) gets agitated and who himself does not experience agitation from any person and who is free from joy, amarsh (intolerance), fear and excitement, is dear to me.

Original: 12.16 He who is free from wants, pure, expert, unconcerned, and free from pain, renouncing all undertakings or commencements  he who is (thus) devoted to Me, is dear to Me.
Translated: ..12.16.. The one who is my devotee who has no expectations, is pure, efficient, disinterested, free from pain and has renounced all activities, is dear to me.

Original: 12.17 He who neither rejoices, nor hates, nor grieves, nor desires, renouncing good and evil, and who is full of devotion, is dear to Me.
Translated: ..12.17.. One who neither rejoices nor hates; Neither mourns nor longs; And the one who gives up auspicious and inauspicious, that devout man is dear to me.

Original: Swami Sivananda did not comment on this sloka
Translated: Swami Tejomayananda did not comment on this sloka

Original: 12.19 He to whom censure and praise are eal, who is silent, content with anything, homeless, of a steady mind, and full of devotion  that man is dear to Me.
Translated: ..12.19.. The one who is equal to both praise and criticism, who is silent, who is satisfied with even a small thing, who is indecisive, that devoted man with a stable mind is dear to me.

Original: 12.20 They verily who follow this immortal Dharma (law or doctrine) as described above, endowed with faith, regarding Me as their supreme goal, they, the devotees, are exceedingly dear to Me.
Translated: ..12.20.. Those devotees who are devout and consider me as the ultimate goal and follow this righteous nectar i.e. a righteous life, they are very dear to me.

Original: 13.1 Arjuna said  I wish to learn about Nature (matter) and the Spirit (soul), the field and the knower of the field, knowledge and that which ought to be known, O Kesava.
Translated: ..13.1.. Arjun said--O Keshav! I want to know nature and man, area and the subject, knowledge and the known.

Original: 13.2 The Blessed Lord said  This body, O Arjuna, is called the field; he who knows it is called the knower of the field, by those who know of them.
Translated: 13.2. Shri Bhagwan said - O Kaunteya! This body is called Kshetra and the one who knows it is called Tatvagya Jan, Kshetragya.

Original: 13.3 Do thou also know Me as the knower of the field in all fields, O Arjuna. Knowledge of both the field and the knower of the field is considered by Me to be ï1the ï1 knowledge.
Translated: 13.3. Hey India! You know me only as an expert in all fields. It is my opinion that the knowledge of the field and the expert is the real knowledge.

Original: 13.4 What the field is and of what nature, what are its modifications and whence it is and also who He is and what His powers are  hear all that from Me in brief.
Translated: 13.4. Therefore, hear from me in brief what that field is and what it is like and the disorders it has, and the (reason) due to which the (action) has happened and also what it (Kshetragya) is and what effect it has.

Original: 13.5 Sages have sung in many ways, in various distinctive chants and also in the suggestive words indicative of the Absolute, full of reasoning and decisive.
Translated: 13.5. (Concerning the Kshetra-Kshetrajna) has been sung in many ways by the sages in various and sundry verses, and has also been (said in the same way) through the verses of the Brahma Sutra properly determined and justified (i.e. through the words indicative of Brahma). ..

Original: 13.6 The great elements, egoism, intellect, and also the Unmanifested Nature, the ten senses and one (mind), and the five objects of the senses.
Translated: 13.6. Panch Mahabhuta, ego, intellect, unmanifested (nature), ten senses, one mind, five objects of senses.

Original: 13.7 Desire, hatred, pleasure, pain, the aggregate (the body), intelligence, fortitude  the field has thus been briefly described with its modifications.
Translated: ..13.7.. Desire, aversion, happiness, sorrow, Sanghat (physical body), Chetna (conscious instinct of the conscience) and Dhriti - thus this area is stated in brief along with the disorders.

Original: 13.8 Humility, unpretentiousness, non-injury, forgiveness, uprightness, service of the teacher, purity, steadfastness, self-control.
Translated: ..13.8.. Inhumanity, humility, non-violence, forgiveness, arjava, service to Acharya, purification, stability and self-control.

Original: 13.9 Indifference to the objects of the senses and also absence of egoism; perception of (or reflection on) the evil in birth, death, old age, sickness and pain.
Translated: ..13.9.. Detachment towards the objects of the senses, absence of ego, seeing faults in birth, death, old age, disease and sorrow...

Original: 13.10 Non-attachment, non-identification of the Self with son, wife, home and the rest, and constant even-mindedness on the attainment of the desirable and the undesirable.
Translated: ..13.10.. Attachment and lack of identification with son, wife, home etc.; And equanimity in achieving good and evil.

Original: 13.11 Unswerving devotion unto Me by the Yoga of non-separation, resort to solitary places, distaste for the society of men.
Translated: ..13.11.. Unadulterated devotion in Me through Ananyayoga; Nature of living in a solitary place and disinterest in the community of (uncultured) people.

Original: 13.12 Constancy in Self-knowledge, perception of the end of true knowledge  this is declared to be knowledge, and what is opposed to it is ignorance.
Translated: ..13.12.. In spiritual knowledge, eternity i.e. stability and the philosophy of God as the meaning of philosophy, all this is called knowledge, and whatever is contrary to this is ignorance.

Original: 13.13 I will declare that which has to be known, knowing which one attains to immortality, the beginningless supreme Brahman, called neither being nor non-being.
Translated: ..13.13.. I will clearly describe that knowable object by knowing which man attains immortality. He is knowable - the eternal, ultimate Brahma, who can be called neither true nor false.

Original: 13.14 With hands and feet everywhere, with eyes, heads and mouths everywhere, with ears everywhere, He exists in the worlds enveloping all.
Translated: ..13.14.. He has arms and legs on all sides, eyes, head and mouth on all sides and ears on all sides; He is situated pervading everyone in the world.

Original: 13.15 Shining by the functions of all the senses, yet without the senses; unattached, yet supporting all; devoid of alities, yet their experiencer.
Translated: ..13.15.. He is illuminated by the qualities (functions) of all the senses, but is (actually) devoid of all the senses; Despite being free from attachment and devoid of virtues, He is the sustainer of all and the enjoyer of virtues.

Original: 13.16 Without and within (all) beings the unmoving and also the moving; because of Its subtlety, unknowable; and near and far away is That.
Translated: ..13.16.. (That Brahma) is situated within the existence of mere existence; He is variable and also constant. Being subtle it is undetectable; He is both distant and very close.

Original: 13.17 And undivided, yet It exists as if divided in beings; It is to be known as the supporter of being; It devours and It generates.
Translated: ..13.17.. And He is undivided, yet He is situated among the ghosts like a divided one. That knowable Brahma is the creator, destroyer and originator of all existence.

Original: 13.18 That, the Light of all lights, is said to be beyond darkness: knowledge, the knowable and the goal of knowledge, seated in the hearts of all.
Translated: ..13.18.. (That Brahma) is said to be the light of lights and beyond the darkness of (ignorance). That knowledge (Chaitanya Swarup) is knowable and knowable through knowledge (Gyangamya). He is situated in everyone's heart.

Original: 13.19 Thus the field, as well as knowledge and the knowable have been briefly stated. My devotee, knowing this, enters into My Being.
Translated: ..13.19.. Thus, (by me) the field, knowledge and the known were briefly stated. By knowing it from its essence (Vigyaya), My devotee attains My form.

Original: 13.20 Know thou that Nature (matter) and the Spirit are both beginningless; and know also that all modifications and alities are born of Nature.
Translated: ..13.20.. You should know both nature and man as eternal. And you should also know that all the vices and virtues have arisen from nature itself.

Original: 13.21 In the production of the effect and the cause, Nature (matter) is said to be the cause; in the experience of pleasure and pain, the soul is said to be the cause.
Translated: ..13.21.. Prakriti is said to be the cause in giving rise to cause and effect and Purusha is said to be the cause in the enjoyment of happiness and sorrow.

Original: 13.22 The soul seated in Nature experiences the alities born of Nature; attachment to the alities is the cause of its birth in good and evil wombs.
Translated: ..13.22.. A man situated in nature enjoys the qualities emanating from nature. The combination of these qualities is the reason for this man (being) to be born in auspicious and inauspicious species.

Original: 13.23 The Supreme Soul in this body is also called the spectator, the permitter, the supporter, the enjoyer, the great Lord and the Supreme Self.
Translated: ..13.23.. The Supreme Being is called the Creator, Sumanta, Bharta, Enjoyer, Maheshwar and Supreme Soul in this body.

Original: 13.24 He who thus knows the Spirit and Matter together with the alities, in whatever condition he may be, he is not born again.
Translated: ..13.24.. In this way, the man who knows nature along with man and qualities, even while living (behaving) in every way, is not born again.

Original: 13.25 Some by meditation behold the Self in the self by the self, others by the Yoga of knowledge, and still others by the Yoga of action.
Translated: ..13.25.. Some men, by the practice of meditation, see the soul in the soul (heart) through the soul (pure intellect); Others see the soul through Sankhya Yoga and some seekers through Karma Yoga.

Original: 13.26 Others also, not knowing thus, worship, having heard of It from others; they, too, cross beyond death, regarding what they have heard as the Supreme refuge.
Translated: ..13.26.. But, other people who worship only after hearing from others (Acharyas) without knowing it themselves, those people who are Shrutiparayan (i.e. for whom hearing is the ultimate means) also avoid death without any doubt.

Original: 13.27 Wherever a being is born, whether unmoving or moving, know thou, O best of the Bharatas (Arjuna), that it is from the union between the field and its knower.
Translated: ..13.27.. O great Bharat! In other words, whatever immovable or movable object is produced, you should know that it has arisen from the combination of the field and the knower of the field.

Original: 13.28 He sees, who sees the Supreme Lord, existing eally in all beings, the unperishing within the perishing.
Translated: ..13.28.. The man who sees the immortal God present in all mortal beings with equanimity, only he (really) sees.

Original: 13.29 Because he who sees the same Lord eally dwelling everywhere does not destroy the Self by the self; he goes to the highest goal.
Translated: ..13.29.. Certainly, that man does not destroy the soul (swayam) through the soul (swayam) who is equal to God and is present everywhere with equal feelings, through this he attains the supreme state.

Original: 13.30 He sees, who sees that all actions are performed by Nature alone and that the Self is actionless.
Translated: ..13.30.. The man who sees all the actions as being done entirely by nature and sees the soul as the non-doer, only he (truly) sees.

Original: 13.31 When a man sees the whole variety of beings as resting in the One, and spreading forth from That alone, he then becomes Brahman.
Translated: ..13.31.. When this man sees the separate expressions of the ghosts situated in one (God) and knows that this expansion has come from Him (God) only, then he attains Brahma.

Original: 13.32 Being without beginning and being devoid of (any) alities, the Supreme Self, imperishable, though dwelling in the body, O Arjuna, neither acts nor is tainted.
Translated: ..13.32.. Hey Konteya! Being eternal and without qualities, this God is indestructible. Although situated in the body, in reality, he neither performs (actions) nor gets attached (to the fruits).

Original: 13.33 As the all-pervading ether is not tainted, because of its subtlety, so the Self seated everywhere in the body is not tainted.
Translated: ..13.33.. Just as the omnipresent sky does not get entangled because it is subtle, in the same way the soul present in the body does not get entangled everywhere.

Original:
13.34 Just as the one sun illumines the whole world, so also the Lord of the field (Supreme Self) 
illumines the whole field, O Arjuna.
Translated: ..13.34.. Hey India! Just as only one sun illuminates the entire world, in the same way only one Kshetri (expert in the field) illuminates the entire region.

Original: 13.35 They who, by the eye of knowledge, perceive the distinction between the field and its knower and also the liberation from the Nature of being, go to the Supreme.
Translated: ..13.35.. Thus, those men who, through the eye of knowledge, know the difference between the field and the knower of the field and salvation from the disorders of nature, they attain the Supreme Brahma.

Original: 14.1 The Blessed Lord said  I will again declare (to thee) that supreme knowledge, the best of all knowledge, having known which all the sages have gone to the supreme perfection after this life.
Translated: ..14.1.. Shri Bhagwan said - I will again tell you about the supreme knowledge, which is the best among all the knowledge, knowing which all the sages have attained the ultimate success after leaving this world.

Original: 14.2 They who, having taken refuge in this knowledge, have attained to unity with Me, are neither born at the time of creation nor are they disturbed at the time of dissolution.
Translated: 14.2. By taking refuge in this knowledge, the people who attain my form (Sardhamyam) do not take birth in the beginning of creation and do not get troubled in the time of destruction.

Original: 14.3 My womb is the great Brahma; in that I place the germ; thence, O Arjuna, is the birth of all beings.
Translated: 14.3. Hey India! My Mahad Brahmarup Prakriti is the vagina (of the ghosts) in which I conceive; From this all ghosts are born.

Original: 14.4 Whatever forms are produced, O Arjuna, in any womb whatsoever, the great Brahma is their womb and I am the seed-giving father.
Translated: ..14.4.. Hey Konteya! All the idols (bodies) that are born in all the births, the birth i.e. the womb of all of them is Mahadbrahma and I am the father who establishes the seed.

Original: 14.5 Purity, passion and inertia  these alities, O Arjuna, born of Nature, bind fast in the body, the embodied, the indestructible.
Translated: ..14.5.. Oh great arms! Sattva, Raja and Tama, these three qualities arising from nature bind the physical soul with the body.

Original: 14.6 Of these, Sattva, which from its stainlessness is luminous and healthy, binds by attachment to happiness and by attachment to knowledge, O sinless one.
Translated: ..14.6.. O sinless Arjun! Of these (three), Sattva Guna, being pure, is luminous and anamaya (free from matter, free from disorders); (He binds the living being) with attachment to happiness and attachment to knowledge.

Original: 14.7 Know thou Rajas to be of the nature of passion, the source of thirst (for sensual enjoyment) and attachment; it binds fast, O Arjuna, the embodied one by attachment to action.
Translated: 14.7. Hey Konteya! Know Rajoguna as the form of Raga, which gives rise to craving and attachment. He binds the physical soul with the attachment of deeds.

Original: 14.8 But know thou Tamas to be born of ignorance, deluding all embodied beings; it binds fast, O Arjuna, by heedlessness, indolence and sleep.
Translated: ..14.8.. And oh India! Know that Tamoguna arises from ignorance; Which fascinates all the living beings. He binds the living being through carelessness, laziness and sleep.

Original: 14.9 Sattva attaches to happiness, Rajas to action, O Arjuna, while Tamas verily shrouding knowledge attaches to heedlessness.
Translated: ..14.9.. Hey India! Sattva guna makes one engrossed in happiness and Rajo guna in action, but Tamo guna covers the knowledge and makes the living being in a state of heedlessness.

Original: 14.10 Now Sattva arises (prevails), O Arjuna, having overpowered Rajas and Tamas; nor Rajas, having overpowered Sattva and Tamas; and now Tamas, having overpowered Sattva and Rajas.
Translated: ..14.10.. Hey India! Sometimes Sattva Guna increases by suppressing Rajas and Tama, sometimes Tama Guna increases by suppressing Rajas and Satva, and sometimes Rajo Guna increases by suppressing Tama and Satva.

Original: 14.11 When through every gate (sense) in this body, the wisdom-light shines, then it may be known that Sattva is predominant.
Translated: ..14.11.. When light in the form of knowledge arises in the doors of this body i.e. in all the senses, then know that Sattva Guna has increased.

Original: 14.12 Greed, activity, the undertaking of actions, restlessness, longing  these arise when Rajas is predominant, O Arjuna.
Translated: ..14.12.. O great Bharata! When Rajogun increases, greed, tendency (common intention), initiation of actions, lack of shame and desire, all these arise.

Original: 14.13 Darkness, inertness, heedlessness and delusion  these arise when Tamas is predominant, O Arjuna.
Translated: ..14.13.. Hey Kurunandan! When Tamoguna increases, darkness, indifference, carelessness and attachment all arise.

Original: 14.14 If the embodied one meets with death when Sattva is predominant, then he attains to the spotless worlds of the knowers of the Highest.
Translated: ..14.14.. When this living being (Dehbhrit) dies in the growth of Sattva Guna, then those who do good deeds attain the pure worlds i.e. heaven.

Original: 14.15 Meeting death in Rajas, he is born among those who are attached to action; and dying in Tamas, he is born in the womb of the senseless.
Translated: ..14.15.. After dying during the progression of Rajoguna, he takes birth in the human world and during the progression of Tamoguna (after death), he takes birth in the world of foolishness.

Original: 14.16 The fruit of good action, they say, is Sattvic and pure, verily the fruit of Rajas is pain, and ignorance is the fruit of Tamas.
Translated: ..14.16.. The results of good deeds have been said to be pure and pure; The result of Rajogun is sorrow and the result of Tamogun is ignorance.

Original: 14.17 From Sattva arises knowledge, and greed from Rajas; heedlessness and delusion arise from Tamas, and also ignorance.
Translated: ..14.17.. Knowledge arises from Sattva Guna. Rajogun gives rise to greed and Tamagogun gives rise to carelessness, attachment and ignorance.

Original: 14.18 Those who are seated in Sattva go upwards; the Rajasic dwell in the middle; and the Tamasic, abiding in the function of the lowest Guna, go downwards.
Translated: ..14.18.. Men situated in Sattva Guna go higher (to the worlds); Rajasic people live in the middle (human world) and Tamasic people living in extremely inferior tendencies of Tamogun attain degradation.

Original: 14.19 When the seer beholds no agent other than the Gunas and knows That which is higher than they, he attains to My Being.
Translated: ..14.19.. When the seer (seeker) does not see anyone other than the three Gunas as the doer, i.e. does not understand and knows My essence beyond the three Gunas, then he attains My form.

Original: 14.20 The embodied one having crossed beyond these three Gunas out of which the body is evolved, is freed from birth, death, decay and pain, and attains to immortality.
Translated: ..14.20.. This physical man, having gone beyond the three gunas due to the origin of the body, attains immortality and is freed from birth, death, aging and sorrows.

Original: 14.21 Arjuna said  What are the marks of him who has transcended the three alities, O Lord? What is his conduct and how does he go beyond these three alities?
Translated: ..14.21.. Arjun said - Oh Lord! What characteristics does a man who has gone beyond these three qualities possess? What kind of behavior does he have? And, by what means does he go beyond these three qualities?

Original: 14.22 The Blessed Lord said  When light, activity and delusion are present, he hates them not, nor does he long for them when they are absent.
Translated: ..14.22.. Shri Bhagwan said – O Pandava! (The wise man) does not hate light, inclination and attachment even when he is affected by them and does not yearn for them when he retires.

Original: 14.23 He who, seated like one unconcerned, is not moved by the alities, and who, knowing that the alities are active, is self-centred and moves not.
Translated: ..14.23.. One who remains seated like an indifferent person cannot be disturbed by the qualities and remains stable knowing that “the qualities only behave” and does not get distracted from that position.

Original: 14.24 Who is the same in pleasure and pain, who dwells in the Self, to whom a clod of earth, stone and gold are alike, who is the same to the dear and the unfriendly, who is firm, and to whom censure and praise are as one.
Translated: ..14.24.. One who is healthy (situated in form), remains equal in happiness and sorrow and has equanimity among soil, stone and gold; Such a brave man considers what is liked and what is unpleasant and criticism and self-praise as equal.

Original: 14.25 Who is the same in honour and dishonour, the same to friend and foe, abandoning all undertakings  he is said to have transcended the alities.
Translated: ..14.25.. Who is equal in honor and dishonor; There is equality in favor of enemy and friend, such a man who forsakes everything from the beginning is said to be Gunateet.

Original: 14.26 And he who serves Me with unswerving devotion, he, crossing beyond the alities, is fit for becoming Brahman.
Translated: ..14.26.. The man who serves me through unadulterated bhaktiyoga, transcends these three qualities and becomes eligible to become Brahma.

Original: 14.27 For I am the abode of Brahman, the immortal and the immutable, of everlasting Dharma and of absolute bliss.
Translated: ..14.27.. Because I am the establishment of immortality, immortality, Brahma, eternal religion and exclusive i.e. transcendental happiness.

Original: 15.1 The Blessed Lord said  They (the wise) speak of the indestructible peepul tree having its root above and branches below, whose leaves are the metres or hymns: he who knows it is a knower of the Vedas.
Translated: ..15.1.. Shri Bhagwan said - (The wise man calls this worldly tree) Ashvattha and Avya having vertical root and half branch; The one who knows such (worldly tree) whose leaves are verses i.e. Vedas, is a Vedavit.

Original: 15.2 Below and above spread its branches, nourished by the Gunas; sense-objects are its buds; and below, in the world of men, stretch forth the roots, originating action.
Translated: ..15.2.. The branches of that tree, filled with qualities, spread below and above; (Panch) subjects are its shoots; Its other roots, which follow the actions in the human world, are spread below.

Original: 15.3 Its form is not perceived here as such, neither its end nor its origin, nor its foundation nor resting place: having cut asunder this firmly rooted peepul tree with the strong axe of non-attachment.
Translated: 15.3. The form of this (world tree) as stated is not available here, because it has neither beginning nor end nor prestige. By cutting this very strong rooted Ashvattha tree with the strong Asanga weapon...

Original: 15.4 Then That goal should be sought for, whither having gone none returns again. I seek refuge in that Primeval Purusha Whence streamed forth the ancient activity or energy.
Translated: ..15.4.. (After that) one should search for that position which the men having attained do not return to the world again. "I take refuge in that original man from whom this ancient trend has spread."

Original: 15.5 Free from pride and delusion, victorious over the evil of attachment, dwelling constantly in the Self, their desires having completely turned away, freed from the pairs of opposites known as pleasure and pain, the undeluded reach the eternal goal.
Translated: ..15.5.. Those who have given up their pride and attachment, who have conquered the evil of company, who are established in spirituality, whose desires have gone away and who have become free from the dualities called happiness and sorrow, such knowledgeable people who are free from illusions, say that Avyaya Pada. Are received.

Original: 15.6 Neither doth the sun illumine there nor the moon, nor the fire; having gone thither they return not; that is My supreme abode.
Translated: .15.6.. Neither the sun nor the moon nor fire can illuminate it. Having achieved which people do not return again (to the world), that is my supreme abode.

Original: 15.7 An eternal portion of Myself having become a living soul in the world of life, draws to (itself) the (five) senses with the mind for the sixth, abiding in Nature.
Translated: ..15.7.. An eternal part of me has become a living being in this living world. He, situated in nature (at the time of death), pulls the five senses and the mind towards himself, that is, he gathers them.

Original: 15.8 When the Lord (as the individual soul) obtains a body and when He leaves it, He takes these and goes (with them) as the wind takes the scents from their seats (flowers, etc.).
Translated: ..15.8.. When the God (of Dehadi) (the soul) transcends (from one body), then he takes these (the senses and the mind) and takes them to another body in the same way as the wind takes the fragrance from the shelter (flower) of the fragrance. Is..

Original: 15.9 Presiding over the ear, the eye, touch, taste and smell, as well as the mind, it enjoys the objects of the senses.
Translated: ..15.9.. (This living being) consumes the objects by taking shelter of these senses and mind i.e. through hearing, eyes, sense of touch, taste and smell (nose).

Original: 15.10 The deluded do not see Him Who departs, stays and enjoys; but they who possess the eye of knowledge behold Him.
Translated: ..15.10.. Ignorant people do not see the soul, having abandoned the body, being situated in it, or enjoying (objects), integrated with the qualities; (But) men with eyes of knowledge see it.

Original: 15.11 The Yogins striving (for perfection) behold Him dwelling in the Self; but, the unrefined and unintelligent, even though striving, see Him not.
Translated: ..15.11.. Yogis see the soul situated in their heart only by making an effort, whereas people with impure conscience (Akritatman) and irrational (Achetas) do not see it even after making efforts.

Original: 15.12 That light which residing in the sun illumines the whole world, that which is in the moon and in the fire  know that light to be Mine.
Translated: ..15.12.. The glory which resides in the Sun and illuminates the entire world and the glory which is in the Moon and in the fire, know that glory to be mine.

Original: 15.13 Permeating the earth I support all beings by (My) energy; and having become the watery moon I nourish all herbs.
Translated: ..15.13.. It is I who enter the earth and absorb all the matter with my energy and by becoming the moon in the form of essence, I nourish all the medicines i.e. plants.

Original: 15.14 Having become the fire Vaisvanara, I abide in the body of living beings and, associated with the Prana and the Apana, digest the fourfold food.
Translated: ..15.14.. I, in the form of Vaishwanar Agni present in the bodies of all living beings, digest the four types of food consisting of prana and apana.

Original: 15.15 And I am seated in the hearts of all; from Me are memory and knowledge, as well as their absence. I am verily That which has to be known by all the Vedas; I am indeed the author of the Vedanta and the knower of the Vedas am I.
Translated: ..15.15.. I am present in the heart of all living beings. It is from me that memory, knowledge and apohana (their absence) come. I am the object worth knowing through all the Vedas and I am also the knower of Vedanta and the Vedas.

Original:
15.16 Two Purushas there are in this world, the perishable and the imperishable. All beings are 
the perishable and the Kutastha  the unchanging  is called the imperishable.
Translated: ..15.16.. In this world, there are two men, Kshar (mortal) and Akshar (immortal), all beings are Kshar and 'Kutastha' is called Akshar.

Original: 15.17 But distinct is the Supreme Purusha called the highest Self, the indestructible Lord Who, pervading the three worlds, sustains them.
Translated: ..15.17.. But the best person is someone else, who is called God and who is the inseparable God who enters all the three worlds and sustains them all.

Original: 15.18 As I transcend the perishable and am even higher than the imperishable, I am declared to be the highest Purusha in the world and in the Vedas.
Translated: ..15.18.. Because I am beyond Kshar and better than Akshar, that is why I am famous in the world and in the Vedas by the name of Purushottam.

Original: 15.19 He who, undeluded, knows Me thus as the highest Purusha, he, knowing all, worships Me with his whole being (heart), O Arjuna.
Translated: ..15.19.. Hey India! In this way, the person who knows me as the Supreme Being, free from attachment, becomes omniscient and worships me with all his heart, i.e. with all his heart.

Original: 15.20 Thus, this most secret science has been taught by Me, O sinless one; on knowing this, a man becomes wise, and all his duties are accomplished, O Arjuna.
Translated: ..15.20.. Oh innocent India! In this way, this most secret scripture has been told by me, after knowing it a person becomes intelligent and grateful.

Original: 16.1 The Blessed Lord said  Fearlessness, purity of heart, steadfastness in knowledge and Yoga, almsgiving, control of the senses, sacrifice, study of scriptures, austerity and straightforwardness.
Translated: 16.1. Shri Bhagwan said - Fearlessness, purification of conscience, firm position in Gyan Yoga, charity, strength, yajna, self-study, penance and aarjava.

Original: 16.2 Harmlessness, truth, absence of anger, renunciation, peacefulness, absence of crookedness, compassion towards beings, non-covetousness, gentleness, modesty, absence of fickleness.
Translated: 16.2. Non-violence, truth, absence of anger, renunciation, peace, apaishunam (not criticizing anyone), compassion towards the living beings, non-extinction, mardava (tenderness), shyness, restlessness.

Original: 16.3 Vigour, forgiveness, fortitude, purity, absence of hatred, absence of pride  these belong to the one born for a divine state, O Arjuna.
Translated: 16.3. Hey India! Sharpness, forgiveness, patience, purity, rebellion and absence of pride are all the characteristics of a man who has attained divine wealth.

Original: 16.4 Hypocrisy, arrogance and self-conceit, anger and also harshness and ignorance, belong to one who is born for a demoniacal state, O Partha (Arjuna).
Translated: 16.4. Hey Parth! Arrogance, arrogance, pride, anger, harsh speech (Parusya) and ignorance are all demonic possessions.

Original: 16.5 The divine nature is deemed conducive to liberation, and the demoniacal to bondage. Grieve not, O Arjuna, thou art born with divine endowments.
Translated: 16.5. Hey Pandava! Divine wealth is considered for salvation and demonic wealth is considered for bondage, do not grieve, because you have received divine wealth.

Original: 16.6 There are two types of beings in this world, the divine and the demoniacal; the divine has been described at length; hear from Me, O Arjuna, of the demoniacal.
Translated: 16.6. Hey Parth! There are two types of creatures in this world, divine and demonic. In them the nature (divine wealth) of the gods has been described in detail; Now listen to me in detail about the nature of demons.

Original: 16.7 The demoniacal know not what to do and what to refrain from; neither purity, nor right conduct nor truth is found in them.
Translated: ..16.7.. People of demonic nature and tendencies; They know and there is no retirement in them, there is neither purification, nor virtue nor truth.

Original: 16.8 They say, "This universe is without truth, without (moral) basis, without a God, brought about by mutual union, with lust for its cause; what else?"
Translated: ..16.8.. They say that this world is shelterless, unreal and godless, it has arisen only from sexual intercourse (of man and woman), and what could be (the reason for this)?

Original: 16.9 Holding this view, these ruined souls of small intellect and fierce deeds, come forth as the enemies of the world for its destruction.
Translated: ..16.9.. By following this vision, people with low intelligence of destructive nature and who commit grave deeds are born as enemies of the world (wishers of harm) to destroy it.

Original: 16.10 Filled with insatiable desires, full of hypocrisy, pride and arrogance, holding evil ideas through delusion, they work with impure resolves.
Translated: ..16.10.. These people of impure thoughts work in the world, taking refuge in never-fulfillable desires filled with pride, honor and pride, adopting false notions out of delusion.

Original: 16.11 Giving themselves over to immeasurable cares ending only with death, regarding gratification of lust as their highest aim, and feeling sure that that is all.
Translated: ..16.11.. These demonic people, who are suffering from infinite worries that will last till death and consider the enjoyment of sensual pleasures as the ultimate goal, are of the firm opinion that "this much (truth, happiness) is all there is".

Original: 16.12 Bound by a hundred ties of hope, given over to lust and anger, they strive to obtain by unlawful means hoards to wealth for sensual enjoyments.
Translated: ..16.12.. Bound by hundreds of traps, under the influence of lust and anger, these people try to accumulate wealth unjustly to satisfy sensual pleasures.

Original: 16.13 "This has been gained by me today; this desire of mine I shall fuffil; this is mine and this wealth also shall be mine in future."
Translated: ..16.13.. I have achieved this today and will also achieve this desire, I have this much wealth and will have even more wealth in the future.

Original: 16.14 "That enemy has been slain by me; and others also I shall slay. I am the lord. I enjoy. I am perfect, powerful and happy."
Translated: ..16.14.. "This enemy has been killed by me and I will kill other enemies also", "I am God and the enjoyer", "I am a perfect man", "I am strong and happy", etc.

Original: 16.15 "I am rich and born in a noble family. Who else is equal to me? I shall perform sacrifices. I shall give (charity). I shall rejoice," thus deluded by ignorance.
Translated: ..16.15.. "I am born in a rich and noble family. Who else is like me?", 'I will perform yagya', 'I will donate', 'I will have fun' - they are fascinated by this kind of ignorance.

Original: 16.16 Bewildered by many a fancy, entangled in the snare of delusion, addicted to the gratification of lust, they fall into a foul hell.
Translated: ..16.16.. These people, whose minds are confused in many ways, trapped in the web of attachment and engrossed in sensual pleasures, fall into a terrible, unholy hell.

Original: 16.17 Self-conceited, stubborn, filled with the pride and intoxication of wealth, they perform sacrifices in name out of ostentation, contrary to scriptural ordinances.
Translated: 16.17. People who believe themselves to be superior, proud, intoxicated with wealth and honor perform sacrificial sacrifices arrogantly through nominal sacrifices devoid of scriptures.

Original: 16.18 Given over to egoism, power, haughtiness, lust and anger, these malicious people hate Me in their own bodies and in those of others.
Translated: ..16.18.. These people who blaspheme under the influence of ego, force, greed, lust and anger are the ones who hate me (God) present in their own and others' bodies.

Original: 16.19 Those cruel haters, worst among men in the world, I hurl those evil-doers into the wombs of demons only.
Translated: ..16.19.. In this world, I repeatedly drop (Ajasram) those haters, cruel people and evildoers into demonic species.

Original: 16.20 Entering into demoniacal wombs and deluded, birth after birth, not attaining Me, they thus fall, O Arjuna, into a condition still lower than that.
Translated: ..16.20.. Hey Konteya! Those foolish people attain demonic birth in birth after birth and (thus) instead of attaining me, they attain the lowest state.

Original: 16.21 Triple is the gate of this hell, destructive of the self  lust, anger and greed; therefore one should abandon these three.
Translated: ..16.21.. Lust, anger and greed are the three doors of self-destruction, hence these three should be abandoned.

Original: 16.22 A man who is liberated from these three gates to darkness, O Arjuna, practises what is good for him and thus goes to the Supreme Goal.
Translated: ..16.22.. Hey Konteya! A man freed from these three gates of hell pursues the means of his welfare and thus attains the supreme state.

Original: 16.23 He who, having cast aside the ordinances of the scriptures, acts under the impulse of desire, attains not perfection, nor happiness nor the Supreme Goal.
Translated: ..16.23.. The man who abandons the scriptures and works only under the influence of his own desires, neither attains perfection, nor happiness, nor supreme progress.

Original: 16.24 Therefore, let the scripture be thy authority in determining what ought to be done and what ought not to be done. Having known what is said in the ordinance of the scriptures, thou shouldst act here in this world.
Translated: ..16.24.. Therefore, for you, the scriptures are the only proof in the arrangement (decision) of duties and non-duties. You should perform your actions after knowing the rules mentioned in the scriptures.

Original: 17.1 Arjuna said  Those who, setting aside the ordinances of the scriptures, perform sacrifice with faith, what is their condition, O Krishna? Is is Sattva, Rajas or Tamas?
Translated: ..17.1.. Arjun said – O Krishna! What is the condition (loyalty) of those who abandon the scriptures and perform (only) yagya (worship) with devotion? Is it sattvik or rajasik or tamasik?

Original: 17.2 The Blessed Lord said  Threefold is the faith of the embodied, which is inherent in their nature  the Sattvic (pure), the Rajasic (passionate) and the Tamasic (dark). Do thou hear of it.
Translated: 17.2. Shri Bhagwan said - The natural (knowledgeless) faith of embodied beings (human beings) is of three types - Sattvik, Rajasik and Tamasik, listen to it from me.

Original: 17.3 The faith of each is in accordance with his nature, O Arjuna. The man consists of his faith; as a man's faith is, so is he.
Translated: 17.3. O Bharat, the faith of all human beings is according to their Sattva (nature, sanskar). This man has faith, hence the man who has faith is also the same, that is, according to the faith one has, so is his form.

Original: 17.4 The Sattvic or the pure men worship the gods; the Rajasic or the passionate worship the Yakshas and the Rakshasas; the others (the Tamasic or the deluded people) worship the ghosts and the hosts of the nature-spirits.
Translated: ..17.4.. Satvik people worship gods, Rajasic people worship Yakshas and demons, and other Tamasic people worship ghosts and ghosts.

Original: 17.5 Those men who practise terrific austerities not enjoined by the scriptures, given to hypocrisy and egoism, impelled by the force of lust and attachment.
Translated: ..17.5.. Those who perform severe penance devoid of the scriptures and are also filled with pride, ego, lust and attachment.

Original: 17.6 Senseless, torturing all the elements in the body and Me also, Who dwell in the body,  know thou these to be of demonical resolves.
Translated: ..17.6.. And consider those irrational people who are causing pain to the physical world as well as to me as well as the inner self, to have demonic determination.

Original: 17.7 The food also which is dear to each is threefold, as also sacrifice, austerity and almsgiving. Hear thou the distinction of these.
Translated: ..17.7.. (According to one's nature) Everyone's favorite food is also of three types? Yagya in the same way? There are three types of penance and charity? You listen to me about their secret.

Original: 17.8 The foods which increase life, purity, strength, health, joy and cheerfulness (good appetite), which are savoury and oleaginous, substantial and agreeable, are dear to the Sattvic (pure) people.
Translated: ..17.8.. Food items that increase life span, sattva (purity), strength, health, happiness and love and are juicy, smooth (greased with ghee etc.), stable and pleasing to the mind are loved by sattvik people.

Original: 17.9 The foods that are bitter, sour, saline, excessively hot, pungent, dry and burning, are liked by the Rajasic and are productive of pain, grief and disease.
Translated: ..17.9.. Bitter, sour, salty, very hot, pungent, dry. Foods that cause burning, sorrow, grief and disease are dear to a Rajas man.

Original: 17.10 That which is state, tasteless, putrid, rotten, refuse and impure, is the food liked by the Tamasic.
Translated: ..17.10.. Half-ripe, juiceless, foul-smelling, stale, unclean and impure (Amedhya) food is liked by tamasic people.

Original: 17.11 That sacrifice which is offered by men without desire for reward as enjoined by the ordinance (scripture), with a firm faith that to do so is a duty, is Sattvic or pure.
Translated: ..17.11.. The Yagya which is controlled by the scriptures and is performed by people with the determination of “This is my duty” and no desire for results, that Yagya is Sattvik.

Original: 17.12 The sacrifice which is offered, O Arjuna, seeking a reward and for ostentation, know thou that to be a Rajasic Yajna.
Translated: ..17.12.. O great Arjun of Bharat! The yagya which is performed for the sake of pride and with the expectation of results, consider that yagya as rajasic.

Original: 17.13 They declare that sacrifice to be Tamasic which is contrary to the ordinances of the scriptures, in which no food is distributed, which is devoid of Mantras, gifts and faith.
Translated: ..17.13.. The Yagya performed without the scriptures, without food donation, without mantras, without Dakshina and without faith is called Tamas Yagya.

Original: 17.14 Worship of the gods, the twice-born, the teachers and the wise, purity, straightforwardness, celibacy and non-injury are called the austerities of the body.
Translated: ..17.14.. Worship of Gods, Dwija (Brahmins), Gurus and knowledgeable people, defecation, Aarjava (simplicity), celibacy and non-violence, these are called penances related to the body.

Original: 17.15 Speech which causes no excitement, truthful, pleasant and beneficial, the practice of the study of the Vedas, are called austerity of speech.
Translated: ..17.15.. The sentence (speech) which does not cause excitement, which is beloved, beneficial and true and the practice of self-study of the Vedas is called Vammay (speech) penance.

Original: 17.16 Serenity of mind, good-heartedness, self-control, purity of nature  this is called mental austerity.
Translated: ..17.16.. Happiness of mind, gentleness, silent self-control and purification of conscience, all this is called mental penance.

Original: 17.17 This threefold austerity, practised by steadfast men, with the utmost faith, desiring no reward, they call Sattvic.
Translated: ..17.17.. The above mentioned threefold penance, performed with utmost devotion by wise men who have no desire for results, is called Sattvik.

Original: 17.18 The austerity which is practised with the object of gaining good reception, honour and worship, and with hypocrisy, is here said to be Rajasic, unstable and transitory.
Translated: ..17.18.. The penance which is done for the sake of respect, honor and worship or only out of pride (hypocrisy), that indefinite and momentary penance is called Rajas here.

Original: 17.19 That austerity which is practised out of a foolish notion, with self-torture, or for the purpose of destroying another, is declared to be Tamasic.
Translated: ..17.19.. The penance which is done foolishly by causing suffering to oneself or to destroy other people is called Tamasic penance.

Original: 17.20 That gift which is given to one who does nothing in return, knowing it to be a duty to give in a fit place and time to a worthy person, that gift is held to be Sattvic.
Translated: ..17.20.. "Giving charity is a duty" - In this sense, the charity which is given to a worthy deserving person (person) considering the country and time, from whom no return is expected, is considered to be a Satvik charity.

Original: 17.21 And, that gift which is given with a view to receive something in return, or looking for a reward, or reluctantly, is held to be Rajasic.
Translated: ..17.21.. And the charity which is given out of pain and for the purpose of retribution or with the desire of getting results, is considered Rajasic.

Original: 17.22 The gift that is given at a wrong place and time, to unworthy persons, without respect or with insult is declared to be Tamasic.
Translated: ..17.22.. The charity which is given without respect, or contemptuously, in unworthy times, to deserving people, is considered to be Tamasic.

Original: 17.23 "Om Tat Sat": This has been declared to be the triple designation of Brahman. By that were created formerly, the Brahmanas, the Vedas and the sacrifices.
Translated: ..17.23.. 'Om, Tat Sat' is said to be the threefold instruction (name) of Brahma; From that in ancient times (Pura) Brahman, Vedas and Yagya were created.

Original: 17.24 Therefore, with the utterance of "Om" are the acts of sacrifice, gift and austerity as enjoined in the scriptures, always begun by the students of Brahman.
Translated: ..17.24.. Therefore, the activities of Yagya, charity and penance as prescribed in the scriptures of Brahmaists always begin with the recitation of Omkar.

Original: 17.25 Uttering ï1Tatï1, without aiming at the fruits, are the acts of sacrifice and austerity and the various acts of gifts performed by the seekers of liberation.
Translated: ..17.25.. By uttering the word 'Tat', without desiring any result, Mumukshujan performs various acts like Yagya, penance, charity etc.

Original: 17.26 The word ï1Satï1 is used in the sense of reality and of goodness; and so also, O Arjuna, the word ï1Satï1 is used in the sense of an auspicious act.
Translated: ..17.26.. Hey Parth! The word 'Sat' is used in the sense of truth and good deeds, and the word 'Sat' is used in the sense of good (best, auspicious) action.

Original: 17.27 Steadfastness in sacrifice, austerity and gift, is also called 'Sat' and also action in connection with these (or for the sake of the Supreme) is called 'Sat'.
Translated: ..17.27.. A firm stance in Yagya, penance and charity is also called Sat, and the work done for Him (God) is also called Sat.

Original: 17.28 Whatever is sacrificed, given or performed, and whatever austerity is practised without faith, it is called 'Asat', O Arjuna; it is naught here or hereafter (after death).
Translated: ..17.28.. Hey Parth! The yagya, charity, penance and work which is done without faith is called 'Asat'; It is beneficial neither in this world (ih) nor after death (in that world).

Original: 18.1 Arjuna said  I desire to know severally, O mighty-armed, the essence or truth of renunciation, O Hrishikesa, as also of abandonment, O slayer of Kesi.
Translated: ..18.1.. Arjun said - O mighty arm! Hey Hrishikesh! Hey Keshanishudan! I want to know the elements of renunciation and renunciation separately.

Original: 18.2 The Blessed Lord said  The sages understand Sannyasa to be the renunciation of action with desire; the wise declare the abandonment of the fruits of all actions as Tyaga.
Translated: 18.2. Sri Bhagavan said - (Some) poets (pundits) consider renunciation of lustful deeds as 'Sanyas' and thoughtful people call renunciation of the fruits of all deeds as 'Tyaga'.

Original: 18.3 Some philosophers declare that actions should be abandoned as an evil; while others (declare) that acts of sacrifice, gift and austerity should not be relinished.
Translated: 18.3. Some sages say that all actions are worth relinquishing because they are flawed; And others say that yagya, charity and penance are not shunable.

Original: 18.4 Hear from Me the conclusion or the final truth about this abandonment, O best of the Bharatas; abandonment, verily, O best of men, has been declared to be of three kinds.
Translated: ..18.4.. Hey Bharatsattam! You listen to my decision regarding that sacrifice. O great man! That sacrifice has been said to be of three types.

Original: 18.5 Acts of sacrifice, gift and austerity should not be abandoned, but should be performed; sacrifice, gift and also austerity are the purifiers of the wise.
Translated: ..18.5.. Yagya, charity and penance are not something to be forsaken, but they are undoubtedly a duty; Yagya, charity and penance purify the mystics.

Original: 18.6 But even these actions should be performed leaving aside attachment and the desire for rewards, O Arjuna; this is My certain and best conviction.
Translated: ..18.6.. Hey Parth! These actions should also be performed by abandoning the fruits and attachments, this is my firm opinion.

Original: 18.7 Verily the renunciation of obligatory action is not proper; the abandonment of the same from delusion is declared to be Tamasic.
Translated: ..18.7.. It is not right to abandon one's duty; Renunciation of attachment due to attachment is called “Tamas renunciation”.

Original: 18.8 He who abandons action on account of the fear of bodily trouble (because it is painful), does not obtain the merit of renunciation by doing such Rajasic renunciation.
Translated: ..18.8.. The person who considers his work as a sorrow and renounces it due to the fear of physical pain, that man never attains the fruit of renunciation by making that rajasic renunciation.

Original: 18.9 Whatever obligatory action is done, O Arjuna, merely because it ought to be done, abandoning attachment and also the desire for reward, that renunciation is regarded as Sattvic (pure).
Translated: ..18.9.. Hey Arjun! The duty which is performed with the understanding that it is a duty to do it, renouncing attachment and results, is considered as sattvik renunciation.

Original: 18.10 The man of renunciation, pervaded by purity, intelligent, and with his doubts cut asunder, does not hate a disagreeable work nor is he attached to an agreeable one.
Translated: ..18.10.. The man who does not hate unskilled (inauspicious) deeds and is not attached to skilled (auspicious) deeds, that man who is full of Sattva Guna, is free from doubt, intelligent (knowledgeable) and a renouncer.

Original: 18.11 Verily, it is not possible for an embodied being to abandon actions entirely; but he who relinishes the rewards of actions is verily called a man of renunciation.
Translated: ..18.11.. Because it is not possible for a human being to give up the remaining karmas, the one who has renounced the fruits of his actions is called a renunciationist.

Original: 18.12 The threefold fruit of action (evil, good and mixed) accrues after death to the non-abandoners, but never to the abandoners.
Translated: ..18.12.. These threefold fruits of auspicious, inauspicious and mixed deeds are received only by the renunciant people even after death; But never to sannyasi men.

Original: 18.13 Learn from Me, O mighty-armed Arjuna, these five causes as declared in the Sankhya system for the accomplishment of all actions.
Translated: ..18.13.. Oh great arms! These five reasons for the accomplishment of all actions have been stated in the Sankhya principle, which you should know very well from me.

Original: 18.14 The seat (body), the doer, the various senses, the different functions of various sorts, and the presiding deity, also, the fifth.
Translated: ..18.14.. Adhishthana (body), subject, various causes (senses etc.), various and different movements and the fifth reason is God.

Original: 18.15 Whatever action a man performs with his body, speech and mind  whether right or the reverse  these five are its causes.
Translated: ..18.15.. Whatever right or wrong action a person does with his body, speech and mind, these are the five reasons for it.

Original: 18.16 Now, such being the case, verily he who  owing to untrained understanding  looks upon his Self, which is isolated, as the agent, he of perverted intelligence, sees not.
Translated: ..18.16.. Now in this situation, the person who, due to his uncultured intellect, considers only the pure soul as the doer, does not see the evil person (the reality).

Original:
18.17 He who is free from the egoistic notion, whose intelligence is not tainted (by good or evil), 
though he slays these people, he slayeth not, nor is he bound (by the action).
Translated: ..18.17.. The man who does not have the feeling of ego and whose intellect is not attached to any (good or bad) thing, even after killing all these worlds, that man neither actually dies nor gets bound (by sin).

Original: 18.18 Knowledge, the knowable and the knower form the threefold impulse to action; the organ, the action and the agent form the threefold basis of action.
Translated: ..18.18.. Knowledge, knowable and knower, these three ways are the drivers of action, and, Karan, Karma. The subject is a collection of threefold action.

Original: 18.19 Knowledge, action and actor are declared in the science of the Gunas (Sankhya philosophy) to be of three kinds only, according to the distinction of the Gunas. Of these also, hear duly.
Translated: ..18.19.. Knowledge, action and doer are also called triple in Sankhyashastra (Gunasankhyanae) due to the difference of qualities; You should listen to them as per the correct form from me.

Original: 18.20 That by which one sees the one indestructible Reality in all beings, not separate in all the separate beings  know thou that knowledge to be Sattvic.
Translated: ..18.20.. The knowledge by which man sees the one undivided and imperishable (Avyaya) form in all the entities existing in divided form, you should consider that knowledge as Sattvik.

Original: 18.21 But that knowledge which sees in all beings various entities of distinct kinds as different from one another  know thou that knowledge to be Rajasic.
Translated: ..18.21.. The knowledge through which a man knows different aspects of all the beings, you should consider that knowledge as Rajas.

Original: 18.22 But that which clings to one single effect as if it were the whole, without reason, without foundation in Truth, and trivial  that is declared to be Tamasic.
Translated: ..18.22.. And the knowledge through which a person becomes attached to a work (body) as if that (work itself) is the complete thing and which (knowledge) is without reason (irrational), devoid of meaning and narrow (limited), that (knowledge) ) is tamas.

Original: 18.23 An action which is ordained, which is free from attachment, and which is done without love or hatred by one who is not desirous of any reward  that action is declared to be Sattvic.
Translated: ..18.23.. The action which is determined (according to the scriptures) and has no accompaniment, and is done without any attachment or aversion by a person who does not want the result, that (action) is called Sattvik.

Original: 18.24 But that action which is done by one longing for the fulfilment of desires or gain with egoism or with much effort  that is declared to be Rajasic (passionate).
Translated: ..18.24.. And the work which involves a lot of hard work and is done by a man full of ego and desirous of results, that work is called Rajasic.

Original: 18.25 That action which is undertaken from delusion, without a regard for the conseences, loss, injury and (one's own) ability  that is declared to be Tamasic (dark).
Translated: ..18.25.. The work which is started only out of attachment without considering the consequences, harm, violence and power (Paurusham), is called Tamasic work.

Original: 18.26 An agent who is free from attachment, non-egoistic, endowed with firmness and enthusiasm, and unaffected by success or failure, is called Sattvic (pure).
Translated: ..18.26.. The doer who is free from attachments, free from egoism, full of patience and enthusiasm and remains unperturbed in the accomplishment (success) and asiddhi (failure) of the work, is called Sattvik.

Original: 18.27 Passionate, desiring to obtain the reward of actions, greedy, cruel, impure, moved by joy and sorrow, such an agent is said to be Rajasic (passionate).
Translated: ..18.27.. The doer who is passionate, desirous of the fruits of action, greedy, violent in nature, impure and filled with joy and sorrow is called Rajas.

Original: 18.28 Unsteady, vulgar, unbending, cheating, malicious, lazy, desponding and procrastinating  such an agent is called Tamasic.
Translated: ..18.28.. Ayutka, Prakrit, stunned, false, natural, lazy, melancholy and long-winded doer is called Tamas.

Original: 18.29 Hear thou the threefold division of intellect and firmness according to the Gunas, as I declare them fully and distinctly, O Arjuna.
Translated: ..18.29.. Hey Dhananjay! Listen to the threefold difference between intelligence and wisdom arising from the gunas, spoken about by me in essence and separately.

Original: 18.30 The intellect which knows the path of work and renunciation, what ought to be done and what ought not to be done, fear and fearlessness, bondage and liberation  that intellect is Sattvic (pure), O Arjuna.
Translated: ..18.30.. Hey Parth! The intellect which knows the principle of tendency and withdrawal, action and non-action, fear and fearlessness, bondage and salvation, is that intellect which is Satvik.

Original: 18.31 That, by which one wrongly understands Dharma and Adharma and also what ought to be done and what ought not to be done  that intellect, O Arjuna, is Rajasic (passionate).
Translated: ..18.31.. Hey Parth! The intellect by which a man does not know righteousness and unrighteousness and what is duty and what is not, is a royal intellect.

Original: 18.32 That, which, enveloped in darkness, sees Adharma as Dharma and all things perverted  that intellect, O Arjuna, is Tamasic (dark).
Translated: ..18.32.. Hey Parth! The intellect which is covered with Tamas (darkness of ignorance) and considers unrighteousness as religion and knows all things in opposite ways, that intellect is Tamasic.

Original: 18.33 The unwavering firmness by which, through Yoga, the functions of the mind, the life-force and the senses are restrained  that firmness, O Arjuna, is Sattvic (pure).
Translated: ..18.33.. It is sattvikhi.

Original: 18.34 But that, O Arjuna, by which, on account of attachment and desire for reward, one holds fast to Dharma (duty), enjoyment of pleasures and earning of wealth  that firmness, O Arjuna, is Rajasic (passionate).
Translated: ..18.34.. Oh Arjun, son of Pritha! The Dhriti by which a man desirous of achieving the results of his actions, with extreme attachment (context), adheres to Dharma, Artha and Kama (these three purushaarthas), that Dhriti is royal.

Original: 18.35 That, by which a stupid man does not abandon sleep, fear, grief, despair and also conceit  that firmness, O Arjuna, is Tamasic.
Translated: ..18.35.. Yes Parth! The Dharti by which an unintelligent person does not give up dreams, fear, grief, sadness and intoxication is Tamasic.

Original: 18.36 And now hear from Me, O Arjuna, of the threefold pleasure, in which one rejoices by practice and surely comes to the end of pain.
Translated: ..18.36.. O Bharatashrestha! Now listen to me about the threefold happiness, in which (the devotee) enjoys through practice and attains the end of his sorrows (where his sorrows come to an end).

Original: 18.37 That which is like poison at first but in the end like nectar  that happiness is declared to be Sattvic, born of the purity of one's own mind due to Self-realisation.
Translated: ..18.37.. The happiness which at first (in the beginning) seems like poison, but in the end is like nectar, that happiness arising from the offerings of self-intellect is said to be Sattvik.

Original: 18.38 That happiness which arises from the contact of the sense-organs with the objects, which is at first like nectar, and in the end like poison  that is declared to be Rajasic.
Translated: ..18.38.. The happiness which arises from the combination of objects and senses, which is like nectar at first, but which is like poison in the end, is called Rajasic happiness.

Original: 18.39 That happiness which at first as well as in the seel deludes the self, and which arises from sleep, indolence and heedlessness  that is declared to be Tamasic.
Translated: ..18.39.. The happiness which fascinates the soul (man) in the beginning as well as in the outcome (contract), that happiness arising from sleep, laziness and carelessness is called Tamasic.

Original: 18.40 There is no being on earth or again in heaven among the gods, that is liberated from the three alities born of Nature.
Translated: ..18.40.. There is no such being on earth or among the gods in heaven who is free from these three qualities arising from nature.

Original: 18.41 Of Brahmanas, Kshatriyas and Vaisyas, as also of Sudras, O Arjuna, the duties are distributed according to the alities born of their own nature.
Translated: ..18.41.. O Parantap!  The actions of Brahmins, Kshatriyas, Vaishyas and Shudras have been divided according to the qualities arising from nature.

Original: 18.42 Serenity, self-restraint, austerity, purity, forgiveness and also uprightness, knowledge, realisation and belief in God are the duties of the Brahmanas, born of (their own) nature.
Translated: ..18.42.. Sham, Dam, Tapa, Shaucha, Kshanti, Aarjava, Gyan, Vijnana and Astikya - these are the natural actions of a Brahmin.

Original: 18.43 Prowess, splendour, firmness, dexterity and also not fleeing from battle, generosity and lordliness are the duties of the Kshatriyas, born of (their own) nature.
Translated: ..18.43.. Courage, sharpness, agility, Dakshya (efficiency), not running away from battle, charity and devotion to God (Lord Bhava) - all these are the natural deeds of a Kshatriya.

Original: 18.44 Agriculture, cattle-rearing and trade are the duties of the Vaisya (merchant), born of (their own) nature; and action consisting of service is the duty of the Sudra (servant-class), born of (their own) nature.
Translated: ..18.44.. Agriculture, cow rearing and commerce - these are the natural duties of a Vaishya, and the natural duty of a Shudra is to look after or serve.

Original: 5.10 He who does actions, offering them to Brahman, and abandoning attachment, is not tainted by sin, just as a lotus-leaf is not tainted by water.
Translated: ..5.10.. The man who performs all his actions by offering them to Brahma and renouncing attachment, is not indulged in sins like a lotus leaf.

Original: 18.46 He from Whom all the beings have evolved and by Whom all this is pervaded  worshipping Him with his own duty, man attains perfection.
Translated: ..18.46.. By worshiping that (God) from whom the existence of existence has originated and from whom this entire world is pervaded, man attains success by worshiping that (God) through his own actions.

Original: 18.47 Better is one's own duty (though) destitute of merits, than the duty of another well performed. He who does the duty ordained by his own nature incurs no sin.
Translated: ..18.47.. Self-righteousness without virtues is better than rightly practiced other-righteousness. (Because) man does not commit sin by performing the actions prescribed by his nature.

Original: 18.48 One should not abandon, O Arjuna, the duty to which one is born, though faulty; for, all undertakings are enveloped by evil, as fire by smoke.
Translated: ..18.48.. Hey Konteya! One should not abandon spontaneous action even if it is flawed; Because all actions are covered with defects, like fire with smoke.

Original: 18.49 He whose intellect is unattached everywhere, who has subdued his self, from whom desire has fled,  he by renunciation, attains the supreme state of freedom from action.
Translated: ..18.49.. That man with an intellect free from attachment everywhere, who is free from desires and is a living soul, attains the ultimate selflessness through renunciation.

Original: 18.50 Learn from Me in brief, O Arjuna, how he who has attained perfection reaches Brahman (the Eternal), that supreme state of knowledge.
Translated: ..18.50.. Know from me in brief how a man who has attained Siddhi attains Brahma, and also the supreme devotion of knowledge.

Original: 18.51 Endowed with a pure intellect, controlling the self by firmness, relinishing sound and other objects and abandoning attraction and hatred.
Translated: ..18.51.. Having a pure intellect, having self-control with perseverance, giving up matters like words and giving up attachment and hatred.... ॥ ॥ ॥.

Original: 18.52 Dwelling in solitude, eating but little, with speech, body and mind subdued, always engaged in meditation and concentration, resorting to dispassion.
Translated: ..18.52.. Vivikt Sevi, Laghvashi (Mitahari), who has controlled his body, speech and mind, always ready in the practice of meditation and dependent on renunciation.

Original: 18.53 Having abandoned egoism, strength, arrogance, desire, anger and covetousness, and free from the notion of 'mine' and peaceful,  he is fit for becoming Brahman.
Translated: ..18.53.. By renouncing ego, force, lust, lust, anger and attachment, a man who is free from attachment and is peaceful becomes capable of attaining Brahma.

Original: 18.54 Becoming Brahman, serene in the Self, he neither grieves nor desires, the same to all beings, he obtains supreme devotion to Me.
Translated: ..18.54.. Brahmabhuta (the seeker who has become Brahma), a man with a happy mind, neither desires nor grieves, being equal towards all beings, he attains supreme devotion towards Me.

Original: 18.55 By devotion he knows Me in truth, what and who I am; then having known Me in truth, he forthwith enters into the Supreme.
Translated: ..18.55.. Through (that supreme) devotion he knows Me in essence, how extensive I am and what I am. (In this way) after knowing the Tattva, it immediately enters into me, that is, it becomes the form of Matswarupa.

Original: 18.56 Doing all actions always having taken refuge in Me, by My grace he obtains the eternal indestructible state of being.
Translated: ..18.56.. The person who always performs all the deeds while being dependent on alcohol, attains eternal, imperishable status by my grace.

Original: 18.57 Mentally renouncing all actions in Me, having Me as the highest goal, resorting to the Yoga of discrimination do thou ever fix thy mind on Me.
Translated: ..18.57.. By renouncing all actions from your mind in Me, being devoted to the mind, and taking refuge in the Yoga of your intellect, become constantly mindful.

Original: 18.58 Fixing thy mind on Me, thou shalt by My grace overcome all obstacles; but if from egoism thou wilt not hear Me, thou shalt perish.
Translated: ..18.58.. By becoming alert, you will overcome all difficulties (Sarvadurgani) by my grace; And if you do not listen (to this sermon) out of ego, you will be destroyed.

Original: 18.59 If, filled with egoism, thou thinkest: "I will not fight", vain is this, thy resolve; Nature will compel thee.
Translated: ..18.59.. And out of ego you are thinking, "I will not fight", this is your determination that is false, (because) nature (your nature) itself will push you (to violent action).

Original: 18.60 O Arjuna, bound by thy own Karma (action) born of thy own nature, that which from delusion thou wishest not to do, even that thou shalt do helplessly.
Translated: ..18.60.. Hey Konteya! You are bound by your natural actions, (so) out of attachment, you will be forced to do the actions that you do not want to do.

Original: 18.61 The Lord dwells in the hearts of all beings, O Arjuna, causing all beings, by His illusive power, to revolve as if mounted on a machine.
Translated: ..18.61.. O Arjun, God rotates all the ghosts (as if) mounted on some machine with his illusion (Bhramayan) and resides in the heart of every living being.

Original: 18.62 Fly unto Him for refuge with all thy being, O Arjuna; by His grace thou shalt obtain supreme peace (and) the eternal abode.
Translated: ..18.62.. Hey India! You surrender yourself to Him (God) with all your heart. With his offerings you will attain ultimate peace and eternal abode.

Original: 18.63 Thus has wisdom, more secret than secrecy itself, been declared unto thee by Me; having reflected over it fully, then act as thou wishest.
Translated: ..18.63.. In this way I told you more secret knowledge than all secrets; After giving complete consideration to this, do as per your wish.

Original: 18.64 Hear thou again My supreme word, most secret of all; because thou art dearly beloved of Me, I will tell thee what is good.
Translated: ..18.64.. Once again you hear from me the most secret message (sermon) of all secrets. You are very dear to me, so I will tell you what is in your interest.

Original: 18.65 Fix thy mind on Me, by devoted to Me, sacrifice to Me, bow down to Me. Thou shalt come even to Me; truly do I promise unto thee, (for) thou art dear to Me.
Translated: ..18.65.. You become a mad devotee and my worshiper (Madyaji) and salute me; (Thus) you will attain me only; I give you this true promise, (because) you are my favorite.

Original: 18.66 Abandoning all duties, take refuge in Me alone: I will liberate thee from all sins; grieve not.
Translated: ..18.66.. Abandoning all religions, you take refuge in me alone, I will free you from all sins, do not grieve.

Original: 18.67 This is never to be spoken by thee to one who is devoid of austerities or devotion, nor to one who does not render service or who does not desire to listen, nor to one who cavils at Me.
Translated: ..18.67.. This knowledge should not be told to a person who is atapaska (without penance), nor to one who is a non-devotee; Not even to the one who is Ashushrushu (eager in service) and also not to the person who is jealous of me (God), that is, sees faults in me.

Original: 18.68 He who with supreme devotion to Me will teach this supreme secret to My devotees, shall doubtlessly come to Me.
Translated: ..18.68.. The person who, with utmost love for Me (para bhakti), preaches this supreme secret knowledge to My devotees, undoubtedly attains Me.

Original: 18.69 Nor is there any among men who does dearer service to Me, nor shall there be another on earth dearer to Me than he.
Translated: ..18.69.. Neither is there anyone among humans who does a work more dear to me than him, nor will there be anyone else on this earth more dear to me than him.

Original: 18.70 And he who will study this sacred dialogue of ours, by him I shall have been worshipped by the sacrifice of wisdom,  such is My conviction.
Translated: ..18.70.. I believe that the person who will read this religious dialogue between us will be worshiped with the Yagya of knowledge.

Original: 18.71 Also the man who hears this, full of faith and free from malice, he, too, liberated, shall attain to the happy worlds of those of righteous deeds.
Translated: ..18.71.. And the devout and unsuspecting person who even listens to this will be freed from sins and will attain the auspicious (best) worlds of virtuous people.

Original: 18.72 Has this been heard, O Arjuna, with one-pointed mind? Has the delusion of thy ignorance been destroyed, O Dhananjaya?
Translated: ..18.72.. Hey Parth! Did you listen to it (my sermon) with concentration? And O Dhananjay! Has your illusion born of ignorance been completely destroyed?

Original: 18.73 Arjuna said  Destroyed is my delusion as I have gained my knowledge (memory) through Thy grace, O Krishna. I remain freed from doubts. I will act according to Thy word.
Translated: ..18.73.. Arjun said – O Achyuta! By your grace has my attachment been destroyed, and have I attained memory (knowledge)? Now I have become free from doubts and I will obey your word (order).

Original: 18.74 Sanjaya said  Thus I have heard this wonderful dialogue between Krishna and the high-souled Arjuna, which causes the hair to stand on end.
Translated: ..18.74.. Sanjay said - This is how I described this wonderful and exciting dialogue between Lord Vasudev and Mahatma Arjun.

Original: 18.75 Through the grace of Vyasa I have heard this supreme and most secret Yoga direct from Krishna, the Lord of Yoga, Himself declaring it.
Translated: ..18.75.. By the grace of Vyas ji, I heard this supreme secret yoga being said in person from Lord Shri Krishna himself.

Original: 18.76 O King, remembering this wonderful and holy dialogue between Krishna and Arjuna, I rejoice again and again.
Translated: ..18.76.. Oh king! I feel happy again and again remembering this wonderful and virtuous conversation between Lord Keshav and Arjuna.

Original: 18.77 And, remembering again and again, also that most wonderful form of Hari, great is my wonder, O King; and I rejoice again and again.
Translated: ..18.77.. Hey king! Remembering again and again the wonderful form of Shri Hari gives me great astonishment and I feel happy again and again.

Original: 18.78 Wherever is Krishna, the Lord of Yoga; wherever is Arjuna, the wielder of the bow; there are prosperity, victory, happiness and firm policy; such is my conviction.
Translated: ..18.78.. Where Yogeshwar is Shri Krishna and where archer Arjun is there, there is Shri, Vijay, Vibhuti and Dhruva Niti, this is my opinion.
